CHAPTER 5
VILLAGE PRESIDENT
SECTION:
1-5-1: Bond; Oath; Compensation
1-5-2: Powers And Duties
1-5-3: Unanticipated Expenditures
1-5-4: President Pro Tem; Temporary Chair
1-5-1: BOND; OATH; COMPENSATION:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the President shall give a bond
with sureties to be approved by the Board of Trustees, conditioned upon his
faithful performance of his duties, in the sum of three thousand dollars
($3,000.00). He shall take the oath of office as prescribed by statute and
shall receive such compensation as may be set from time to time by the Board.
(Ord. 1318, 2-28-2018)
1-5-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Village President is the Chief Executive Officer of the Village, with
duties and rights and powers prescribed by laws of the State, by this Code, or
by "Robert's Rules of Order" (when not in conflict with State law or this
Code). In addition, the President shall perform all such other duties and have
all additional powers that are or may be prescribed by the laws of the State or
the provisions of this Code. (Ord. 1318, 2-28-2018)
1-5-3: UNANTICIPATED EXPENDITURES:
The Village President has authority to spend up to twenty thousand dollars
($20,000.00) without previous Board approval solely upon his authority for
unanticipated or emergency expenditures. Any such expenditures shall be
presented to the Village Board at the next meeting practicable. (Ord. 1333, 9-
26-2018)
1-5-4: PRESIDENT PRO TEM; TEMPORARY CHAIR:
   A.   President Pro Tem: If a temporary absence from the Village or
disability of the President incapacitates him or her from the performance of
his or her duties but does not create a vacancy in the office, the President
Pro Tem, during such absence or disability of the President, shall perform the
duties and possess all the rights and powers of the President. The President
Pro Tem shall be a member of the Board of Trustees and shall be elected by a
simple majority of the Board of Trustees, at the first Board meeting following
the incapacity of the President, and shall serve until the President's
incapacity ends or until a new President takes office, whichever occurs first.
Nothing in this section shall deprive the President Pro Tem from voting in his
or her capacity as Trustee, but he or she shall not be entitled to another vote
in his or her capacity as President Pro Tem.
   B.   Temporary Chair: If the President or President Pro Tem is unable or
fails to attend a meeting of the Board of Trustees, the Board shall elect a
temporary Chair who shall have the power of the presiding officer and the right
to vote in his capacity as Trustee. (Ord. 1318, 2-28-2018)
CHAPTER 6
VILLAGE BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-6-1: Elected Officials; Qualifications; Term
1-6-2: Meetings
1-6-3: Quorum
1-6-4: Order Of Business
1-6-5: Procedures
1-6-6: Trustee Liaison To Commissions And Zoning Board Of Appeals
1-6-7: Additional Board Assignments
1-6-8: Remote Attendance At Meetings
1-6-1: ELECTED OFFICIALS; QUALIFICATIONS; TERM:
The Board of Trustees shall consist of the Village President and six (6)
Trustees, who shall be citizens of the United States, qualified electors and
shall have resided in the Village at least one year next preceding the
election. They shall hold office for four (4) years, three (3) Trustees to be
elected every two (2) years, and until their successors are elected and
qualified, unless otherwise provided by law. (1977 Code §
2-3-1; amd. 2004 Code)
1-6-2: MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The regular meetings of the Board of Trustees shall
be held on the third Wednesday of each month at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M.,
unless otherwise provided by the Board of Trustees. The regular meeting place
shall be the North Barrington Village Hall unless otherwise ordered by the
Board.
   B.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be called by the Village
President or any three (3) Trustees. Public notice of any special meeting,
except a meeting held in the event of a bona fide emergency, shall be given at
least forty eight (48) hours before such meeting, which notice shall also
include the agenda for the special meeting. Notice shall be given to the
President and the Trustees and otherwise as then required by statute.
   C.   Time Limit For Meetings: Regular, special and committee meetings of the
Village Board shall not extend beyond ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. (central time),
except closed sessions, unless authorized by a majority vote of the Board of
Trustees or committee members.
   D.   Open Meetings: All meetings of the Village Board of Trustees shall be
open to the public unless otherwise excepted by law. (1977 Code § 2-3-3; amd.
2004 Code; Ord. 889, 5-20-2002; Ord. 1164, 8-15-2009; Ord. 1359; 12-18-2019)
1-6-3: QUORUM:
A majority of the President and Trustees then holding office shall constitute a
quorum to do business, but no ordinance shall be passed except upon the
favorable vote of a majority of the corporate authorities then holding office,
as provided by statutes. (1977 Code § 2-3-6; amd. 2004 Code)
1-6-4: ORDER OF BUSINESS:
   A.   Order Of Business Established: The order of business of the Board of
Trustees shall be as follows:
      1.   Roll call.
      2.   Approval of minutes of the preceding meeting.
      3.   Other matters in the order set forth on the agenda.
      4.   Adjournment.
   B.   Changes: The corporate authorities, by majority vote, can change the
order of business.
   C.   Agenda: The agenda shall be prepared by the President or pursuant to
the President's direction. (1977 Code § 2-3-7)
1-6-5: PROCEDURES:
   A.   Voting By President: The President of the Board of Trustees shall not
vote except in the following situations:
      1.   The vote of the Trustees has resulted in a tie; or
      2.   When one-half (1/2) of the Trustees have voted in favor of any
ordinance, resolution or motion even though there is no tie vote; or
      3.   When a vote greater than a majority of the corporate authorities is
required by state statute or local ordinance to adopt an ordinance, resolution
or motion. (2004 Code)
   B.   Robert's Rules Of Order: Insofar as the procedures for the conduct of
meetings and actions of the corporate authorities or any commission, committee
or officer are not regulated by state statutes, this code or any other
ordinance or resolution of the Village, "Robert's Rules Of Order" shall govern.
(1977 Code § 2-3-5)
   C.   Disturbing Meetings: It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any
meeting of the Board of Trustees or of any committee thereof. (1977 Code § 2-3-
9; amd. Ord. 1206, 6-29-2011)
   D.   Suspension Of Rules: The rules of order, other than those prescribed by
statutes, may be suspended at any time by the consent of a majority of the
members present at any meeting. (1977 Code § 2-3-10; amd. Ord. 1206, 6-29-2011)
1-6-6: TRUSTEE LIAISON TO COMMISSIONS AND ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS:
   A.   Liaison Appointed: One or more trustees may be appointed by the Village
President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees to the following
commissions and boards of the Village as the same shall exist from time to
time:
Environmental and Health Commission
Ethics Commission
Finance and Budget Commission
Parks and Recreation Commission
Plan Commission
Zoning Board of Appeals (Ord. 895, 7-22-2002; amd. Ord. 1040, 6-28-2004; Ord.
1129, 12-17-2007)
   B.   Notice Of Meetings: The assigned Trustee liaison shall be notified of
such meeting of the commission or board at least forty eight (48) hours in
advance thereof. (Ord. 895, 7-22-2002)
1-6-7: ADDITIONAL BOARD ASSIGNMENTS:
In addition to liaisons to commissions and boards, there are responsibilities
within the Village which may be assigned to Trustees for areas of concentrated
diligence. These assignments are made by the Village President with the advice
and consent of the Board of Trustees and may include, but are not limited to:
roads, stormwater management, building, mosquito abatement, utilities, legal,
newsletter editor, website manager, Village lands, police, fire and public
safety. (Ord. 895, 7-22-2002)
1-6-8: REMOTE ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS:
A.   A trustee may attend a regular or special meeting without being physically
present if physical attendance is prevented by:
   1.   Personal illness or disability;
   2.   Absence from the Village for personal employment purposes or for
Village business;
   3.   Family or other emergency, which emergency shall be stated on the
record and be part of the minutes of that meeting.
B.   If a trustee wishes to attend a regular or special meeting of the Village
Board by electronic means, the trustee must notify the Village Clerk before the
meeting unless advanced notice is impractical.
C.   The clerk, after receiving the electronic attendance request, shall inform
the Village Board of the request for electronic attendance. After establishing
that there is a quorum physically present at a meeting where a member of the
Village Board desires to attend electronically, the presiding officer shall
state that (i) a notice was received by a member of the Village Board in
accordance with Village ordinance, and (ii) the member of the Village Board
will be deemed authorized to attend the meeting electronically unless a motion
objecting to the member's electronic attendance is made, seconded, and approved
by two thirds of the members of the Village Board physically present at the
meeting. If no such motion is made and seconded or if any such motion fails to
achieve the required vote by the members of the Village Board physically
present at the meeting, then the request by the member of the Village Board to
attend the meeting electronically shall be deemed approved by the Village
Board.
D.   If the trustee who is attending electronically would normally chair the
meeting, a president pro tempore who is physically present may be appointed.
E.   No more than two (2) trustees may attend a regular or special meeting by
electronic means for any one meeting. Participation through electronic means
shall be recognized in the order the request to the village clerk is received.
Participation by a trustee by electronic means shall include any closed
sessions called during that meeting.
F.   A quorum of the board of trustees must be physically present for any
public meeting.
G.   This section shall apply in like manner to any subsidiary committee,
subcommittee or other agency of the Village that is a "public body" under the
Illinois Open Meetings Act. (Ord. 1351, 9-25-2019)
CHAPTER 7
VILLAGE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES; APPOINTED MEMBERS OF BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
SECTION:
1-7-1: Applicability Of Provisions
1-7-2: Residency Requirements
1-7-3: Date Of Expiration Of Office; Term Of Office
1-7-4: Oath And Bond
1-7-5: Restrictions On Elected And Appointed Officials
1-7-6: Duties
1-7-7: Inspection Of Records
1-7-8: Indemnification Of Officers And Employees
1-7-9: Conflict Of Interest
1-7-10: Removal From Office
1-7-11: Vacations
1-7-12 Paid Leave Required For Eligible Village Employees
1-7-13:    Village Exemption From The Requirements Of The Paid Leave For All
Workers Act
1-7-14 - 1-7-49: Reserved
1-7-50:    Authorization To Employ Village Administrator; Appointment
1-7-51:    Village Administrator; Bond
1-7-52:    Village Administrator; Compensation
1-7-53:    Powers And Duties Of Village Administrator
1-7-54:    Removal Of Village Administrator
1-7-1: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all officers, elected officials,
appointed members of the boards and commissions and employees generally,
regardless of the time of the creation of the office or position, at the time
of the appointment of the officer or employee. All employees of the Village are
employed "at-will", and no officer, elected official, appointed member, and/or
employee shall have a claim to a guarantee of any particular benefits,
procedures, terms or conditions, except as required by law, and only the Board
of Trustees may alter an existing "at-will" employment relationship by
enactment of a written agreement. (Ord. 1346, 6-26-2019)
1-7-2: RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS:
All elected Village officials and all members of the Plan Commission 1  and
Zoning Board of Appeals 2  shall be qualified electors living in the Village,
except to the extent that nonresidency is permitted for members of the Plan
Commission by the Illinois Municipal Code 3 . All elected officials, or persons
appointed to an elective Village office, shall be qualified electors and shall
have resided in the Village at least one year next preceding their election or
appointment. Any such elected official or member of the Plan Commission (other
than a member living outside of the Village at the time of his appointment) or
Zoning Board of Appeals who does not regularly reside in the Village for a
period of one hundred thirty five (135) days, shall forfeit the office in
question upon the passage of a resolution by the Corporate Authorities;
provided however, that the Corporate Authorities may, in their discretion,
waive the requirement of forfeiture for good cause shown, such as, but not
limited to, temporary absence from the Village due to fire or other destruction
or substantial damage to the regular dwelling place of the individual within
the Village. (1977 Code §
2-1-8; amd. 2004 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 1 of this Code.
2 2. See title 2, chapter 2 of this Code.
3 3. 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4.
1-7-3: DATE OF EXPIRATION OF OFFICE; TERM OF OFFICE:
Unless otherwise specified, all appointed officers, whether appointed for one
year or more, shall serve for terms expiring on June 30, or until their
respective successors are appointed and qualify. Unless otherwise specified or
required by law, all appointed officials shall serve a term of one year or, in
the case of a mid-term vacancy, the duration of the original one year term.
(Ord. 1330, 7-25-2018)
1-7-4: OATH AND BOND:
   A.   Oath Required: Every officer of the Village shall, before entering upon
his duties, take the oath prescribed by statute. (1977 Code §
2-1-3)
   B.   Bond: Every officer and employee shall, if required by the Corporate
Authorities or State Statute, prior to entering upon the duties of his office,
give a bond in such amount and with such sureties as may be determined by the
Corporate Authorities, such sureties to be rated AA-1, conditioned upon the
faithful performance of the duties of his office or position, to be approved by
the Corporate Authorities. (1977 Code §
2-1-5; amd. 2004 Code)
1-7-5: RESTRICTIONS ON ELECTED AND APPOINTED OFFICIALS:
Unless specifically waived by resolution of the Village Board:
   A.   No elected official shall serve as a member of the Zoning Board of
Appeals or Plan Commission of the Village.
   B.   No official elected to a Village office or to any other elective office
shall serve as an appointed official of the Village.
   C.   No appointed Village official shall serve as an appointed or elected
official of the Village in any capacity other than in the position to which
such person was appointed. (1977 Code §
2-1-9)
1-7-6: DUTIES:
   A.   Monies To Treasurer: Every officer of the Village shall turn over all
monies received by him in his official capacity to the Treasurer with a
statement showing the source from which the same was received. (1977 Code §
2-1-2)
   B.   Property To Successor: Every officer and employee of the Village, upon
the expiration of his term for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his
successor all books and records which may be the property of the Village, but
if there is no successor, to the Village Clerk. (1977 Code §
2-1-6)
1-7-7: INSPECTION OF RECORDS:
All records kept by any officer of the Village shall be open to inspection by
the president or, upon vote of the corporate authorities, by any member of the
Board of Trustees at all reasonable times, whether or not such records are
required to be kept by statute or ordinance. (1977 Code §
2-1-4; amd. 2004 Code)
1-7-8: INDEMNIFICATION OF OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
   A.   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following words
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
    EMPLOYEE: Includes all employees of the Village.
   OFFICER: Includes any elected or appointed official of the Village. (1977
Code § 1-1-14)
   B.   Indemnification Responsibilities Of Village: If any claim or action is
instituted against any present officer or employee or former officer or
employee of the Village based on an injury or event allegedly arising out of an
act or omission occurring within the scope of his employment or official duties
as such employee or officer, the Village shall, to the extent permitted by law:
(1977 Code § 1-1-14; amd. 2004 Code)
      1.   Appear and defend against the claim or action; and
      2.   Indemnify the officer or employee or former officer or employee for
his attorney fees and court costs incurred in the defense of such claim or
action; and
      3.   Indemnify the officer or employee or former officer or employee for
any judgment based on such claim or action; or
      4.   Indemnify the officer or employee or former officer or employee for
any compromise or settlement of such a claim or action if approved in advance
by the Village.
Provided, however, that the Village shall not indemnify any officer or employee
for any portion of a judgment representing an award of punitive or plenary
damages.
   C.   Interpretation And Application Of Provisions:
      1.   Nothing in this section shall be construed as waiving any defense of
the Village or its employees or officers, including, but not limited to, any
defense provided by the Illinois local governmental and governmental employees
tort immunity act 1  as it may exist from time to time, in any action brought
against the Village or such officer or employee.
      2.   The provisions of this section shall apply only where the Village
has been given notice of any actions brought against any Village employee or
officer, based upon any action of such employee or officer within the scope of
his authority as such. Any Village officer or employee against whom a claim or
action is instituted shall notify the Village of such claim in writing within
thirty (30) days of service of process upon said officer or employee. (1977
Code § 1-1-14)
 
Notes
1 1. 745 ILCS 10/1-101 et seq.
1-7-9: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
   A.   Conflict Of Interest: It is in the interest of the Village and its
citizens that all officers of the Village avoid any conflicts of interest and
also avoid the appearance of conflict of interest or other improprieties. (1977
Code § 2-1-11)
   B.   Statute Provisions:
      1.   65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-55-10 provides, in applicable
part:
(a) A municipal officer shall not be interested, directly or indirectly, in his
own name or in the name of any other person, association, trust or corporation,
in any contract, work or business of the municipality, or in the sale of any
article whenever the expense, price or consideration of the contract, work,
business or sale is paid either from the treasury or by any assessment levied
by any statute or ordinance. A municipal officer shall not be interested,
directly or indirectly in the purchase of any property which: i) belongs to the
municipality, or ii) is sold for taxes or assessments, or iii) is sold by
virtue of legal process at the suit of the municipality. (Then follow certain
exceptions).
      2.   50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 105/3 also contains prohibitions
against persons holding any office under the laws or constitution of the state
being interested, directly or indirectly, in contracts and the performance of
certain work.
      3.   All present elected and appointed officials of the Village shall be
provided with a copy of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-55-10 and of 50
Illinois Compiled Statutes 105/3, by the Village Clerk, and all newly elected
or appointed officials shall be provided with such copy within thirty (30) days
after their election or appointment.
   C.   Nepotism Deemed Conflict Of Interest: It shall be considered improper
and a conflict of interest by the Village if there is employed by the Village,
directly or indirectly, a relative of any elected or appointed Village officer
having the following relationship: spouse, descendent, brother or sister, aunt
or uncle, niece or nephew, or cousin. This subsection shall not apply to any
contract entered into as a result of the request by the Village for competitive
bids where the person or entity awarded this contract is the lowest responsible
bidder. (1977 Code § 2-1-11; amd. 2004 Code)
1-7-10: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
Any member of the Zoning Board of Appeals, Plan Commission or other commission
of the Village, without excuse deemed adequate to the Board of Trustees, may be
removed from office and such office declared vacant if such person fails to
attend three (3) consecutive meetings, or more than a total of five (5) in a
twelve (12) month period, of the board or commission of which such person is a
member, upon resolution approved by the Board of Trustees. (1977 Code § 2-1-10;
amd. 2004 Code)
1-7-11: VACATIONS:
A.   Vacation Eligibility. Full-time employees, defined as those who work an
average of thirty-seven and a half (37.5) hours per week or more, are eligible
to receive paid vacation based on the year of service with the Village. The
number of vacation days for which each employee is eligible shall be based on a
calendar year (January 1 - December 31) and accrues for each full month of
employment, according to the schedule set forth below.
 
Year of Service    Hours Per Work Week Accrued Hours Per Annual Vacation Days
                                       Month             Per Year
Date of Hire -     37.5                3.125             5
December 31st
2nd - 5th Years    37.5                6.250             10
6th - 15th Years   37.5                9.375             15
16th or More Years 37.5                12.50             20
 
B.   Vacation Benefit. The first year of employment for all eligible employees
shall begin with the date of hire and shall end on December 31st of that year.
At the beginning of each calendar year thereafter, eligible employees will be
allotted vacation hours equal to the amount the employee will accrue in that
calendar year. An employee who leaves the employment of the Village in the
first six months will forfeit all vacation accrued.
C.   No Carryover of Vacation Days. Vacation time may not be carried over from
one calendar year to the next and must be used in the calendar year in which it
is earned, unless otherwise approved by the Board.
D.   Requests for Vacations. Prior to taking accrued vacation time, employees
must request approval from the Village Administrator. The Village President
will review requests in the absence of a Village Administrator, or Village
Administrator vacation requests. All vacation requests will be reviewed based
on several factors, including business needs and staffing requirements.
Vacation time may be taken in increments of not less than 4 hours at a time.
E.   Part Time and Temporary Employees. Employees who work an average of less
than thirty-seven and a half (37.5) hours per week, and temporary employees
shall not be entitled to vacations or vacation pay.
F.   Vacation at Separation. Employees who end their employment with accrued,
but unused vacation hours will be paid for those hours. If an employee leaves
the employment of the Village having taken vacation time in excess of hours
accrued, the employee is responsible for reimbursing the Village for the
unaccrued vacation hours taken. The Village can deduct these unaccrued vacation
hours from the employee's final paycheck. (Ord. 1358, 12-18-2019)
1-7-12: PAID LEAVE REQUIRED FOR ELIGIBLE VILLAGE EMPLOYEES:
The Village of North Barrington shall provide eligible employees of the Village
with paid leave as provided for in the Village's Code of Ordinances, Employee
Handbook, Annual Salary Ordinances, any collective bargaining agreements to
which the Village is a party and all other binding legislative actions
governing paid leave adopted by the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village, as the same may be amended from time to time. However, in no event
shall the Village, as an employer, provide less than one (1) day of paid leave
(or prorated equivalent) per year to any eligible Village employee. (Ord. 2023-
10, 12-20-2023)
1-7-13: VILLAGE EXEMPTION FROM THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE PAID LEAVE FOR ALL
WORKERS ACT:
The Village, as an employer, shall have no additional obligations with regard
to mandatory paid leave, including, without limitation, any obligations
provided under the Paid Leave of All Workers Act (820 ILCS 192/1 et seq.),
except those obligations required by Federal and/or state law which validly
preempt the Village's authority. (Ord. 2023-10, 12-20-2023)
1–7-14 - 1-7-49: RESERVED:
1-7-50: AUTHORIZATION TO EMPLOY VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR; APPOINTMENT:
The Village President and Board of Trustees are hereby authorized to employ a
Village Administrator. Such Administrator shall be appointed by the Village
President, by and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The
Village Administrator shall also serve as the Budget Officer for the Village,
subject to appointment by the Village President and with the advice and consent
of the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 1355, 11-20-2019; amd. Ord. 2020-03, 4-15-2020)
1-7-51: VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR; BOND:
The Village Administrator shall furnish a bond in such amount and with such
surety as may be approved by the corporate authorities, such bond to be
conditioned upon the faithful performance of his or her duties. The cost of the
bond shall be paid by the Village. The bond of the Village Administrator may be
part of a blanket bond. (Ord. 1355, 11-20-2019)
1-7-52: VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR; COMPENSATION:
The Village Administrator shall receive such compensation as the Corporate
Authorities shall, from time to time, establish.
(Ord. 1355, 11-20-2019)
1-7-53: POWERS AND DUTIES OF VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR:
The Village Administrator shall have the following powers and duties:
(A)   Provide for the enforcement of all laws and ordinances within the
Village.
(B)   Attend all regular meetings of the Village Board of Trustees, as well as
Committee and Commission meetings, unless excused by the Village President, and
prepare and coordinate their agendas and meeting schedules.
(C)   Develop policies and procedures necessary for the operation of the
Village and present them to the Village President and Board of Trustees for
approval.
   Provide the Board of Trustees with adequate information to help it reach
sound decisions and establish policies.
(D)   Direct, supervise and coordinate the activities of all departments,
offices, and agencies of the Village, except as otherwise provided by law, and
to administer the affairs of the Village to ensure that all Village business is
accomplished efficiently and economically.
(E)   Evaluate all employees and conduct performance reviews with the Village
President, and responsibility for all personnel matters and employee benefits,
including recommendations for hiring, promotions, demotions, discipline, and
suspensions of all employees pursuant to the personnel policy.
(F)   Sign on behalf of the Village any contract authorized by Board of
Trustees, except where the Board of Trustees or state statutes direct that some
other officer shall do so. It shall be the duty of the Village Administrator to
ensure that all franchises granted by, and all contracts with, the Village are
faithfully kept and performed; by all parties hereto.
(G)   Preparation of the annual budget in conjunction with the Finance
Committee and submit to Village Board of Trustees for approval, and
responsibility for compliance with all statutes and ordinances pertaining to
finances, appropriations, and levies. Keep the Village Board advised of the
financial condition and future needs of the Village and make such
recommendations as he/she shall deem advisable.
(H)   Establish and coordinate a system of purchasing, to include Requests for
Proposals, within the approved budgets, policies and procedures established by
the Village Board of Trustees and approve emergency purchases not to exceed
$10,000.
(I)   Keep a current inventory of all real and personal property of the
Village.
(J)   Participate with Village Board of Trustees in the development and
establishment of short- and long-range goals and objectives.
(K)   Represent the Village in its dealings with other governmental agencies
and officials, businesses, not-for-profit organizations, residents, and the
general public as necessary.
(L)   Oversee the preparation of grant and/or loan applications on behalf of
the Village and administer such grant and/or loan funds that may be required.
(M)   The Village Administrator shall perform such other duties as may be
required by the Board of Trustees consistent with state statutes and the
ordinances of the Village.
(N)   Hold such other appointive offices as may be consistent with law,
including but not limited to the position of FOIA Officer, as the Village
President and Board of Trustees may determine, and to faithfully and honestly
discharge the duties and powers associated with such offices. (Ord. 1355, 11-
20-2019)
1-7-54: REMOVAL OF VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR:
The Village Administrator may be removed at the direction and decision of the
Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees at any
time, in accordance with the law. (Ord. 1355, 11-20-2019)
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE CLERK
SECTION:
1-7A-1: Residency Requirements
1-7A-2: Appointment And Term Of Office
1-7A-3: Powers And Duties
1-7A-4: Deputy Village Clerk
1-7A-5: Compensation
1-7A-1: RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS:
As provided by the Illinois municipal code, the Village Clerk is not required
to be a resident of the Village. (Ord. 1196, 12-20-2010)
1-7A-2: APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE:
The Village Clerk is appointed by the Village President with the concurrence of
the Village Board. The Deputy Village Clerk is appointed by the Village Clerk
subject to the concurrence of the Village President and Board of Trustees. The
terms of office for the Village Clerk and Deputy Village Clerk shall be one
year (coinciding with the fiscal year) beginning on May 1 of every year and
ending on the following April 30; except, that in the case of appointment after
May 1, the term shall be for a partial year ending on May 1 following the date
of appointment. (Ord. 836, 2-28-2000)
1-7A-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Attend Meetings: The Village Clerk shall attend meetings of the Board
of Trustees and be responsible for the keeping of a full record of their
proceedings (minutes) and the accuracy of the record. The Village Clerk may be
asked to attend other governmental meetings as deemed appropriate by the
Village President. (Ord. 836, 2-28-2000)
   B.   Record Of Proceedings:
      1.   The Village Clerk shall attend all meetings of the corporate
authorities and prepare the draft record of the proceedings (minutes).
      2.   The minutes of each meeting of the corporate authorities shall be
arranged as near as may be appropriate in chronological sequence.
      3.   The minutes shall contain:
         a.   An accurate record of the transaction of public business and
official actions, including all motions, decisions or other actions of the
corporate authorities.
         b.   A summary of reports of committees, commissions or Village
officers as presented at the meeting.
         c.   Informational data needed or desirable to understand the actions
of the corporate authorities.
         d.   A reasonable summarization of comments from the audience.
         e.   A reasonable summarization of any member of the corporate
authorities, and of any other reports, data or memoranda presented to the
meeting, at the specific request of the corporate authorities.
      4.   At the direction of the corporate authorities, the proceedings shall
be recorded by tape recorder or other appropriate means. Any person is
permitted to tape record or videotape any meeting open to the public pursuant
to state law.
      5.   Subject to the matters otherwise provided in this article, the role
of the Village Clerk in preparation of minutes is to record the proceedings of
the Board and to prepare draft and final minutes.
      6.   The draft minutes will be presented for approval at the next meeting
of the corporate authorities, where possible. The Village President and
Attorney may present to the corporate authorities suggested corrections and/or
clarification of the draft minutes, and the same shall be incorporated in the
minutes without a specific motion being required. Any Trustee desiring to
correct or clarify the draft minutes (including correction and/or clarification
of matters suggested by the Village Attorney) shall make a motion stating the
matters to be corrected or clarified, and such motion will be voted upon if
seconded. The minutes, as presented, or as corrected and clarified, will be
subject to approval by motion approved by a majority of the Trustees present.
      7.   After the corporate authorities have approved the minutes, they may
be signed by both the Village Clerk and President; however, failure of either
or both to sign the minutes will not affect the validity of such minutes once
approved, and the corporate authorities may designate one of their members to
sign any particular minutes if both the President and Clerk fail to do so.
      8.   The minutes shall be made available for public inspection within
seven (7) days after being approved or accepted by the corporate authorities as
the official minutes of their proceedings. (Ord. 836, 2-28-2000; amd. 2004
Code)
   C.   Records Required: In addition to the record of ordinances, resolutions
and other records which the Village Clerk is required by statute to keep, the
Village Clerk shall keep a register of all licenses and permits issued and the
payment thereon, and such other records as may be required by the Board of
Trustees.
   D.   Special Projects: The Village Clerk may be asked to work on special
projects for the Village President as needed.
   E.   Authenticate Documents: The Village Clerk shall sign and authenticate
documents in accordance with state law.
   F.   Custodian: The Village Clerk shall be the custodian of all documents
belonging to the Village which are not assigned to the custody of some other
officer. (Ord. 836, 2-28-2000)
   G.   Publication Of Ordinances: The Village Clerk shall publish all
ordinances passed by the corporate authorities imposing any fine, penalty,
imprisonment or forfeiture, or making any appropriation, in pamphlet form,
whether or not each such ordinance contains language authorizing such
publication in pamphlet form.
   H.   Additional Duties: In addition to the duties herein provided, the
Village Clerk shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required
by statute or ordinance or as otherwise specified by the Village President and
Board of Trustees. The duties of the Village Clerk shall include general office
coordination such as:
      1.   Sign, seal and attest all contracts of the Village and all licenses,
permits and such other documents as shall require this formality.
      2.   Publication of ordinances passed by the corporate authorities
requiring publication.
      3.   Assist Village residents as needed.
      4.   Handle incoming calls and general office duties.
      5.   Assist Administrative Assistant, as necessary.
      6.   With the Administrative Assistant, prepare and distribute agenda
packets for Board meetings.
      7.   Prepare various resolutions and ordinances.
      8.   Help maintain and update Village mailing list on the computer.
      9.   Help maintain and update building records on the computer.
      10.   Prepare agenda packets and distribute same for Plan Commission,
Zoning Board of Appeals and Environmental and Health Commission, as well as
other commissions as mutually agreed.
      11.   Serve as secretary (with additional compensation) for Plan
Commission, Zoning Board of Appeals and Environmental and Health Commission, as
well as other commissions as mutually agreed.
      12.   Make arrangements for all meetings and hearings, including
notification to media and posting and publication of notices.
      13.   Prepare election materials for municipal elections.
      14.   Take over duties to maintain daily functions and needs of the
Village office when the Administrative Assistant is not available due to
vacation, illness, etc. (Ord. 836, 2-28-2000; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. 1040, 6-28-
2004; Ord. 1129, 12-17-2007)
1-7A-4: DEPUTY VILLAGE CLERK:
   A.   Duties And Responsibilities: In the absence of the Village Clerk, the
Deputy Village Clerk shall attend meetings of the corporate authorities and
prepare the draft record of the proceedings, and perform any and all duties and
responsibilities of the Village Clerk as requested and specified by the Village
President and Board of Trustees. (2004 Code)
   B.   Sealing And Attesting Documents: If the Village Clerk is absent from
the office, the Deputy Village Clerk shall sign, seal and attest all contracts
of the Village and all licenses, permits and such other documents as shall
require this formality.
   C.   Publication Of Ordinances: If the Village Clerk is absent from the
office, the Deputy Village Clerk shall and is hereby authorized to publish all
ordinances hereafter passed by the corporate authorities requiring publication.
   D.   Additional Duties: In addition to the duties herein provided, the
Deputy Village Clerk shall perform such other duties and functions as may be
required by statute or ordinance or as otherwise specified by the Village
President and Board of Trustees. The duties of the Deputy Village Clerk shall
include general office coordination such as:
      1.   Assist Village residents as needed.
      2.   Handle incoming calls and general office duties.
      3.   Assist Administrative Assistant, as necessary.
      4.   With the Administrative Assistant, prepare and distribute agenda
packets for Board meetings.
      5.   Process vehicle sticker applications.
      6.   Prepare agenda packets and distribute same for Plan Commission,
Zoning Board of Appeals, Environmental and Health Commission, as well as other
commissions as mutually agreed.
      7.   Serve as secretary (with additional compensation) for Plan
Commission, Zoning Board of Appeals and Environmental and Health Commission, as
well as other commissions as mutually agreed.
      8.   Take over duties to maintain daily functions and needs of the
Village office when the Administrative Assistant is not available due to
vacation, illness, etc. (Ord. 836, 2-28-2000; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. 1040, 6-28-
2004; Ord. 1129, 12-17-2007)
1-7A-5: COMPENSATION:
   A.   Village Clerk: The Village Clerk shall receive such compensation as
determined by the President and Board of Trustees.
   B.   Deputy Village Clerk: The Deputy Village Clerk shall receive such
compensation as determined by the President and Board of Trustees as
commensurate with duties and responsibilities. (Ord. 836, 2-28-2000)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE TREASURER
SECTION:
1-7B-1: Office Established; Appointment; Term
1-7B-2: Bond
1-7B-3: Powers And Duties
1-7B-4: Warrants And Checks
1-7B-5: Compensation
1-7B-1: OFFICE ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
There is established the Office of Village Treasurer, an administrative office
of the Village. The Village Treasurer shall be appointed by the President with
the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The Village Treasurer shall
hold office for a term of one year, reviewed and subject to reappointment
annually, and until a successor has been appointed and qualified. (Ord. 1330,
7-25-2018)
1-7B-2: BOND:
The Village Treasurer shall give a surety bond, before entering upon the duties
of his office, in the sum required by the Board of Trustees, but such amount
shall not be less than that required by State Statute. This bond shall be
conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties as the Treasurer and
shall be conditioned to indemnify the Village for any loss by reason of any
neglect of duty or any improper act of the Treasurer. (1977 Code § 2-5-5; amd.
2004 Code)
1-7B-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Generally: The Village Treasurer shall perform such lawful powers and
duties as may be prescribed for him by statute or ordinance or otherwise by the
Corporate Authorities, as well as provided in this article. He shall pay out
money only on vouchers, bills or orders properly approved by the Village Board
or approved by another Village official within the authority of such official.
(1977 Code §
2-5-3; amd. Ord. 911, 12-16-2002; 2004 Code)
   B.   Custody Of Funds: The Village Treasurer shall deposit the Village funds
in such depositories as may be selected by the Corporate Authorities from time
to time as provided by law, and he shall keep the deposit of the Village funds
separate and distinct from his own funds, and shall not make private or
personal use of any Village funds. (1977 Code § 2-5-4; amd. 2004 Code)
   C.   Monthly Reports: The Village Treasurer shall render an account under
oath to the Board of Trustees on a monthly basis. (1977 Code § 2-5-6; amd. 2004
Code)
1-7B-4: WARRANTS AND CHECKS:
   A.   Warrants:
      1.   Definition: "Warrants" are authorizations to the Village Treasurer
to disburse Village funds.
      2.   Signatures Required; Contents: No funds shall be disbursed unless
the Treasurer first receives a warrant signed by the Village President and
countersigned by the Village Clerk, except petty cash as authorized by the
Board of Trustees. Each warrant shall state the particular fund or
appropriation to which the same is chargeable, and the person to whom payable.
(1977 Code § 2-5-7)
   B.   Checks:
      1.   The Treasurer is authorized to issue checks up to one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) with the Treasurer's signature only.
      2.   Checks covering expenditures over one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
will require the signatures of the Treasurer and any one of the Village
President, Village Clerk, or Village Trustee appointed by the Village
President.
      3.   The Village President has authority to direct the issuance of checks
up to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for purchases and/or cash.
(Ord. 1057, 5-23-2005)
1-7B-5: COMPENSATION:
The Village Treasurer shall receive such compensation as may be fixed by the
President and Board of Trustees. (1977 Code § 2-5-8; amd. 2004 Code)
ARTICLE C. VILLAGE COLLECTOR
SECTION:
1-7C-1: Office Established; Appointment; Term
1-7C-2: Bond
1-7C-3: Duties
1-7C-4: Compensation
1-7C-1: OFFICE ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
There is established the office of Village Collector, an administrative office
of the Village. The Village Collector shall be appointed by the President with
the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees and shall hold office for a
term of one year and until a successor has been appointed and qualified. (1977
Code §§ 2-5A-1, 2-5A-2; amd. 2004 Code)
1-7C-2: BOND:
The Village Collector shall give a five thousand dollar ($5,000.00) surety bond
before entering upon the duties of the office, or such greater amount as
required by the Board of Trustees or by state statute. This bond shall be
conditioned upon the faithful performance of the Collector's duties as the
collector, and shall be conditioned to indemnify the Village for any loss by
reason of any neglect of duty or any act of the Collector. (1977 Code § 2-5A-4;
amd. 2004 Code)
1-7C-3: DUTIES:
The Village Collector shall perform such lawful duties as may be prescribed by
state statute or ordinance or otherwise by the Board of Trustees. The collector
shall receive all funds due to or delivered to the Village and shall promptly
deliver the same to the Village Treasurer. (1977 Code § 2-5A-3)
1-7C-4: COMPENSATION:
The Village Collector shall receive such compensation, if any, as may be fixed
by the President and Board of Trustees. (1977 Code § 2-5A-5; amd. 2004 Code)
ARTICLE D. VILLAGE ATTORNEY AND VILLAGE PROSECUTOR
SECTION:
1-7D-1: Position Established; Appointment
1-7D-2: Term And Termination Of Position
1-7D-3: Duties
1-7D-4: Compensation
1-7D-5: Village Prosecutor
1-7D-6: Contract For Special Projects
1-7D-1: POSITION ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT:
There is established the position of Village Attorney, which shall consist of
an attorney or firm of attorneys duly licensed by the state, appointed by the
Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. (Ord.
894, 7-22-2002)
1-7D-2: TERM AND TERMINATION OF POSITION:
The term of office of the Village Attorney shall be July 1 to June 30, reviewed
and subject to reappointment annually. The attorney, or firm, or corporate
authorities may terminate such appointment with thirty (30) days' written
notice. (Ord. 894, 7-22-2002)
1-7D-3: DUTIES:
   A.   Legal Advisor: The Village Attorney shall advise and represent the
Village President and Board of Trustees and other Village officials on all
matters referred to such attorney and shall perform such duties as are provided
by law or ordinance and, in addition thereto, such other duties as from time to
time may be requested by the Village President or the corporate authorities.
   B.   Reports Required: The Village Attorney shall submit project reports on
a regular basis, and shall make such suggestions to the President or corporate
authorities regarding those matters in the areas of responsibility of the
Village Attorney based upon such Village Attorney's best judgment, and in the
best interests of the Village and its residents. (Ord. 894, 7-22-2002)
1-7D-4: COMPENSATION:
The Village Attorney shall receive compensation for hours worked pursuant to a
fixed schedule approved from time to time by the corporate authorities. (Ord.
894, 7-22-2002)
1-7D-5: VILLAGE PROSECUTOR:
The Village Attorney, with the consent of the Village President and Board, may
recommend a Village Prosecutor to assist in prosecutions for Village code and
other alleged violations. If the corporate authorities appoint a Village
Prosecutor in accordance herewith, the duties of such Village Prosecutor shall
be performed under the supervision of the Village Attorney. (Ord. 894, 7-22-
2002)
1-7D-6: CONTRACT FOR SPECIAL PROJECTS:
Nothing in this article or this code shall prohibit the Village from entering
into a contract with any municipal attorney for special projects and legal
work. (Ord. 894, 7-22-2002)
ARTICLE E. BUILDING AND ZONING OFFICER
SECTION:
1-7E-1: Office Established; Appointment And Term; Termination Of Office
1-7E-2: Powers And Duties
1-7E-3: Deputy Building Officer And Inspector
1-7E-4: Compensation
1-7E-1: OFFICE ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT AND TERM; TERMINATION OF OFFICE:
There is established the office of Building and Zoning Officer, an
administrative office of the Village. The Building and Zoning Officer shall be
appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. The term of office of the Building and Zoning Officer shall be July 1
to June 30, reviewed and subject to reappointment annually. The Building and
Zoning Officer or corporate authorities may terminate such appointment with
thirty (30) days' written notice. (1977 Code § 2-9-1; amd. Ord. 813, 8-23-1999;
2004 Code)
1-7E-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Generally: The Building and Zoning Officer shall enforce all ordinances
and provisions of this code pertaining to building and zoning in the Village,
including issuance of building permits and inspections of construction as
required. (1977 Code § 2-9-3)
   B.   Reports Required: The Building and Zoning Officer shall inquire into
and report upon any matter pertaining to building and zoning as may be required
by the President and Board of Trustees. (1977 Code § 2-9-4)
1-7E-3: DEPUTY BUILDING OFFICER AND INSPECTOR:
There is hereby created the office of Deputy Building Officer and Inspector, an
administrative office of the Village. The Deputy Building Officer and Inspector
shall be appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. The Deputy Building Officer and Inspector shall have the same term of
office and, subject to the direction of the Building and Zoning Officer, the
same powers and duties as are assigned to the Building and Zoning Officer.
(1977 Code § 2-9-5; amd. 2004 Code)
1-7E-4: COMPENSATION:
The Building and Zoning Officer and Deputy Building Officer and Inspector shall
receive such compensation, if any, as may be fixed by the President and Board
of Trustees. (1977 Code § 2-9-6; amd. 2004 Code)
ARTICLE F. FORESTER
SECTION:
1-7F-1: Office Established; Appointment; Term
1-7F-2: Powers And Duties
1-7F-3: Compensation
1-7F-1: OFFICE ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
There is established the Office of Village Forester, an administrative office
of the Village. The Village Forester shall be appointed by the President with
the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The Village Forester shall
hold office for a term of one year, reviewed and subject to reappointment
annually, and until a successor has been appointed and qualified. (Ord. 1330,
7-25-2018)
1-7F-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Generally: The Forester shall enforce all ordinances and provisions of
this Code pertaining to the control of Dutch elm and oak wilt disease, and any
other provisions of ordinances or this Code pertaining to weeds and trees.
(1977 Code § 2-10-3)
   B.   Reports Required: The Forester shall inquire into and report upon any
matter pertaining to trees as may be required by the Environmental and Health
Commission and/or by the President and Board of Trustees. (1977 Code § 2-10-4;
amd. 2004 Code; Ord. 1040, 6-28-2004; Ord. 1129, 12-17-2007)
1-7F-3: COMPENSATION:
The Forester shall receive such compensation, if any, as may be fixed by the
President and Board of Trustees. (1977 Code § 2-10-5; amd. 2004 Code)
ARTICLE G. HEALTH OFFICER
SECTION:
1-7G-1: Office Established; Appointment And Term; Termination Of Office
1-7G-2: Powers And Duties
1-7G-3: Deputy Health Officer
1-7G-4: Compensation
1-7G-1: OFFICE ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT AND TERM; TERMINATION OF OFFICE:
There is established the office of Village Health Officer, an administrative
office of the Village. The Health Officer shall be appointed by the President
with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The term of office of the
Village Health Officer shall be July 1 to June 30, reviewed and subject to
reappointment annually. The Health Officer or corporate authorities may
terminate such appointment with thirty (30) days' written notice. (1977 Code §
2-11-1; amd. Ord. 813, 8-23-1999; 2004 Code)
1-7G-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Generally: The Health Officer shall enforce all ordinances and
provisions of this code containing provisions for the protection of public
health and is hereby authorized and empowered to inspect all buildings, lands,
and places as to their conditions affecting health and sanitation, and whenever
any public nuisance, source of filth or condition prejudicial to the public
health is found to exist, the Health Officer shall have the power and authority
to order the owner or occupant thereof to make such alterations or changes
necessary to correct and remove said nuisance, source of filth or condition
prejudicial to the public health. (1977 Code § 2-11-3)
   B.   Reports Required: The Health Officer shall inquire into and report upon
any matter pertaining to health and sanitation as may be required by the
Environmental and Health Commission and/or the President and Board of Trustees.
(1977 Code § 2-11-4; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. 1040, 6-28-2004; Ord. 1129, 12-17-
2007)
1-7G-3: DEPUTY HEALTH OFFICER:
There is established the office of Deputy Health Officer, an administrative
office of the Village. The Deputy Health Officer shall be appointed by the
President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The Deputy
Health Officer shall have the same term of office and, subject to the direction
of the Health Officer, the same powers and duties as are assigned to the Health
Officer. (1977 Code § 2-11-5; amd. 2004 Code)
1-7G-4: COMPENSATION:
The Health Officer and Deputy Health Officer shall receive such compensation,
if any, as may be fixed by the President and Board of Trustees. (1977 Code § 2-
11-6; amd. 2004 Code)
ARTICLE H. SUPERVISION OF ROADS
SECTION:
1-7H-1: Village Board Member Responsible For Roads
1-7H-2: Powers And Duties
1-7H-3: Delegation Of Responsibilities
1-7H-1: VILLAGE BOARD MEMBER RESPONSIBLE FOR ROADS:
Effective June 1 of each year, the Village President shall appoint a member of
the Corporate Authorities (himself or a Village Trustee) as the Board Member
Responsible for Roads. (Ord. 1245, 11-20-2013)
1-7H-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Road And Culvert Maintenance: The Board Member Responsible for Roads
shall have charge of carrying out the program of planned maintenance of all
public streets, roads, bridges, culverts and other structures and appurtenances
thereto in the village and regular cleaning, maintenance and inspections of
road conditions and drainage structures. Such Board Member shall develop a
program whereby all culverts within the rights of way of any roads and streets,
or which are appurtenant to drainage for roads or streets, are inspected, and
to the extent necessary, repaired and replaced, on a semiannual basis, to
assure that each culvert in the village is clear of debris or other blockage
and in such state of maintenance and repair as to ensure its functionality;
provided however that nothing in this article shall release any property owner
of such owner's obligations to inspect and clear any culvert on such owner's
property.
   B.   Signs: The Board Member Responsible for Roads shall have charge of
installing road signs required for traffic and/or other reasons and regular
inspections of such signs.
   C.   Activities In Public Ways: The Board Member Responsible for Roads shall
be responsible for the following activities within the rights of way of village
streets:
      1.   Tree and brush removal or trimming and grass cutting.
      2.   Placement of emergency storm and stormwater traffic barricades.
      3.   Street sweeping.
      4.   Removal of dead or injured animals.
      5.   Construction traffic routing and weight limitations.
   D.   Enforcement Duties:
      1.   The Board Member Responsible for Roads shall enforce all ordinances
and provisions of this code relating to public utility service facilities.
      2.   Such Board Member shall enforce all ordinances and provisions of
this code relating to roads, driveways, culverts, culvert installation, and
other such ordinances and provisions of this code relating to roads and public
rights of way. (Ord. 1245, 11-20-2013)
1-7H-3: DELEGATION OF RESPONSIBILITIES:
The Board Member Responsible for Roads is authorized to delegate the
responsibilities defined in this article to the person, firm, entity or agency
employed by the village from time to time to perform such responsibilities.
(Ord. 1245, 11-20-2013)
ARTICLE I. CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER
SECTION:
1-7I-1: Office Established; Appointment; Term And Termination Of Office
1-7I-2: Powers And Duties
1-7I-3: Compensation
1-7I-1: OFFICE ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT; TERM AND TERMINATION OF OFFICE:
There is established the office of Code Enforcement Officer, an administrative
office of the Village. The Code Enforcement Officer shall be appointed by the
President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The term of
office of the Code Enforcement Officer shall be July 1 to June 30, reviewed and
subject to reappointment annually. The Code Enforcement Officer or corporate
authorities may terminate such appointment with thirty (30) days' written
notice. (1977 Code §§ 2-15-1, 2-15-2; amd. 2004 Code)
1-7I-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Generally: The Code Enforcement Officer shall have authority to enforce
all provisions of this code pertaining to on view violations other than
violations of the provisions of title 3, title 6 and title 7 of this code;
provided, however, the Code Enforcement Officer shall have authority to enforce
any provisions of this code if authorized to do so by the Village President,
including, but not limited to, those excluded provisions set forth above. The
Code Enforcement Officer shall likewise have authority to advise persons of
such existing on view violations and send out notices requesting abatement of
such violations and shall furthermore have authority to initiate legal action
by the issuance of a citation and notice to appear where, in his opinion, it is
necessary to do so. (1977 Code § 2-15-3)
   B.   Reports Required: The Code Enforcement Officer shall inquire into and
report upon any matter pertaining to violations of this code as may be
requested by the President and Board of Trustees. (1977 Code § 2-15-4)
1-7I-3: COMPENSATION:
The Code Enforcement Officer shall receive such compensation, if any, as may be
fixed by the President and Board of Trustees from time to time in the annual
appropriation ordinance or by separate ordinance. (1977 Code § 2-15-5; amd.
2004 Code)

(Repealed by Ord. 1355, 11-20-2019)

1-7K-2: Term Of Office

892, 6-24-2002)

1-7K-3: DUTIES:

matters referred to such engineer and shall perform such duties as are provided
by law or ordinance and, in addition thereto, such other duties as from time to
time may be requested by the Village President or the corporate authorities.

a regular basis, and shall make such suggestions to the President or corporate
