4-5-8: HOLDING TANKS:
   A.   Holding Tanks Prohibited; Exceptions: The use of any holding tank for
the purpose of storing human excreta or liquid waste, or both, from any
premises, building or structure, if the holding tank is not connected to a
properly functioning and approved individual sewage disposal system, shall not
be permitted; except, if the Village Health Officer certifies in writing that
there is no practical alternative to the use of a holding tank, a holding tank
may be permitted for seasonal use for not more than five (5) months in any
calendar year by property in any club zoning district; provided, that prior to
the first use of such holding tank in any calendar year, there is filed with
the Village written evidence that such holding tank will be pumped on a regular
basis as needed by a licensed septic hauler, and provided further, that such
holding tank is not prohibited by valid state or federal law or regulations.
(1977 Code §
7-8-1)
   B.   Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this section shall be
punishable as provided in section
4-1-4 of this title. (2004 Code)
4-5-9: REQUIRED PERIODIC MAINTENANCE OF PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS:
   A.   History, Purpose And Scope:
      1.   History: Historically, North Barrington has addressed failing
private sewage disposal systems ("septic systems") within the Village through
enforcement of current codes and regulations, during the abatement of
complaints, or by providing assistance or variances to those who have
experienced problems with their systems and have requested guidance.
      2.   Purpose: The purpose of this section is to protect the public
health, safety, and natural environment by providing a program which
establishes required periodic maintenance of septic systems within the Village.
Failing septic systems are expensive to repair or replace, and poor maintenance
is a common cause of early system failures. The minimal amount of preventative
maintenance that septic systems require costs very little in comparison to the
cost to replace one that has failed. Many of these problems and failures could
have been prevented with proper maintenance.
The protection of the health of families, community and the environment is a
benefit to all when private sewage disposal systems are maintained properly.
When septic systems fail, inadequately treated household wastewater is released
into the environment. Contact with human waste that is not treated or is
inadequately treated can pose significant health risks, and untreated
wastewater from failing septic systems can contaminate nearby wells,
groundwater and drinking water sources. It is important that residents of the
Village educate themselves about what should and should not be disposed of
through a septic system and that their septic systems should be regularly
maintained and inspected.
Proper maintenance of a septic system protects the economic health of the
community. Failed septic systems can cause property values to decline. Building
permits cannot be issued or real estate sales can be delayed for properties
until the failed septic systems are repaired or replaced. Also, failed or
inadequately maintained septic systems can constitute a nuisance to nearby
properties and contribute to the pollution of local creeks, streams, rivers,
lakes, and shorelines that the community uses for commercial or recreational
activities.
      3.   Scope: All property within the Village, upon which a septic system
is installed, whether the system is in use or is dormant, is subject to the
provisions of this section.
   B.   Required Maintenance Of Private Septic Systems: The tank and field
lines of all septic systems within the Village shall be regularly serviced
every five (5) years as required herein.
Required maintenance or servicing of private septic systems shall include
pumping of the septic system's tank(s), cleaning filters, inspection of the
tank inlet and outlet tees and drainage field, and any additional necessary
services or repairs to the tank, drainage field lines, or mechanical components
of the system identified during the inspection. These services must be
performed by qualified septic system maintenance service personnel licensed by
the state of Illinois, including, but not limited to, licensed private sewage
pumping contractors. It is recognized that while such maintenance may indicate
that the system was in proper operating condition on the date of the inspection
and maintenance, there is no assurance that the system will remain in proper
operating condition for the duration of the operating permit.
   C.   Five Year Service Interval: All septic systems shall be serviced as
provided in subsection B of this section at least every five (5) years.
   D.   Notification And Reporting Requirements: Not less than ninety (90) days
prior to the date which is five (5) years after the prior maintenance as
provided for in subsection B of this section, a "notice for service due" shall
be mailed by the Village to the owner or occupant of such property at the
address to which real estate tax bills are sent. The owner or occupant shall
provide proof of inspection, service or pumping to the Village within thirty
(30) days after the expiration of the ninety (90) day notice period. A valid
copy, e-mail or facsimile transmissions will be accepted. Failure of the
Village to mail the notice does not release any owner or occupant of
responsibility to perform the required maintenance as described herein.
   E.   Permit Costs: The Village shall issue to the owner or occupant a
private sewage disposal system operating permit after completion of the
required maintenance upon payment of a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per
permit issued. Notwithstanding that operating permits are issued for a term of
five (5) years, they shall expire upon a septic system malfunction or failure.
The operating permits will be reissued upon proof of maintenance service or
upon proof that malfunctioning system has been repaired.
   F.   Repairs: All repairs or alterations to an existing private septic
system within the Village must be performed in accordance with sections
4-5-1, "Rules And Regulations; Purpose", and
4-5-3, "Permit To Construct Or Alter Private Systems", of this chapter.
All required maintenance and repairs of private septic systems shall be at the
expense of the owner or occupant.
   G.   Provision For Exemption Or Waiver From This Requirement: Owners or
occupants whose sanitary sewers are connected to a sewer system owned by a
municipality or the Wynstone Property Owners' Association are exempt from the
requirements of this section.
Owners and occupants shall be exempt from the initial service requirements if
they are able to submit verification to the Village that their septic system
was pumped out on or after April 1, 2010, and the maintenance requirements of
this section shall begin on the date which is five (5) years after the date of
such service occurring after April 1, 2010. Further routine maintenance may not
be required until the subsequent due date as recorded by the Village, providing
all other provisions of this section are satisfied.
Property owners who have had maintenance performed on their systems before
their regularly scheduled interval and without a "notice for service due" from
the village, or who did not receive such notice and who would like to credit
the procedure to the village record by reporting this unscheduled service to
the village, may submit their documentation at any time.
A permit shall be issued at five (5) year intervals based on the documentation
of this maintenance service and the payment of the twenty five dollar ($25.00)
permit fee. (Ord. 1191-A, 8-25-2010)
   H.   Penalties: Failure of an owner/occupant to renew or have in effect a
current septic system permit shall be punishable by a fine of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) and/or further legal action; provided that such fine shall be
reduced to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) if paid within fourteen (14)
days after being imposed. Each subsequent enforcement proceedings initiated by
reason of failure of the owner/occupant to remedy a prior failure to renew or
have in effect a current septic system permit shall be punishable by a fine of
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and/or further legal action. (Ord. 1249,
1-22-2014)
CHAPTER 5
PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS
ARTICLE A. CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS
SECTION:
4-5A-1: Definitions
4-5A-2: Minimum Standards
4-5A-3: Septic Tank Capacity And Design
4-5A-4: Septic Tank Construction And Installation
4-5A-5: Sewer Header Line Construction
4-5A-6: Subsurface Seepage Requirements
4-5A-7: Private Disposal System Standards
4-5A-8: Aerobic Treatment Plants
4-5A-9: Covering Over Septic Systems
4-5A-10: Curtain Drains
4-5A-11: Improvements To Structures
4-5A-1: DEFINITIONS:
   A.   Words Defined: As used in this article, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
    AT GRADE SYSTEM: One designed in accordance with "Wisconsin At-Grade Soil
Absorption System, Siting, Design and Construction Manual, Small Scale Waste
Management Project", University of Wisconsin, Madison, January 1990 (these
systems are identified as "type 4" systems in the Lake County code).
   LOW PRESSURE PIPE TRENCH SYSTEM: One designed in accordance with "Design and
Installation of Low Pressure Pipe Waste Treatment Systems", University of North
Carolina Sea Grant College Publication, University of North Carolina 56-82-03,
May 1982 (these systems are identified as "type 3" systems in the Lake County
code).
   MOUND SYSTEM: One designed in accordance with the "Wisconsin Mound Soil
Absorption System, Siting, Design and Construction Manual", Small Scale Waste
Management Project, University of Wisconsin, Madison, January 1990 (these
systems are identified as "type 5" systems in the Lake County code). A "mound
system" may be referred to in this article as an "aboveground system".
   NONPRESSURE SUBSURFACE TRENCH SYSTEM: One designed in accordance with
parameters set forth in this code (these systems are identified as "types 1 and
2" systems in the Lake County code).
   SUBSURFACE TRENCH SYSTEM: Shall consist of underground trenches and drop
boxes.
   B.   Exceptions To Design Criteria: Exceptions to design criteria of systems
defined in subsection A of this section, definitions of "at grade system, "low
pressure pipe trench system" and "mound system", are described in this article.
(1977 Code §
7-5-1)
4-5A-2: MINIMUM STANDARDS:
Every individual sewage disposal system shall be designed, constructed and
utilized in accordance with the minimum standards as specified in the
regulations of this article. (1977 Code §
7-5-2)
4-5A-3: SEPTIC TANK CAPACITY AND DESIGN:
   A.   Minimum Capacity: Minimum capacity below outlet   500 gallons
   B.   Single-Family Residential Units: Minimum capacities below outlet for
septic tanks serving new single-family residential units will be as follows:
 
Number Of Minimum Liquid
Bedrooms  Capacity Of Tank
          
3 or less 1,500
4         2,000
5         2,200
6         2,600
7 or more 3,000
 
   C.   Buildings Other Than Residences: For buildings other than residences,
the septic tank capacity below the outlet for the following flow estimates
shall be as follows:
 
Flow Estimates In Gallons Per Day    Septic Capacity In Gallons
Up to 667                            At least 1,000
Greater than 667 and less than 1,500 At least 11/2 times the estimated daily
                                     sewage flow
Greater than 1,500                   1,125 plus 75 percent of the daily sewage
                                     flow
 
   D.   Tank Design: All tanks, except when used in series, shall have two (2)
compartments designed with at least one-half (1/2) but not more than two-thirds
(2/3) of the total capacity provided in the first compartment. When the total
capacity exceeds one thousand five hundred (1,500) gallons, two (2) tanks or
more in series may be installed with at least one-half (1/2) but no more than
two-thirds (2/3) of the total capacity provided in the first tank. (1977 Code §
7-5-3)
4-5A-4: SEPTIC TANK CONSTRUCTION AND INSTALLATION:
   A.   Approval Required: All septic tanks must be approved by the Health
Officer. In granting such approval, the Health Officer's determination will be
based upon the requirements of the private sewage disposal licensing act 1  and
code 2  and the specific requirements set forth in this section.
   B.   Construction Requirements:
      1.   Manhole Cover: If the tank cover is cast monolithically with sides
of the tank, a manhole cover with a minimum diameter of twelve inches (12")
shall be provided; this manhole may be used as an inspection port if it is
located over the inlet or outlet.
      2.   In Place Construction: Any tank constructed in place must meet the
requirements of this article, Illinois private sewage disposal licensing act
and the private sewage disposal code. (1977 Code §
7-5-4)
      3.   Baffles: Baffles are required on the inlets and outlets and an
approved baffling system is required between compartments. See the state
private sewage disposal licensing act and code for construction requirements.
(1977 Code §
7-5-4; amd. 2004 Code)
      4.   Grease Traps: Grease traps are not permitted for residential use.
Grease traps, if used for industrial or commercial use, shall have a liquid
capacity of at least five hundred (500) gallons, shall be constructed to permit
inspection and servicing, and shall be of an approved design and capacity.
   C.   Installation:
      1.   If the top of the tank is more than eight inches (8") below the
ground surface, watertight risers to the ground surface level shall be
installed over the ports. Risers shall have a minimum diameter of eight inches
(8").
      2.   If the top of the tank is more than twenty four inches (24") below
the ground surface, all joints, covers and inspection ports must be watertight.
(1977 Code §
7-5-4)
      3.   New septic tanks and replacements within five feet (5') of or in
flood areas must have the outlet at or above the base flood elevation of
record. (1977 Code §
7-5-4; amd. 2004 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 225/1 et seq.
2 2. 225 ILCS 225/7.
4-5A-5: SEWER HEADER LINE CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   All piping located five feet (5') from the building foundation, used to
convey wastewater to an individual sewage disposal system, shall be considered
a part of that system. (1977 Code §
7-5-5)
   B.   All piping located five feet (5') from the building foundation to the
septic tank shall be of cast iron or plastic as described in the list of
approved plastic pipe for the individual sewage disposal system uses in the
private sewage disposal licensing act and the private sewage disposal code.
Cast iron piping cannot be used after the tank or between tanks in series, due
to corrosion. (1977 Code §
7-5-5; amd. 2004 Code)
   C.   Plastic pipe or fittings utilized in individual sewage disposal systems
shall be manufactured from the list of approved materials, as specified in the
private sewage disposal licensing act and the private sewage disposal code.
   D.   All lines shall have watertight joints and be installed according to
the manufacturer's directions.
   E.   Sewer lines from any dwelling or building to a septic tank which are
located under driveways or other structures shall be constructed of schedule 40
PVC or stronger pipe and may, upon direction of the Health Officer, be
encapsulated within a second pipe of equal strength to improve insulation
against freezing. Additional insulation may be necessary.
   F.   No sewer line shall be less than four inches (4") in diameter. The
slope shall be a minimum of one-fourth inch (1/4") per foot between the
building and tank. (1977 Code §
7-5-5)
4-5A-6: SUBSURFACE SEEPAGE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Soil Evaluation: All proposed systems shall be evaluated based on soil
analyses performed by qualified soil scientists and by percolation tests.
   B.   Size Of Systems: The size of all trench systems and treatment areas
shall be based on the number of bedrooms in a residence as follows:
      1.   Minimum Treatment Area:
         a.   Subsurface trench systems shall be designed with a minimum of
five hundred (500) square feet of trench per bedroom with a minimum field size
of one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet of trench.
         b.   All other systems shall have a minimum treatment area which meets
the requirements of the Lake County health and sanitation ordinance of the Lake
County code but shall provide for a treatment area of not less than that
required by the Lake County code for a three (3) bedroom house.
      2.   Responsibility For Tests: Notwithstanding the results of soil and
percolation tests, the licensed private sewage contractor shall be responsible
for the proper construction and initial functioning of the treatment systems.
(1977 Code §
7-5-6)
      3.   Percolation Test Results: Written percolation test results pursuant
to the requirements of section
4-5-6 of this chapter shall be provided to the Health Officer. (Ord. 854, 11-
20-2000)
   C.   Approved Treatment Systems:
      1.   Approved Systems:
         a.   A subsurface trench system is the treatment process approved in
the Village.
         b.   An at grade system shall be used in lieu of subsurface trench
systems when construction of an at grade system preserves significant trees,
provides extra protection of the water table or adds aesthetically to the
landscape.
         c.   Mound systems are to be used only when at grade systems are not
feasible due to depth of water table and soil types.
         d.   Whether a subsurface trench system alone will be utilized shall
be based on soils, location of water table and percolation rates.
         e.   A class I aeration system is required:
            (1)   For all at grade systems and mound systems; or
            (2)   When percolation tests performed at a minimum of eighteen
inches (18") below natural grade yield results less than one inch (1") in sixty
(60) minutes; or
            (3)   In all soils identified as Beecher, Elliotts and similar type
soils; or
            (4)   When the seasonal high water table is less than thirty inches
(30") below the natural ground surface; or
            (5)   When the observed water table is less than thirty inches
(30") below the natural ground surface; or
            (6)   When the septic system is within one hundred feet (100') of
high water elevations of detention ponds, lakes and streams.
      2.   Alternate Systems:
         a.   If the above requirements for the approved systems cannot be met,
at the request of the property owner, the Environmental and Health Commission
will consider submittals on other system proposals which have been reviewed by
the Health Officer and have been approved by the state.
         b.   Upon consideration of an alternative system request, the
Environmental and Health Commission will make a recommendation to the corporate
authorities. Any approval by the corporate authorities shall be by resolution.
If an alternative system is found to be acceptable, the Health Officer will
recommend design parameters to be used based on each individual situation.
         c.   The owner's design engineer must consider drainage, aesthetics
and final landscaping when designing an aboveground system. The design of an
aboveground system shall be subject to approval of the Village Health Officer.
Prior to issuance of a permit for an aboveground system, the property owner
shall sign and file with the Village an agreement that the aboveground system
will be built and maintained in accordance with the approved design.
   D.   Reserve Treatment System: All septic system plans shall include an area
for a reserve treatment system which shall be available in the event of failure
of the original or primary treatment system. The area set aside for the reserve
treatment system shall meet all the requirements of the area provided for the
primary treatment system, including size and acceptable percolation test
performance pursuant to this title. (1977 Code §
7-5-6; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. 1040, 6-28-2004; Ord. 1129, 12-17-2007)
4-5A-7: PRIVATE DISPOSAL SYSTEM STANDARDS:
   A.   Protection Of Site: The area proposed for the wastewater disposal
system and expansion area shall be fenced with a snow fence, two by fours (2 x
4) or equivalent, before a construction permit is issued, and such fencing
shall be maintained until an occupancy permit is issued for the structure to be
served by the wastewater disposal system if there is new construction or
remodeling. No vehicular traffic shall drive over the area enclosed by the
fence, and vehicular traffic is prohibited in the immediate area except for
vehicles necessary for the installation of the wastewater disposal system which
shall be under the supervision of the licensed septic contractor. If the system
area is disturbed, the permit may be revoked by the Health Officer, and
additional soil evaluations, including bulk density, may be required to
determine suitability. A new permit application and fees will be required.
   B.   Site Approval; Activities To Cease: After a proposed system has been
approved, the area in which it is to be installed shall not be cut, or filled,
or disturbed in any way, unless alterations are specified on the plan approved
by the Health Officer. Prior to approval for construction by the Health
Officer, the well site and the soil absorption system shall be staked out.
   C.   Location Of Structures: Alterations or additions to any structures or
the erection of any new structure shall be a minimum of twenty feet (20') from
the primary and future (reserve) soil absorption field areas. Patios,
driveways, and other similar installations shall be a minimum of ten feet (10')
from the primary and future (reserve) soil absorption field.
   D.   Location Of Utilities:
      1.   Wells And Other Water Sources: Drinking water and sprinkler lines
and pools shall not be installed or permitted within twenty five feet (25') of
the soil absorption field area or future expansion area.
      2.   Utility Lines: Utility service lines to the house shall not be
installed within five feet (5') of a soil absorption field area or future
expansion area.
   E.   Subsurface Trench System Requirements:
      1.   Trenching Specifications:
         a.   The minimum width of trench shall be twenty four inches (24");
the maximum width of trench shall be thirty six inches (36").
         b.   The bottom of the trenches shall be level. Trenches shall not be
excavated when the soil is of such wetness as to smear easily or when frost
depth exceeds eight inches (8").
         c.   Minimum distance between trenches (center to center) is three (3)
times the trench width, but in no case less than six feet (6').
         d.   Maximum length of each soil absorption trench from point of
distribution shall be one hundred feet (100').
      2.   Serial Distribution, Distribution Box And Diversion Devices:
         a.   Serial distribution systems shall be used where the difference in
elevation in the soil absorption area exceeds six inches (6"). All material
used to construct these types of distribution systems must be approved by the
Health Officer; distribution and drop boxes shall be constructed of plastic or
other approved material.
         b.   The lines of distribution box system must be tied together. The
following are details from the state code:
            (1)   The bottom of each trench and its distribution line shall be
level.
            (2)   There shall be a minimum of six inches (6") of earth backfill
over the bedding material in the trenches.
            (3)   The trench shall follow the ground surface contours so that
variation in trench depth will be minimized.
            (4)   There shall be a minimum of five feet (5') of undisturbed
earth between the septic tank and the nearest trench.
            (5)   Adjacent trenches shall be connected with a relief line or a
drop box arranged so that each trench is completely filled to the full depth of
the gravel before effluent flows to the succeeding trench.
            (6)   The relief lines connecting the trenches shall have
watertight joints and direct connections to the distribution lines in adjacent
trenches. Tight joint "Ts" and forty five degree (45°) ells, or a drop box
arrangement shall be used to connect adjacent trenches.
            (7)   Where the relief pipe trench connects with the higher trench,
it shall not be deeper than the top of the gravel in the higher trench. Relief
lines shall rest on undisturbed earth, and the backfill shall be carefully
tamped.
            (8)   The invert of the first relief line shall be at least one
inch (1") lower than the invert of the septic tank or aerobic treatment plant
outlet.
      3.   Pipe In The Soil Absorption System: Minimum inside diameter of pipe
shall be one and one-fourth inch (11/4") for low pressure systems and four
inches (4") for nonpressure systems. Perforated pipe designed for soil
absorption system use shall be as approved by the Illinois private sewage
disposal act and code and by the Health Officer.
      4.   Trench Fill Material:
         a.   The minimum depth of stone under perforated pipe shall be six
inches (6"). The minimum depth of stone over perforated pipe shall be two
inches (2").
         b.   Trench fill material - stone - shall be washed so as to be free
of dust, sand, clay or fine material. Stone may vary from one-half inch (1/2")
to one and one-half inches (11/2") in size. Stone shall be uniformly spread and
level with, or lower than, the bottom of the tank outlet and must also be lower
than the drop box outlet throughout the length of each line.
         c.   Stone shall be covered with approved polypropylene, approved
polyester, or a minimum of six inches (6") of straw or other material approved
by the Health Officer. The trench shall be backfilled with a minimum of six
inches (6") of topsoil, with the maximum depth dependent on soil type.
      5.   Backfill:
         a.   All trenches shall be backfilled as soon as possible after
inspection and approval by the Health Officer.
         b.   No portion of the system shall be covered before it has been
inspected and approved in writing by the Health Officer.
         c.   Frozen or wet (so as to smear) material may not be used for
backfilling.
         d.   Rough and finished grading of the soil absorption system shall be
so designed and executed with respect to elevation and slope so that the
surface drainage is off the area. A minimum of one foot (1') per one hundred
feet (100') of slope must be maintained over the septic field area. Mounding
soil above the absorption system area may be required to shed rainfall.
         e.   All systems must have final grading and seeding or be mulched
with straw or other acceptable material prior to occupancy and final approval.
Only hand held equipment may be used on the septic field area after system has
been installed.
      6.   Minimum Distances: The locations of all components of an individual
sewage disposal system shall comply with the minimum distances listed in the
following chart:

4-5A-8: AEROBIC TREATMENT PLANTS:
   A.   Compliance With National Standards: All aerobic treatment plants
hereafter installed shall comply with the requirements of the National
Sanitation Foundation (NSF) standard number 40, individual aerobic wastewater
treatment, May 1983, or that standard as it may be amended from time to time,
and shall bear the NSF seal.
   B.   Class I Aerobic Treatment Plants:
      1.   Aerobic treatment plants listed by NSF for class I effluent (BOD5,
20 mg/l and suspended solids, 40 mg/l) shall discharge to a subsurface seepage
field designed and constructed in accordance with the requirements of this
article.
      2.   Class I aerobic treatment systems, as described herein, shall be
required when a percolation test performed in original soil yields results
greater than sixty (60) minutes per inch. An aerator may be required on
alternative systems if they are permitted. (1977 Code §
7-5-8)
      3.   Aerobic treatment plants which are listed by NSF as class I shall be
sized as follows:
Bedrooms Minimum Rated Treatment
         Capacity/Gallons
Bedrooms Minimum Rated Treatment
         Capacity/Gallons
         
3        500
4        600
5        750
6        900
7        1,050
8        1,200
9        1,350
10       1,500
 
(1977 Code §
7-5-8; amd. 2004 Code)
   C.   Chlorinators And Sand Filters: Any design which requires an aerobic
treatment plant may require, at the discretion of the Health Officer, a
chlorinator and sand filter system in addition to the subsurface seepage system
as determined by the Health Officer.
   D.   Installation: All components of aerobic treatment plants shall be
installed at the time of the original installation.
   E.   Access: Access to an aerobic treatment plant shall be adequate to allow
maintenance and service of all components within such plant.
   F.   Maintenance: The property owner at all times must have a maintenance
agreement in effect for the aerobic unit to cover such things as filter
replacement and general condition. A copy of the current maintenance agreement
must be on file with the Village, or the owner may be subject to penalties.
(1977 Code §
7-5-8)
4-5A-9: COVERING OVER SEPTIC SYSTEMS:
The minimum required covering over the tile in a septic system shall not be
reduced by any landscaping after the septic system contractor has completed his
work on the septic system. When landscaping or grading is to be done, it must
be accomplished without affecting the minimum standards of this title for
covering over a septic system. (1977 Code §
7-5-9)
4-5A-10: CURTAIN DRAINS:
   A.   Purpose: Curtain drains shall divert such water that otherwise would
travel onto or into the seepage field of the individual sewage disposal system.
Such curtain drains shall divert such water to an elevation lower than such
seepage field. Curtain drains shall not discharge into a ditch.
   B.   Curtain Drain Required: Upon review by the Health Officer, a curtain
drain may be required when septic systems are placed in slow permeability type
soils or when seasonal high water table is less than forty eight inches (48")
from ground surface.
   C.   Construction Specifications:
      1.   Curtain drains shall be installed in a trench twelve inches (12") in
width, said trench to be filled with gravel to within four inches (4") of the
existing grade, and the top four inches (4") shall be filled with porous
topsoil.
      2.   The curtain drain shall be installed into the slowly permeable
subsoil.
      3.   The curtain drainpipe shall be constructed with PVC material, not
less than four inches (4") in diameter, and shall be separate from any other
drains. The pipe shall be perforated when located above and below parallel to
the trenches and solid when running alongside and perpendicular to the septic
trenches. (1977 Code § 7-5-10)
4-5A-11: IMPROVEMENTS TO STRUCTURES:
   A.   Bedroom Additions 1 : Whenever any existing residence is enlarged to
add one or more bedrooms, or other rooms suitable to be used regularly as
bedrooms, all requirements of this title applicable to new residences relative
to individual sewage disposal systems shall be fully complied with unless the
Village Board of Trustees, after a hearing before the Environmental and Health
Commission, concludes that such requirement should be waived in a particular
case. (1977 Code § 7-5-11; amd. Ord. 1040, 6-28-2004; Ord. 1129, 12-17-2007)
   B.   Other Improvements:
      1.   Septic Tank Alterations: Except as hereinafter provided, whenever
the relocation of a septic tank is required by reason of alterations or an
addition to a building, only the tank system shall be required to be brought
into compliance with the then current provisions of the Village code. If the
alteration or addition to a building affects any other part of the septic
system, an evaluation report must be submitted from a licensed sanitarian
describing the condition of the existing septic field. If it is determined by
such evaluation report or by the Village Health Officer that the existing
septic field is in such condition as to not function properly, then the entire
septic system shall be brought into compliance with current Village code
provisions and regulations.
When a septic alteration is required by reason of a failing septic system, the
existing system shall be brought into compliance with existing Village code
provisions and regulations to the extent feasible, taking into consideration
existing lot size, topography and other pertinent features. (Ord. 1051, 11-22-
2004)
      2.   Plat Of Survey: A copy of the most recent plat of survey showing the
size and location of the existing septic system and location of replacement
field and the well location shall be submitted.
      3.   Infringement Upon Existing Fields: If the improvement infringes in
any existing septic field or in the replacement field area, the following may
be required:
         a.   New soil borings to determine alternate septic field location.
         b.   Percolation tests.
         c.   New septic drawing.
         d.   Septic permit application. (1977 Code § 7-5-12; amd. 2004 Code)
      4.   Approval Or Denial Of Improvement Requests: Upon review of the above
information, a determination will be made to determine compliance with this
chapter. If the review indicates noncompliance with this chapter, a denial
letter will be forwarded to the Environmental and Health Commission. The
applicant may then choose to apply for a variance as outlined in this chapter.
(1977 Code § 7-5-12; amd. 2004 Code; Ord. 1040, 6-28-2004; Ord. 1129, 12-17-
2007)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  4-1-1 of this title for definition of "bedroom".
ARTICLE B. PERCOLATION TESTS 1
SECTION:
4-5B-1: Percolation Test Standards
4-5B-2: Time Limit For Tests
4-5B-3: Test Hole Specifications
4-5B-4: Preparation And Procedure
4-5B-5: Notice Of Test; Reports
4-5B-6: Scheduling And Fees
 
Notes
  1. See also sections
1 4-5-6 and
  4-5A-6 of this chapter.
4-5B-1: PERCOLATION TEST STANDARDS:
Percolation tests shall be performed in accordance with this chapter. (1977
Code §
7-6-1)
4-5B-2: TIME LIMIT FOR TESTS:
Percolation tests must be performed within eighteen (18) months prior to
submittal of an application for a building or septic system permit. (1977 Code
§ 7-6-8)
4-5B-3: TEST HOLE SPECIFICATIONS:
   A.   Number And Location: Six (6) or more tests shall be made in separate
test holes spaced uniformly over the proposed absorption field site and reserve
field site as required by section
4-5A-6 of this title. (1977 Code §
7-6-2; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Depth Of Tests:
      1.   Tests shall be conducted at a depth which is within four inches (4")
of the anticipated bottom of the designed trench depth unless otherwise
approved by the Health Officer; provided, that the maximum depth of the hole
for percolation tests shall be thirty six inches (36") and the minimum test
depth shall be twelve inches (12") in natural soil where no fill has been
imported to the site and six inches (6") into natural soils below filled areas.
      2.   It is recommended, but not required, that tests be at a depth of
twelve inches (12") when it is expected that fill is to be imported prior to
construction. (1977 Code §
7-4-3)
   C.   Type Of Test Hole: A hole shall be dug or bored with a diameter of
between four (4) and twelve inches (12") and to a depth of the proposed
absorption trench (a minimum of 12 inches). (1977 Code §
7-6-3; amd. 2004 Code)
4-5B-4: PREPARATION AND PROCEDURE:
   A.   Preparation Of Test Hole Area: The bottom and sides of the hole shall
be scratched with a knife blade or sharp pointed instrument in order to remove
any smeared soil surfaces and to provide a natural soil interface into which
water may percolate. All loose material shall be removed from the hole.
   B.   Test Procedure: On the day prior to the test, the holes shall be filled
with clear water and kept full for at least four (4) hours on the day of the
test; twelve inches (12") of water shall be kept in the holes for the first two
(2) hours of the four (4) hours prior to commencing the test, and during the
next two (2) hours, the water should be allowed to drop to six inches (6"). Six
inches (6") of water shall be kept in the holes until test time. The test shall
begin with six inches (6") of water in the holes. After one hour, the drop in
water level shall be measured and recorded. The holes shall be refilled to six
inches (6") and repeated for a total of three (3) 1-hour readings followed by
two (2) half hour readings. (1977 Code § 7-6-4)
4-5B-5: NOTICE OF TEST; REPORTS:
   A.   Notice Of Test; Presence Of Village Official Required: The Health
Officer or a designated representative shall be notified in advance of the
conducting of soil absorption tests. Tests conducted without prior notice being
given the Health Officer, as described above, will not be recognized. The test
must be witnessed by the Health Officer or designated representatives if it is
to be used for design purposes and permit request. (1977 Code § 7-6-5)
   B.   Reports And Results: Absorption test results shall be reported on the
form provided by the Health Officer. (1977 Code § 7-6-6)
4-5B-6: SCHEDULING AND FEES:
   A.   Fee: Prior to scheduling a witnessed percolation test, the applicant
shall pay to the Village a fee as set out in subsection 4-5-3E of this chapter.
The Village will issue a receipt and give notice of payment to the person
designated by the Village to witness the test.
   B.   Tests To Be Scheduled: The test must be scheduled by twelve o'clock
(12:00) noon at least two (2) business days prior to the first test date. For
example, if the applicant wants to start the test on Thursday, a call for
scheduling must be made not later than twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on the
preceding Tuesday.
   C.   Cancelled Tests; Refund Or Credit:
      1.   Full refunds or credits will be given for a test cancelled twenty
four (24) hours or more prior to scheduled start of the test.
      2.   If the test is cancelled less than twenty four (24) hours from the
scheduled first day of the test, the entire witnessing fee shall be forfeited
unless the Village determines that cancellation was for reasons beyond the
control of the applicant, such as unexpected adverse weather conditions.
   D.   Test Witness: Applicants should contact the Village Hall for names and
phone numbers of Village representatives who will be available to witness the
tests. (1977 Code § 7-6-7; amd. 2004 Code)
ARTICLE C. SOIL SUITABILITY
SECTION:
4-5C-1: Soils Investigation Procedure
4-5C-2: Unauthorized Change Of Contour
4-5C-1: SOILS INVESTIGATION PROCEDURE:
Soils investigation shall be performed and reported as required by the Lake
County Health Department. (2004 Code)
4-5C-2: UNAUTHORIZED CHANGE OF CONTOUR:
Should the contour of the original ground be changed by filling, compacting or
excavating to a degree that would significantly alter the original soil
absorption rate, a new soil evaluation will determine the extent of the damage.
All permits issued before the unauthorized change of contour shall be void, and
a new application request must be submitted along with appropriate fees. (1977
Code §
7-7-2)
CHAPTER 6
SUMP PUMPS
SECTION:
4-6-1: Sump Pump Pipe Terminus
4-6-1: SUMP PUMP PIPE TERMINUS:
Effective April 1, 2018, based upon site conditions, the termination of all
sump pump pipes must be protected with an erosion control measure (such as a
lined apron, infiltration trench or an infiltration pit) to be approved by the
Village Health Officer or Village Engineer. An air gap shall be installed in
the drainage pipe at the discharge point at the building. The infiltration pit
shall be constructed with Illinois Department of Transportation (IDOT)
gradation for Coarse Aggregate - 7 (CA-7), with at least eighteen inches (18")
deep, with a minimum surface area of one hundred (100) square feet, and a
minimum of six inches (6") of topsoil cover and vegetative planting. The
discharge termination shall be located at least twenty five feet (25') from any
property line unless this requirement is waived by the Village Health Officer
or Village Engineer for good cause and the Village Health Officer or Village
Engineer finds that there are adequate safeguards to protect adjoining property
from drainage discharge. The Village Health Officer or Village Engineer may, in
their sole discretion, make exceptions or alterations to any and all
requirements of this section for an individual location, to the extent that the
exception or alteration avoids a commercial impracticability and otherwise does
not pose a risk to the health, safety, and welfare of persons or property in
the Village. (Ord. 1319, 3-21-2018)
CHAPTER 7
ILLICIT DISCHARGES AND CONNECTIONS TO STORMWATER DRAINAGE SYSTEM
SECTION:

4-7-8: Industrial Or Construction Activity Discharges
4-7-9: Monitoring Of Discharges
4-7-10: Requirement To Prevent, Control, And Reduce Stormwater Pollutants By
The Use Of Best Management Practices
4-7-11: Watercourse Protection
4-7-12: Notification Of Spills
4-7-13: Notice Of Violation
4-7-14: Appeal Of Notice Of Violation
4-7-15: Enforcement
4-7-16: Cost Of Abatement Of The Violation
4-7-17: Injunctive Relief
4-7-18: Compensatory Action
4-7-19: Violations Deemed A Public Nuisance
4-7-20: Criminal Prosecution
4-7-21: Remedies Not Exclusive
4-7-1: PURPOSE/INTENT:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the health, safety, and general
welfare of the citizens of the Village of North Barrington through the
regulation of nonstormwater discharges to the stormwater drainage system to the
maximum extent practicable, as required by federal and state law. This chapter
establishes methods for controlling the introduction of pollutants into the
Village's municipal separate storm sewer system (MSSSS) in order to comply with
requirements of the national pollutant discharge elimination system (NPDES)
permit program. The objectives of this chapter are:
   A.   To regulate the discharge of pollutants to the MSSSS.
   B.   To prohibit illicit connections and discharges to the MSSSS.
   C.   To establish legal authority to carry out all inspection, surveillance
and monitoring procedures necessary to ensure compliance with this chapter.
(Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following shall mean:
AUTHORIZED ENFORCEMENT AGENCY: Employees or designees of the municipal agency
designated to enforce the provisions of this chapter.
BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPs): Schedules of activities, prohibitions of
practices, general good housekeeping practices, stormwater pollution prevention
and educational practices, maintenance procedures, and other management
practices intended to prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants directly or
indirectly to stormwater, receiving waters, and stormwater drainage systems.
BMPs also include treatment practices, operating procedures, and practices to
control site runoff, spillage, leaks, sludge and wastewater disposal, and
drainage from raw materials storage areas.
CLEAN WATER ACT: The federal water pollution control act (33 USC section 1251
et seq.), and any subsequent amendments thereto.
CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITY: Activities subject to an NPDES construction site
activities permit. Currently, these activities include construction projects
resulting in a land disturbance of one acre or more. Such activities include,
but are not limited to, clearing, grubbing, grading, excavating, and
demolition.
HAZARDOUS MATERIALS: Any material, including any substance, waste, or
combination thereof, which because of its quantity, concentration, or physical,
chemical, or infectious characteristics, may cause, or significantly contribute
to, a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, safety,
property, or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported,
disposed of, or otherwise managed.
ILLEGAL DISCHARGE: Any direct or indirect nonstormwater discharge to the
stormwater drainage system, except as exempted in section
4-7-6 of this chapter.
ILLICIT CONNECTION: Either of the following:
A. Any drain or conveyance, whether on the surface or subsurface, which allows
an illegal discharge to enter the stormwater drainage system, including, but
not limited to, any conveyances which allow any nonstormwater discharges such
as sewage, processed wastewater, and wash water, to enter the stormwater
drainage system and any connections to the stormwater drainage system from
indoor drains and sinks, regardless of whether said drain or connection had
been previously allowed, permitted, or approved by an authorized enforcement
agency; or
B. Any drain or conveyance connected from a commercial or industrial land use
to the stormwater drainage system which has not been documented in plans, maps,
or equivalent records and approved by an authorized enforcement agency.
INDUSTRIAL ACTIVITY: Activities subject to an NPDES industrial activities
permit as defined in 40 CFR section 122.26(b)(14).
MUNICIPAL SEPARATE STORM SEWER SYSTEM (MSSSS): The system of stormwater
drainage facilities, including sidewalks, roads with drainage systems,
municipal streets, catch basins, curbs, gutters, ditches, manmade channels and
storm drains, owned and operated by the Village and used for collecting and/or
conveying stormwater. The MSSSS is not used for collecting and/or conveying
sewage.
NATIONAL POLLUTANT DISCHARGE ELIMINATION SYSTEM (NPDES) STORMWATER DISCHARGE
PERMIT: A permit issued by the United States environmental protection agency
("EPA") (or by a state under authority delegated pursuant to 33 USC section
1342(b)) that authorizes the discharge of pollutants to waters of the United
States, whether the permit is applicable on an individual, group or general
areawide basis.
NONSTORMWATER DISCHARGE: Any discharge to the stormwater drainage system that
is not composed entirely of stormwater.
PERSON: Any individual, association, organization, partnership, firm,
corporation, or other entity recognized by law and acting as either the owner
or as the owner's agent.
POLLUTANT: Anything which causes or contributes to pollution. Pollutants may
include, but are not limited to, paints, varnishes, solvents, oil and other
automotive fluids, nonhazardous liquid and solid wastes, yard wastes, refuse,
rubbish, garbage, litter or other discarded or abandoned objects, ordinances,
accumulations that may cause or contribute to pollution, floatables,
pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers, hazardous substances and wastes, sewage,
fecal coliform and pathogens, dissolved and particulate metals, animal wastes,
wastes and residues that result from construction activity, and noxious or
offensive matter of any kind.
PREMISES: Any building, lot, parcel of land, or portion of land, whether
improved or unimproved, including adjacent sidewalks and parking strips located
on a public or private road or right of way.
STORMWATER: Any surface flow, runoff, and drainage consisting entirely of water
resulting from any form of natural precipitation.
STORMWATER DRAINAGE SYSTEM: The facilities by which stormwater is collected
and/or conveyed, including, but not limited to, sidewalks, roads with drainage
systems, municipal streets, catch basins, curbs, gutters, storm drains, pumping
facilities, retention and detention basins, natural and humanmade or altered
drainage channels, reservoirs, and other drainage structures.
STORMWATER POLLUTION PREVENTION PLAN: A document which describes the best
management practices and activities to be implemented by a person or business
to identify sources of pollution or contamination at a site and the actions to
eliminate or reduce pollutant discharges to stormwater, receiving waters, and
stormwater drainage systems to the maximum extent practicable.
WASTEWATER: Any water or other liquid, other than uncontaminated stormwater,
discharged from any premises. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-3: RESPONSIBILITY FOR ADMINISTRATION:
The Village shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this
chapter. Any powers granted or duties imposed upon the authorized enforcement
agency may be delegated in writing by the authorized enforcement agency to
persons or entities acting in the beneficial interest of or in the employ of
the Village. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-4: APPLICABILITY:
This chapter shall apply to all water entering the stormwater drainage system
and generated on any developed and undeveloped lands unless explicitly exempted
by the authorized enforcement agency. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-5: ULTIMATE RESPONSIBILITY:
The standards set forth in this chapter and promulgated pursuant to this
chapter are minimum standards; therefore this chapter does not intend, nor
imply, that compliance by any person will ensure that there will be no
contamination or pollution of stormwater or unauthorized discharge of
pollutants to the stormwater drainage system or to waters of the United States.
(Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-6: DISCHARGE PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Prohibition Of Illegal Discharges: No person shall discharge or cause
to be discharged into the stormwater drainage system or waters of the United
States any materials, pollutants, or waters containing any pollutants that
cause or contribute to a violation of applicable water quality standards.
The commencement, conduct, or continuance of any illegal discharge to the
stormwater drainage system is prohibited except as described as follows:
      1.   The following discharges are exempt from discharge prohibitions
established by this chapter: water line flushing, fire hydrant flushing,
discharges from potable water sources, landscape irrigation, lawn watering,
rising groundwater, groundwater infiltration, uncontaminated pumped
groundwater, diverted stream flows, natural riparian habitat and wetland flows,
springs, storm sewer cleaning water, street wash water from streets where
spills or leaks of pollutants or toxic or hazardous materials have not occurred
(unless the pollutants or toxic or hazardous materials have been removed),
foundation drains, footing drains, crawl space pumps, air conditioning
condensation, noncommercial vehicle washing, routine external building washing
that does not use detergents, dechlorinated swimming pool discharges
(discharges must contain less than one part per million chlorine), firefighting
activities, and any other water source not containing pollutants or toxic or
hazardous materials.
      2.   Discharges specified in writing by the authorized enforcement agency
as being necessary to protect public health and safety.
      3.   Dye testing is an allowable discharge, but requires a verbal
notification to the authorized enforcement agency prior to the time of the
test.
      4.   The prohibition shall not apply to any nonstormwater discharge
permitted under an NPDES permit, waiver, or waste discharge order issued to the
discharger and administered under the authority of the United States
environmental protection agency, provided that the discharger is in full
compliance with all requirements of the permit, waiver, or order and all other
applicable laws and regulations, and provided that written approval has been
granted by the authorized enforcement agency for the discharge to the
stormwater drainage system.
   B.   Prohibition Of Illicit Connections: The construction, use, maintenance,
or continued existence of illicit connections to the stormwater drainage system
is prohibited. This prohibition expressly includes, without limitation, illicit
connections made in the past, regardless of whether the connection was
permissible under law or practices applicable or prevailing at the time of
connection. A person is considered to be in violation of this chapter if the
person connects a line conveying sewage or any other nonstormwater discharge to
the MSSSS, or allows such a connection to continue. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-7: SUSPENSION OF MSSSS ACCESS:
   A.   Suspension Due To Illicit Discharges In Emergency Situations: The
Village may, without prior notice, suspend MSSSS discharge access to a person
when such suspension is necessary to stop an actual or threatened discharge
which presents or may present imminent and substantial danger to the
environment, to the health or welfare of persons, to the MSSSS, or to waters of
the United States. If the violator fails to comply with a suspension order
issued in an emergency, the authorized enforcement agency may take such steps
as deemed necessary to prevent or minimize damage to the MSSSS or waters of the
United States and to minimize danger to persons.
   B.   Suspension Due To The Detection Of Illicit Discharge: Any person
discharging to the MSSSS in violation of this chapter may have their MSSSS
access terminated if such termination would abate or reduce an illicit
discharge. The authorized enforcement agency will notify a violator, in
writing, of the proposed termination of its MSSSS access. The violator may
petition the authorized enforcement agency for a reconsideration and hearing.
A person violates this chapter if the person reinstates MSSSS access to
premises terminated pursuant to this section, without the prior written
approval of the authorized enforcement agency. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-8: INDUSTRIAL OR CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITY DISCHARGES:
Any person subject to an NPDES construction site activities permit or NPDES
industrial activities permit shall comply with all provisions of such permit.
Said person shall submit to the Village a copy of the notice of intent (NOI)
that was provided to the Illinois environmental protection agency (IEPA).
Additional proof of compliance with an NPDES construction site activities
permit or NPDES industrial activities permit may be required, in a form
acceptable to the Village, prior to the allowing of discharges to the MSSSS.
(Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-9: MONITORING OF DISCHARGES:
   A.   The authorized enforcement agency shall be permitted to enter and
inspect premises subject to regulation under this chapter as often as may be
necessary to determine compliance with this chapter. If a discharger has
security measures in force which require proper identification and clearance
before entry into its premises, the discharger shall make the necessary
arrangements to allow access to representatives of the authorized enforcement
agency.
   B.   Facility operators shall allow the authorized enforcement agency ready
access to all parts of the premises for the purposes of inspection, sampling,
examination, copying of records that must be kept under the conditions of an
NPDES permit, and the performance of any additional duties as required by state
and federal law.
   C.   The authorized enforcement agency shall have the right to set up on any
premises such devices as are necessary in the opinion of the authorized
enforcement agency to conduct monitoring and/or sampling of the premises'
stormwater discharge.
   D.   The authorized enforcement agency has the right to require the
discharger to install monitoring equipment as necessary. The facility's
sampling and monitoring equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe
and proper operating condition by the discharger at its own expense. All
devices used to measure stormwater flow and quality shall be calibrated to
ensure their accuracy.
   E.   Any temporary or permanent obstruction to safe and easy access to the
premises to be inspected and/or sampled shall be promptly removed by the
operator at the written or oral request of the authorized enforcement agency
and shall not be replaced. The costs of clearing such access shall be borne by
the operator.
   F.   Unreasonable delays in allowing the authorized enforcement agency
access to a premises is a violation of this chapter. A person who is the
operator of a facility with an NPDES permit to discharge stormwater associated
with industrial activity commits a violation of this chapter if the person
denies the authorized enforcement agency reasonable access to the permitted
facility for the purpose of conducting any activity authorized or required by
this chapter.
   G.   If the authorized enforcement agency has been refused access to any
part of the premises from which stormwater is discharged, and it is able to
demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of this
chapter, or that there is a need to inspect and/or sample as part of a routine
inspection and sampling program designed to verify compliance with this chapter
or any order issued hereunder, or to protect the overall public health, safety,
and welfare of the community, then the authorized enforcement agency may seek
issuance of a search warrant or other order from any court of competent
jurisdiction. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-10: REQUIREMENT TO PREVENT, CONTROL, AND REDUCE STORMWATER POLLUTANTS BY
THE USE OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES:
The owner, or operator of a commercial or industrial establishment, shall
provide, at their own expense, reasonable protection from accidental discharge
of prohibited materials or other wastes into the municipal stormwater drainage
system or waters of the United States through the use of structural and
nonstructural BMPs. Further, any person responsible for a property or premises,
which is, or may be, the source of an illicit discharge, may be required to
implement, at said person's expense, additional structural and nonstructural
BMPs to prevent the further discharge of pollutants to the municipal separate
storm sewer system. Compliance with all terms and conditions of a valid NPDES
permit authorizing the discharge of stormwater associated with industrial
activity, to the extent practicable, shall be deemed compliance with the
provisions of this section. These BMPs shall be part of a stormwater pollution
prevention plan (SWPPP) as necessary for compliance with requirements of the
NPDES permit. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-11: WATERCOURSE PROTECTION:
Every person owning property through which a watercourse passes, or such
person's lessee, shall keep and maintain that part of the watercourse within
the property free of trash, debris, excessive vegetation, and other obstacles
that would pollute, contaminate, or significantly retard the flow of water
through the watercourse. In addition, the owner or lessee shall maintain
existing privately owned structures within or adjacent to a watercourse, so
that such structures will not become a hazard to the use, function, or physical
integrity of the watercourse. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-12: NOTIFICATION OF SPILLS:
Notwithstanding other requirements of law, as soon as any person responsible
for a facility or operation, or any person responsible for emergency response
for a facility or operation, has information regarding any known or suspected
release of materials which are resulting or may result in illegal discharges or
in pollutants entering stormwater, the stormwater drainage system, or waters of
the United States, said person shall take all necessary steps to ensure the
discovery, containment, and cleanup of such release. In the event of such a
release of hazardous materials, said person shall immediately notify emergency
response agencies of the occurrence via emergency dispatch services. In the
event of a release of nonhazardous materials, said person shall notify the
authorized enforcement agency in person, by phone, or by facsimile no later
than the next business day. Notifications in person or by phone shall be
confirmed by written notice addressed and mailed to the Village within three
(3) business days of the phone call or personal notice. If the discharge of
prohibited materials emanates from a commercial or industrial establishment,
the owner or operator of such establishment shall also retain an on site
written record of the discharge and the actions taken to prevent its
recurrence. Such records shall be retained for at least three (3) years. (Ord.
1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-13: NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
Whenever the Village finds that a person has violated a prohibition or failed
to meet a requirement of this chapter, the authorized enforcement agency may
order compliance by written notice of violation to the responsible person. Such
notice may require, without limitation:
   A.   The performance of monitoring, analyses, and reporting;
   B.   The elimination of illicit connections or discharges;
   C.   That violating discharges, practices, or operations shall cease and
desist;
   D.   The abatement or remediation of stormwater pollution or contamination
hazards and the restoration of any affected property;
   E.   Payment of a fine to cover administrative and remediation costs; and
   F.   The implementation of source control or treatment BMPs.
If abatement of a violation and/or restoration of affected property is
required, the notice shall set forth a deadline within which such remediation
or restoration must be completed. Said notice shall further advise that, should
the violator fail to remediate or restore within the established deadline, the
work may be performed by the authorized enforcement agency and the expense
thereof shall be charged to the violator. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-14: APPEAL OF NOTICE OF VIOLATION:
Any person receiving a notice of violation may appeal the determination of the
authorized enforcement agency. The notice of appeal must be received within
fifteen (15) days from the date of the notice of violation. Hearing on the
appeal before a hearing officer of the Village, or other designated
administrative body, shall take place within thirty (30) days from the date of
receipt of the notice of appeal. The decision of the designated hearing officer
shall be final. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-15: ENFORCEMENT:
If the violation has not been corrected pursuant to the requirements set forth
in the notice of violation, or, in the event of an appeal, within thirty (30)
days of the decision of the designated hearing officer, then the authorized
enforcement agency reserves the right to enter upon the subject private
property and to take any and all measures necessary to abate the violation and/
or restore the property. It shall be unlawful for any person, owner, agent or
person in possession of any premises to refuse to allow the authorized
enforcement agency or designee to enter upon the premises for the purposes set
forth above.
The authorized enforcement agency may extend the period for corrective action
upon a showing of good cause for extension of the corrective action period.
(Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-16: COST OF ABATEMENT OF THE VIOLATION:
Within thirty (30) days after abatement of the violation by the authorized
enforcement agency, the owner of the property shall be notified of the cost of
abatement, including administrative costs. The property owner may file with the
Village Clerk of the Village a written protest objecting to the amount of the
assessment within fifteen (15) days. If the amount due is not paid within a
timely manner as determined by the decision of the designated management agency
or by the expiration of the time in which to file an appeal, the charges shall
constitute a lien on the property for the amount of the assessment.
Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall become liable
to the Village by reason of such violation. The liability may be paid in not
more than twelve (12) equal monthly payments. Interest at the rate of prime
rate charged by Harris NA to its most creditworthy customers from time to time
plus two percent (2%) per annum, shall be assessed on the balance beginning on
the first day following discovery of the violation. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-17: INJUNCTIVE RELIEF:
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision or fail to comply
with any of the requirements of this chapter. If a person has violated or
continues to violate the provisions of this chapter, the authorized enforcement
agency may petition for a preliminary or permanent injunction restraining the
person from activities which would create further violations or compelling the
person to perform abatement or remediation of the violation. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-
2008)
4-7-18: COMPENSATORY ACTION:
In lieu of enforcement proceedings, penalties, and remedies authorized by this
chapter, the authorized enforcement agency may impose upon a violator
alternative compensatory actions including, but not limited to, storm drain
stenciling, attendance at compliance workshops and cleanup activities. (Ord.
1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-19: VIOLATIONS DEEMED A PUBLIC NUISANCE:
In addition to the enforcement processes and penalties provided by this
chapter, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter is declared to be a threat to public health, safety,
and welfare, and is declared and deemed a nuisance, and may be summarily abated
or restored at the violator's expense, and/or a civil action to abate, enjoin,
or otherwise compel the cessation of such nuisance may be taken. (Ord. 1137, 3-
19-2008)
4-7-20: CRIMINAL PROSECUTION:
Any person that has violated or continues to violate this chapter shall be
liable to prosecution to the fullest extent of the law, and shall be subject to
a criminal penalty of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per violation per day.
Each violation and each day upon which an individual violation occurs shall
constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
4-7-21: REMEDIES NOT EXCLUSIVE:
The remedies listed in this chapter are not exclusive of any other remedies
available under any applicable federal, state or local law and it is within the
discretion of the authorized enforcement agency to seek cumulative remedies.
The authorized enforcement agency may recover all attorney fees, court costs
and other expenses associated with enforcement of this chapter, including
sampling and monitoring expenses. (Ord. 1137, 3-19-2008)
CHAPTER 8
COAL TAR BASED SEALANTS AND PAH SEALANTS
SECTION:
4-8-1: Definitions
4-8-2: Product Identifications
4-8-3: Certification
4-8-4: Penalties
4-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
APPLICATOR Shall mean any person who, for compensation applies a sealant within
the Village to public or privately owned surfaces including driveways, parking
lots, or recreational surfaces.
SEALANTS As used in this Chapter shall mean and include: "Pavement Sealant",
"Pavement Seal", "Sealcoat," "coal tar based sealant" and "High PAH Sealants"
any of which signifies a liquid that is applied to asphalt surfaces or in some
occasions on any surface, to protect the surfaces from damage or further damage
usually due to the freezing and thawing cycles, ultra- violet frequency rays
and/or traffic.
(Ord. 1287, 6-22-2016)
4-8-2: PRODUCT IDENTIFICATION:
Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (hereinafter "PAH") are unsubstituted
Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAH) and PAH derivatives found in coal-tar
and asphalt-based seal coat products.
product and shall require that all Applicators refrain from using any product
with the identifiers found in Table A below:
   TABLE A:
Coal Tar Based Sealants       Other High PAH Sealants
a.   CAS#65996-92-1        a.   CAS#64742-90-1
b.   CAS#65996-93-2        b.   CAS#69013-21-4
c.   CAS#65996-89-6        c.   Steam-cracked Petroleum Residues
d.   CAS#8007-45-2         d.   Steam-cracked Asphalt
e.   Coal Tar              e.   Pyrolysis Fuel Oil
f.   Coal Tar Pitch        f.   Pyrolysis Oil
g.   Coal Tar Distillates  g.   Heavy Aromatic Pyrolysis Oil
h.   RT-12                 h.   Heavy Fuel Oil (HFO)
I.   Refined Tar           I.   Heavy Pyrolysis Oil (HPO)
j.   Refined Coal Tar Pitchj.   Ethylene Tar
k.   Coal Tar Pitch Volatilk.   Ethylene Bottoms
l.   Tar                    
 
As other coal tar and high PAH sealants are identified by descriptive terms
and/or are identified by CAS#, this additional product information may be added
to the product list stated above by ordinance amending this Table and
thereafter shall be excluded from use.
It shall be unlawful and in violation of this ordinance for any Applicator or
any person to apply any Sealant that exceeds 0.1% total PAH by weight. If it is
not clear if a sealant product contains levels of PAH in excess of those
described in Table A, then a product's total PAH content by weight may be
determined by independent laboratory analysis; alternately, a product's total
PAH content by weight may be estimated through the use of the MSDS (or SDS),
independent laboratory analysis, independent peer-reviewed research, studies by
authoritative governmental bodies, or a combination of these sources. (Ord.
1287, 6-22-2016)
4-8-3: CERTIFICATION:
Prior to application of Sealants by any Applicator, such applicator shall sign
a certification on a form provided by the Village of North Barrington that the
Applicator and any person acting under the direction of the Applicator) will
not apply any products prohibited under this ordinance to any public or private
property within the Village of North Barrington. (Ord. 1287 ,6-22-2016)
4-8-4: PENALTIES:
Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be subject to the provisions of Chapter 4:1-4-1 General Penalty as
determined by the findings of the Health Officer. (Ord. 1287, 6-22-2016)
TITLE 5
ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS
CHAPTER 1
EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL
SECTION:
5-1-1: Purpose
5-1-2: Definitions
5-1-3: General Standards
5-1-4: Operation Standards And Requirements
5-1-5: Site Development Or Alteration Permit
5-1-6: Fees
5-1-7: Bond Requirements
5-1-8: Responsibilities Of Village And Permittee
5-1-9: Appeals
5-1-10: Exemptions From Provisions
5-1-11: Information Retained
5-1-12: Nuisance Conditions
5-1-13: Violations
5-1-1: PURPOSE:
The regulations contained in this chapter governing the clearing, grading,
excavating and transporting of or otherwise disturbing land are established for
the purpose of avoiding or lessening the following situations and to provide
minimum standards to safeguard persons, to protect property and to prevent the
despoliation of the environment and to promote the public welfare by regulating
and controlling the design, construction, quality of materials and the
construction, use and maintenance of any development or other activity which
disturbs or breaks the topsoil or otherwise results in the movement of earth on
land situated within the Village boundaries:
   A.   That the washing, blowing and falling of eroded soil across and upon
roadways endangers the health and safety of users thereof by decreasing vision
and reducing traction of road vehicles;
   B.   That said soil erosion necessitates the costly repairing of gullies,
washed out fills and embankments;
   C.   That the sediment from said soil erosion tends to clog sewers and
ditches and to pollute and silt rivers, streams, lakes and reservoirs;
   D.   That said sediment limits the use of water and waterways for most
beneficial purposes, destroying fish and other aquatic life, and that said
sediment is costly and difficult to remove;
   E.   That said sediment reduces the channel capacity of waterways, resulting
in greatly increased chances of flooding at grave danger to public health and
safety; and
   F.   That stripping and disturbing and breaking the topsoil of land tends to
destroy the physical characteristics of such land and its natural beauty,
especially where the land is rolling. (1977 Code §
6-1-1)
5-1-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, certain terms used herein are defined as set
forth below:
BERM: The placement of fill material to a height greater than eighteen inches
(18") but less than four feet (4') with side slopes not exceeding three to one
(3:1) above the existing ground surface.
BUILDING PERMIT: A permit issued by the Village of North Barrington for the
construction, erection or alteration of a structure or building as required by
this code.
CERTIFY OR CERTIFICATION: That the specific inspections and tests where
required have been performed, and that such tests comply with the applicable
requirements of this chapter.
CUBIC YARDS: The volume of material in excavation and/or fill.
EXCAVATION: Any act by which organic matter, earth, sand, gravel, rock or any
other similar material is cut into, dug, quarried, uncovered, removed,
displaced, relocated by man and shall include the conditions resulting
therefrom.
EXISTING GRADE: The vertical location of the existing ground surface prior to
excavation or filling.
FILL: Any act by which earth, sand, gravel, rock or any other material is
deposited, placed, replaced, pushed, dumped, pulled, transported or moved by
man to a new location and shall include the conditions resulting therefrom.
GRADING: Excavation or fill or any combination thereof and shall include the
conditions resulting from any excavation or fill.
PERMITTEE: Any person to whom a site development permit is issued.
PERSON: Any person, firm or corporation being a legal entity, public or
private, the state of Illinois and its agencies or political subdivisions, and
the United States of America, its agencies and instrumentalities, and any
agent, servant, officer or employee of the foregoing.
REMOVAL: Cutting vegetation to the ground or stumps, complete extraction, or
killing by spraying.
SITE: A lot resulting from any subdivision approved after January 1, 1971, and,
whether approved before or after January 1, 1971:
A. Any subdivision of property; or
B. Any planned unit development; or
C. Any combination of lots or sites where grading work is performed as a single
unified operation.
SITE DEVELOPMENT OR ALTERATION: Altering terrain and/or vegetation and
constructing driveways.
SITE DEVELOPMENT OR ALTERATION PERMIT: The permit provided for and required by
this chapter and this code.
VACANT: Land on which there are no structures.
VILLAGE: The Village of North Barrington. (1977 Code §
6-1-2; amd. Ord. 800, 6-28-1999; 2004 Code)
5-1-3: GENERAL STANDARDS:
The following general principles and those found in chapter 5 of this title
shall apply to any and all applications and plans for and the granting of a
permit provided for herein and the work carried out pursuant to such plan and
permit: (1977 Code §
6-1-3; amd. 2004 Code)
   A.   The smallest practical area of land shall be exposed at any given time
during development.
   B.   Such minimum area exposure shall be kept to as short a duration of time
as is practical.
   C.   Temporary vegetation or, where appropriate, mulching or other nonviable
cover shall be used to protect areas exposed during development.
   D.   Sediment basins, debris basins, desilting basins, or silt traps shall
be installed and maintained where necessary to remove sediment from runoff
waters from land undergoing development.
   E.   Provision shall be made to effectively accommodate the increased runoff
caused by changed soil and surface conditions during and after development.
   F.   Permanent, final plant covering or structures shall be installed as
soon as possible.
   G.   The plan of development shall relate to the topography and soils of the
site so that the lowest potential for erosion is created.
   H.   Natural plant covering, trees, shrubbery and vines shall be retained
and protected so far as is consistent with developing the site. (1977 Code §
6-1-3)
   I.   All berms shall be constructed to the following standards:
      1.   The slope of a berm shall not exceed a three to one ratio (3:1).
      2.   The height of a berm shall not exceed four feet (4'). (Ord. 800, 6-
28-1999)
5-1-4: OPERATION STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENTS:
All earth moving grading and grading operations not specifically exempted by
the provisions of this chapter shall comply with the applicable standards and
requirements set forth in chapter 5 of this title. (1977 Code §
6-1-4; amd. 2004 Code)
5-1-5: SITE DEVELOPMENT OR ALTERATION PERMIT:
   A.   Permit Required: Before land is cleared, graded, excavated, transported
or otherwise disturbed by the movement of earth for purposes including, but not
limited to, the construction of buildings, the mining of minerals, including
sand and gravel, the streets by any person, or any alterations to the
topography of proposed or existing developments, a site development or
alteration permit embodying the proposed earth movement shall be obtained from
the permit officer and plans submitted with the permit application in
conformance with section
8-3-2 of this code, where development comes under any one or more of the
following provisions, unless such development is exempted therefrom by
subsection B of this section:
      1.   Excavation, fill, or any combination thereof, which will exceed one
hundred (100) cubic yards or the construction of a "berm" as defined in this
chapter.
      2.   Excavation will exceed four feet (4') in depth at its deepest point
from existing ground surface.
      3.   Excavation, fill, or any combination thereof will exceed an area of
five thousand (5,000) square feet of ground surface.
      4.   Plant cover is to be removed from an area exceeding five thousand
(5,000) square feet on any vacant parcel of land in excess of ten (10) acres.
(Ord. 800, 6-28-1999)
   B.   Exemptions From Permit: A permit is not required for the following:
      1.   Excavations below finished grade for septic tanks and drain fields,
tanks, water pipes, vaults, tunnels, equipment basements, swimming pools,
cellars, or footings of buildings or structures for which a building permit
shall have been issued by the Village, unless part of a development which would
otherwise require such a permit.
      2.   Excavation or removal of vegetation in public utility easements by
public utility companies for the purpose of installing underground utilities.
      3.   Tilling of the soil for fire protection purposes.
   C.   Application For Permit:
      1.   No site development or building permit shall be issued until the
developer submits a site development plan, together with other submissions
required by this chapter and chapter 5 of this title and certifies that any
land clearing construction or development involving the movement of earth shall
be in accordance with such plan and submissions.
      2.   Each application for a site development permit shall be made by the
owner of the property or his authorized agent to the permit officer on a form
furnished for that purpose. When grading or plant cover removal is proposed as
a part of a building permit application, the building permit application and
the site development permit application may be combined, and one plot plan, in
the number of copies required by the permit officer, may be submitted showing
building plans and site development plans. A registered civil engineer shall
certify as to the accuracy of the existing and proposed contour lines. The
requirements for individual lots ordinarily can be met by reference to a
subdivision or planned unit development for which a site development permit has
been issued. Each application shall be accompanied by the following, unless the
permit officer finds any item unnecessary, to ensure compliance with the
provisions of this chapter; provided, that the permit officer shall grant no
exemption from subsection C2a of this section to any applicant who intends to
move in excess of five hundred (500) cubic yards of dirt:
         a.   With respect to site developments, a vicinity sketch showing
acreage of site, boundary lines, zoning, type of proposed sewer and water
