6-1-2: RESTRICTED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Vehicles: No person, other than authorized personnel, shall bring or
use any vehicle, including, but not limited to, motorcycles, motorbikes,
minibikes, or mopeds, upon any portion of any Village property except as
designated by the Superintendent of Parks. This subsection shall not apply to
Village rights of way. (1977 Code § 8-7-1)
   B.   Sales Of Merchandise: No person shall offer or exchange for sale any
article or thing, or do any hawking, peddling, or soliciting, or buy or offer
to buy any article or thing, or take up any collection, or solicit to receive
contributions of money or anything of value in any Village park or on any
Village right of way or on any other Village property, except in compliance
with title 3, chapter 2 of this code and only when authority to do so has been
granted by the Village Board of Trustees. (1977 Code § 8-7-2)
   C.   Public Meetings Or Assemblies: No person shall call or hold any public
meeting or assembly, or give any concert or public entertainment of any kind in
any Village park or on any Village right of way or on any other Village
property without the express consent of the Village Board of Trustees. (1977
Code § 8-7-3)
   D.   Fires: No person shall light or make use of any fire in any Village
park or on any Village right of way or road or on any other Village property,
except portable barbecue equipment or except in such portions thereof and at
such locations as may be indicated by the Superintendent of Parks for such
purposes and then only under such regulations as are prescribed by him. (1977
Code § 8-7-5)
   E.   Animals: It shall be unlawful to bring any animal into any Village park
or onto any other Village property without the expressed consent of the Park
Superintendent. (1977 Code § 8-7-12)
6-1-3: PERMIT TO USE VILLAGE PARKS:
   A.   Permit Required: All persons using any Village park shall be required
to have a permit which will be issued by the Village Clerk.
   B.   Registration Of Family Members; Vehicle Sticker Required: Each family
member shall be registered, and each car shall display a North Barrington
vehicle sticker.
   C.   Representative Of Civil And Social Groups: A permit will be issued to
the leader of each civic or social group.
   D.   Permit Fees:
 
Resident family                          Included in the vehicle sticker
Nonresident family                        $50.00
Cuba Township family                      25.00
Individual nonresident, age 62 or older   1.00
 
   E.   Term Of Permit: The period for which the permit is valid shall be the
same as that of the current vehicle sticker. (1977 Code § 8-7-13)
6-1-4: HOURS OF OPERATION OF VILLAGE PARKS:
All parks owned and controlled by the Village shall be open daily to the public
from sunrise to sunset. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than
authorized personnel conducting official business, to occupy or be present in
said parks during any hours which the parks are not open to the public. Any
section or part of parks may be declared closed to the public by the
Superintendent of Parks at any time, and for any interval of time, either
temporarily, or at a regularly stated time. (1977 Code § 8-7-10; amd. 2004
Code)
6-1-5: CLEANUP OF AREAS USED:
Each person, firm or corporation, or civic or social group using any Village
park or other Village property and grounds shall clean up all debris,
extinguish all fires when such are permitted and leave the premises in good
order and in a neat, sanitary condition. (1977 Code § 8-7-11)
6-1-6: VIOLATION; PENALTIES:
Any person, firm or corporation, or civic or social group who violates,
disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the
enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be fined a minimum of fifty dollars
($50.00) but not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
offense; provided, however, the minimum fine for any violation of subsection 6-
1-1A1, A2, B1 or C and section
6-1-5 of this chapter shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00). (1977 Code § 8-7-
14; amd. 2004 Code)
CHAPTER 2
ANIMALS
SECTION:
6-2-1: Prohibitions
6-2-2: Additional Prohibitions Involving Dogs
6-2-3: Dangerous, Vicious Animals
6-2-4: Animal Breeding Prohibited
6-2-5: Hunting And Trapping
6-2-6: Rabies Control
6-2-7: Impoundment And Redemption Provisions
6-2-8: Penalties
6-2-1: PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Cruelty: No person shall cruelly treat any animal in the Village in any
way. Any person who inhumanely beats, underfeeds, overloads, or abandons any
animal shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this code. (1977 Code §
8-1-1)
   B.   Noisy Animals: It shall be unlawful to harbor or keep any animal which
disturbs the peace by excessive and unwarranted noises at any time of the day
or night. (1977 Code § 8-1-4)
   C.   Diseased Animals 1 : No domestic animals afflicted with a contagious or
infectious disease shall be allowed to run at large or be exposed in any public
place whereby the health of human or beast may be affected, nor shall such
diseased animal be shipped or removed from the premises of the owner thereof,
except under the supervision of the Health Officer. (1977 Code § 8-1-6)
   D.   Livestock 2 :
      1.   Running At Large: It shall be unlawful to permit any cattle, horse,
swine, sheep, goats, or poultry to run at large in the Village. Any such animal
running at large in any public place in the Village shall be impounded in the
manner provided by this chapter.
      2.   Tying To Graze Or Feed: It shall be unlawful to picket or tie any
such animal in any of the streets of the Village for the purpose of grazing or
feeding. (1977 Code § 8-1-5)
   E.   Animal Houses; Certain Animals Prohibited 3 : No person shall cause or
allow any stable or place where any animal is or may be kept to become unclean
or unwholesome, and it shall be unlawful to keep any live goats, swine, pigs,
poultry or cattle in the Village except as provided in the zoning ordinance.
(1977 Code § 8-1-7)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 4-2-2B of this code.
2 2. See also subsection 6-2-1E of this chapter.
3 3. See also subsection 6-2-1D of this chapter.
6-2-2: ADDITIONAL PROHIBITIONS INVOLVING DOGS:
   A.   Running At Large: Every person who owns, keeps, or harbors a dog and
causes or permits such dog to run at large, other than on the premises of such
person, whereby off the premises of such person within the Village such dog
shall menace, pursue, chase, worry, wound, bite or kill a person or a domestic
animal or destroy or injure plant life or personal property, shall be guilty of
a violation of this chapter, and the offending animal is hereby declared a
public nuisance and shall be apprehended and impounded under the provisions of
this chapter.
   B.   Unattended Dogs: Every person who owns, keeps, or harbors a dog and
causes or permits such dog to be unattended, other than on the premises of such
person, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter, and said dog
shall be apprehended and impounded under the provisions of this chapter. It
shall be a defense to any such violation for the owner to show reasonable care,
and that the violation occurred by the nature of dog; however, any costs of
impounding shall be paid by the owner prior to the release of the dog so
impounded.
   C.   Failure To Remove Excrement: Every person who owns, keeps, or harbors a
dog and who shall fail to remove excrement deposited by his dog upon any
premises, public or private, other than the premises of such person, shall be
deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter.
   D.   Complaint Required: Subsections A, B, and C of this section are only in
effect if a formal complaint is filed with or by the law enforcement agency.
(1977 Code §
8-2-3; amd. 2004 Code)
6-2-3: DANGEROUS, VICIOUS ANIMALS:
   A.   Running At Large Prohibited; Permit For Parades: It shall be unlawful
to permit any dangerous animal or any vicious animal of any kind to run at
large within the Village. Exhibitions or parades of animals that are ferae
naturae in the eyes of the law may be conducted only upon securing a permit
from the law enforcement agency. (1977 Code §
8-1-2; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Authority To Kill Dangerous Animals:
      1.   The law enforcement officials or other authorized Village official
or employee is authorized to kill any dangerous animal of any kind when it is
necessary for the protection of any person or property. (1977 Code §
8-1-3; amd. 2004 Code)
      2.   It shall be lawful for the law enforcement officials or other
authorized Village official or employee to kill any vicious dog at large within
the limits of the Village which cannot safely be taken up and impounded. (1977
Code §
8-2-5; amd. 2004 Code)
6-2-4: ANIMAL BREEDING PROHIBITED:
The raising or breeding of animals including, but not limited to, dogs, cats
and other household pets, for the purpose of sale, trade or donation, or for
any commercial purpose, is hereby prohibited on any lot or adjoining lots
having a common owner; except, that not more than one litter of animals
otherwise permitted by this code shall be allowed in any household during any
twenty four (24) month period. (1977 Code § 8-1-8)
6-2-5: HUNTING AND TRAPPING:
   A.   Hunting Prohibited: Hunting by guns of any kind (including rifles,
shotguns, pistols, blowguns and air rifles) and by bows and arrows is hereby
prohibited within the Village 1 .
   B.   Trapping And Related Activities Prohibited:
      1.   It is unlawful for any person to place, set, use or maintain within
the Village a leghold trap or one of similar construction or a body gripping
trap or one of similar construction.
      2.   The use of humane cage, box or stovepipe type traps shall be
permitted, provided that:
         a.   It shall be unlawful to fail to visit and remove all animals from
such traps staked out, set, used, tendered, placed or maintained at least once
each calendar day.
         b.   It shall be unlawful to trap or attempt to trap within the
Village animals with any cage, box or stovepipe trap designed to take more than
one animal at a single setting.
      3.   It is unlawful to use, maintain or possess within the Village any
snare trap or snare like device, deadfall, net or pit trap to take any animal.
      4.   It is unlawful for any person to trap or allow a dog to hunt within
or upon the property of another within the Village, or upon waters flowing over
or standing on the land of another within the Village, without first obtaining
permission from the owner or occupant of the property.
      5.   It is unlawful to use spears, gigs, hooks or any like device to kill
or capture any animal within the Village.
      6.   It is unlawful to use poisons, chemicals, smoke or explosives to
kill or capture any animal within the Village.
      7.   It is unlawful to trap adjacent to or near any peat, grass, brush or
other flammable substance when it is burning within the Village.
      8.   It is unlawful to kill or capture, pursue or intentionally harass or
disturb in any manner any animal within the Village by the use of or with the
aid of any vehicle or conveyance.
      9.   Notwithstanding anything contained herein to the contrary, this
section shall not be construed to prohibit:
         a.   The killing or trapping by any means of any animal within the
Village by any law enforcement officer or other authorized employee of the
Village or county or state in the performance of their respective duties or by
any other person authorized by any such law enforcement officer or employee; or
         b.   The killing or trapping of by any means of rats, mice or other
vermin within any buildings; or
         c.   Fishing. (Ord. 1014, 9-22-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  6-3-6 of this title, discharging weapons prohibited.
6-2-6: RABIES CONTROL:
   A.   Inoculation Of Dogs Required: Every person who owns, keeps, or harbors
a dog four (4) months of age or older shall, each year, cause said dog to be
inoculated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian and provide the dog with a
collar or harness and attach thereto an official rabies vaccination tag which
shall be worn by the dog at all times. However, if the vaccine used is one
recognized for a three (3) year period of immunity and the dog is over twelve
(12) months of age at the time of inoculation, the interval between
inoculations may be extended to three (3) years. (1977 Code §
8-2-1)
   B.   Biting Animals:
      1.   Definition: "Has been bitten", as used in this chapter, means has
been seized with the teeth or jaws or scratched by the teeth or nails or
wounded or pierced, and includes contact of saliva with any break or abrasion
of the skin. (1977 Code §
8-2-2)
      2.   Procedure In Case Of Animal Bite:
         a.   Notice Of Animal Bite: Whenever any dog or other animal has
bitten a human, the owner of said dog or other animal shall immediately notify
the law enforcement officer who shall order the animal held on the owner's
premises for observation or shall have it impounded for a period of ten (10)
days commencing from twenty four (24) hours of the biting incident. (1977 Code
§
8-2-2; amd. 2004 Code)
         b.   Unvaccinated Animals: If any dog or cat is not currently
vaccinated against rabies, the animal will be impounded in accordance with
state statutes. The owner will then be liable for payment of an inoculation
fee, plus the cost of the animal's stay at the pound, and the owner will be
subject to court citation 1 .
         c.   Vaccinated Animals That Bite: The owner of a dog or cat currently
vaccinated against rabies may keep the animal at home under strict confinement
and away from the public, and may take his animal to a licensed veterinarian to
be examined on the first day, fifth day, and tenth day of a ten (10) day
observation period. If the dog or cat bites again during the confinement
period, it will be impounded for the full ten (10) day period commencing from
the date of the second bite. Owners not returning their animals for followup
examination on the appropriate dates will be in violation and subject to court
citation 2 . (1977 Code §
8-2-2)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  1-4-4 of this code.
2 2. See section
  1-4-4 of this code.
6-2-7: IMPOUNDMENT AND REDEMPTION PROVISIONS:
   A.   Authority To Impound:
      1.   The law enforcement officers or other authorized Village officials
or employees shall apprehend, impound or take other appropriate measures upon
any violation of this chapter in the presence of said officials or employees or
upon any written complaint alleging such violation.
      2.   The Village Health Officer or her designated representative is
authorized to take appropriate action to apprehend, impound and dispose of any
diseased dog or other animal to prevent the communication and spread of
contagion or infection.
   B.   Impoundment Procedures: The law enforcement officials shall arrange for
the impounding of each animal apprehended under the provisions of this chapter
and shall take reasonable measures to identify, locate and notify the owner of
any animal so impounded.
   C.   Redemption Procedures And Requirements: Unless it shall be necessary to
destroy any animal impounded under the provisions of this chapter, the owner or
keeper thereof shall be permitted to redeem such animal within ten (10)
business days of the date of apprehension by paying to the Village Clerk or his
designated representative all costs relative to the impounding and keeping of
said animal, including the cost of keeping said animal, the cost of
advertising, if any, and veterinary fees. If said animal has not been
inoculated for the prevention of rabies as required by state statute and the
provisions of this chapter, then, prior to the release of said animal, the
Village may require adequate proof that said inoculation shall be undertaken
promptly.
   D.   Disposal Of Unredeemed Animal: It shall be the duty of the poundkeeper
to humanely dispose of any animal impounded which is not redeemed from the
pound within ten (10) business days from date of apprehension. (1977 Code §
8-2-4; amd. 2004 Code)
6-2-8: PENALTIES 1 :
Any person convicted of violating the provisions of section
6-2-2,
6-2-6 or
6-2-7 of this chapter, or neglecting to comply with any of the provisions
thereof, shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1977 Code §
8-2-6; amd. 2004 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See section 1-4-4 of this code for citation provisions relative to dogs
  and cats.
CHAPTER 3
MISCELLANEOUS AND CRIMINAL OFFENSES
SECTION:
6-3-1: Illinois Criminal Code Adopted By Reference
6-3-2: Offenses Involving The Person
6-3-2-1: Assault, Battery, Fighting
6-3-2-2: Disorderly Conduct
6-3-2-3: Disturbing Assemblies
6-3-2-4: Unlawful Assemblies
6-3-3: Offenses Involving Property
6-3-3-1: Damage To Property
6-3-3-2: Trespassing
6-3-4: Offenses Involving Public Health And Safety
6-3-4-1: Throwing Missiles
6-3-4-2: Barbed Wire, Electric Fences
6-3-4-3: False Alarms
6-3-5: Offenses Involving Village Officers And Employees
6-3-5-1: Interference With Officers And Employees
6-3-5-2: Impersonating Officers And Employees
6-3-5-3: Resisting Arrest
6-3-6: Discharging Weapons
6-3-7: Responsibility For Minors
6-3-8: Penalties
6-3-1: ILLINOIS CRIMINAL CODE ADOPTED BY REFERENCE:
Except insofar as the application thereof is clearly impractical or
inappropriate, in view of the context of purposes or penalty as provided, all
of the definitions, requirements, regulations, prohibitions, provisions and
sections of the Illinois criminal code 1 , are hereby adopted by the Village.
Any and all violations thereof shall be considered violations of this chapter,
and each such violation shall subject the violator thereof to penalty
provisions under this code if proceeded hereunder. (2004 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.
6-3-2: OFFENSES INVOLVING THE PERSON:
6-3-2-1: ASSAULT, BATTERY, FIGHTING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any assault or battery or to
fight in any public place in the Village. (1977 Code §
8-6-2)
6-3-2-2: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
A person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly:
   A.   Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to provoke, make or aid in
making a breach of the peace; or
   B.   Does or makes any unreasonable or offensive act, utterance, gesture or
display which, under the circumstances, creates a clear and present danger of a
breach of the peace or imminent threat of violence; or (1977 Code §
8-6-7)
   C.   Refuses or fails to cease and desist any peaceful conduct or activity
likely to produce a breach of the peace where there is an imminent threat of
violence and where the law enforcement officials have made all reasonable
efforts to protect the otherwise peaceful conduct and activity and have
requested that said conduct and activity be stopped and explained the request
if there is time; or (1977 Code §
8-6-7; amd. 2004 Code)
   D.   Fails to obey a lawful order of dispersal by a person known by him to
be a peace officer under circumstances where three (3) or more persons are
committing acts of disorderly conduct in the immediate vicinity, which acts are
likely to cause substantial harm or serious inconvenience, annoyance or alarm;
or
   E.   Assembles with three (3) or more persons for the purpose of using force
or violence to disturb the public peace; or
   F.   Appeals in any public place manifestly under the influence of alcohol,
narcotics or other drugs, not therapeutically administered, to the degree that
he may endanger himself or other persons or property, or annoy persons in his
vicinity; or
   G.   Carries in a threatening or menacing manner, without authority of law,
any pistol, revolver, dagger, razor, dangerous knife, stiletto, knuckles,
slingshot, an object containing noxious or deleterious liquid, gas or substance
or other dangerous weapon or conceals said weapon on or about the person or any
vehicle 1 ; or
   H.   Trespasses on the property of another 2 ; or
   I.   Is on any Village, school district, park district, county or state
property without permission or in violation of the rules and regulations of the
Village, school district, park district, county or state, or is loitering on
any publicly dedicated street adjacent to the Village, school district, park
district, county or state property. (1977 Code §
8-6-7)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  6-3-6 of this chapter for discharging weapons.
2 2. See also section
  6-3-3-2 of this chapter.
6-3-2-3: DISTURBING ASSEMBLIES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any lawful assemblage or
gathering in the Village. (1977 Code §
8-6-9)
6-3-2-4: UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLIES:
It shall be unlawful to collect, gather, or be a member of any disorderly
crowd, or any crowd gathered together for any unlawful purpose. (1977 Code §
8-6-10)
6-3-3: OFFENSES INVOLVING PROPERTY:
6-3-3-1: DAMAGE TO PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for anyone to wilfully or maliciously injure, deface,
destroy or interfere with any property belonging to the Village, other
governmental body, or any private person. (1977 Code § 8-6-15)
6-3-3-2: TRESPASSING 1 :
   A.   Trespassing Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation to commit a trespass within the Village upon either public or
private property. (1977 Code §
8-5-1)
   B.   Definition; Prevention: Without constituting any limitation upon the
provisions of subsection A of this section, any of the following acts by any
person, firm or corporation shall be deemed to constitute trespasses in
violation of the provisions of said subsection A, and appropriate action may be
taken hereunder at any time, or from time to time, to prevent or suppress any
violation or violations of this section: (1977 Code §
8-5-2)
      1.   An entry upon the premises, or any part thereof, of another,
including any public property, in violation of a notice posted or exhibited at
the main entrance to said premises or at any point of approach or entry or in
violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in writing, by any
owners or occupant thereof or by a law enforcement official; or
      2.   The pursuit of a course of conduct or action incidental to the
making of any entry upon the land of another in violation of a notice posted or
exhibited at the main entrance to said premises or at any point of approach or
entry, or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in
writing by any owners or occupant thereof or by a law enforcement official; or
      3.   A failure or refusal to depart from the premises of another in case
of being requested, either orally or in writing, to leave by any owners or
occupant thereof, or by a law enforcement official. (1977 Code §
8-5-2; amd. 2004 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 6-3-2-2H of this chapter.
6-3-4: OFFENSES INVOLVING PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY:
6-3-4-1: THROWING MISSILES:
It shall be unlawful to cast, throw or propel any missile on any street, alley
or public place; it shall be unlawful to throw or deposit any glass, nails,
tacks or other similar articles on any street, alley, sidewalk or other public
place in the Village. (1977 Code §
8-6-3)
6-3-4-2: BARBED WIRE, ELECTRIC FENCES:
It shall be unlawful to maintain or construct any fence composed in whole or
part of barbed wire, or with any similar materials designed to cause injury to
any person, or any wire charged with electrical current within the Village,
except:
   A.   Where such fence is used for containment of livestock in approved
areas; and
   B.   That two (2) strands of barbed wire may be used in conjunction with a
permissible open fence constructed for security purposes on property zoned R-
1 as defined in the zoning ordinance of the Village. (1977 Code §
8-6-6)
6-3-4-3: FALSE ALARMS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly start or spread any false
alarm of fire or false call for assistance from the law enforcement agency.
(1977 Code § 8-6-11; amd. 2004 Code)
6-3-5: OFFENSES INVOLVING VILLAGE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
6-3-5-1: INTERFERENCE WITH OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
It shall be unlawful to interfere with or hinder any officer or employee of the
Village while engaged in the duties of his office or employment. (1977 Code §
8-6-12)
6-3-5-2: IMPERSONATING OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to impersonate without lawful authority any
Village officer or employee. (1977 Code § 8-6-13)
6-3-5-3: RESISTING ARREST:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use force to resist an arrest which he
knows is being made either by a peace officer or by a private person summoned
and directed by a peace officer to make the arrest, even if he believes that
the arrest is unlawful and the arrest in fact is unlawful. (1977 Code § 8-6-14)
6-3-6: DISCHARGING WEAPONS 1 :
   A.   Discharge Prohibited: No person shall discharge or set off a rifle of
any type, make or description within the Village, and no person shall discharge
or set off any shotgun, pistol, revolver, or any other gun or device that
discharges projectiles by explosive substance, by air or gas compression or by
mechanical means, including air guns, within the Village. (1977 Code §
8-3-1)
   B.   Exemptions: The provisions of this section shall not apply to sheriffs,
coroners, constables, members of the law enforcement agency, or other peace
officers engaged in the discharge of their official duties, or to any person
summoned by any such officers to assist in making arrests or preserving the
peace while such person so summoned is engaged in assisting such officer, or to
any person acting in the lawful defense of any person or property. (1977 Code §
8-3-2; amd. 2004 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection 6-3-2-2G of this chapter for additional weapons
  regulations; see subsection 6-2-6A of this title, hunting prohibited.
6-3-7: RESPONSIBILITY FOR MINORS:
   A.   Definitions: As used in this section, the following words and terms
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection:
LEGAL GUARDIAN: A person appointed guardian or given custody of a minor by a
circuit court of the state, but does not include a person appointed guardian or
given custody of a minor under the juvenile court act 2 .
MINOR: A person who is above the age of eleven (11) years but not yet eighteen
(18) years of age. (1977 Code § 8-6-16; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Responsibility For Minors:
      1.   In the absence of evidence to the contrary, the parent or legal
guardian of an unemancipated minor residing with such parent or legal guardian
shall be presumed to have failed to exercise proper parental responsibility,
and said minor shall be deemed to have acted with the knowledge and permission
of the parent or guardian in violation of this code, whenever such minor shall:
         a.   Be adjudicated to be in violation of any ordinance, law or
statute prohibiting wilful or malicious acts causing injury to a person or
property; or
         b.   Have incurred nonjudicial sanctions from another governmental
agency resulting from an admission of guilt or violation of any ordinance, law
or statute which prohibits wilful or malicious acts causing injury to a person
or property. (1977 Code § 8-6-16)
      2.   However, said parent or legal guardian shall first receive from the
law enforcement official or other authorized Village official a written notice
following said minor's adjudication or nonjudicial sanction, by registered or
certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service, and the acts
of said minor in violation of any ordinance, law or statute prohibiting wilful
or malicious acts causing injury to a person or property which cause such
presumption of failure to exercise proper parental responsibility shall have
occurred within one year following receipt of said written notice. (1977 Code §
8-6-16; amd. 2004 Code)
 
Notes
2 2. 705 ILCS 405/1-1 et seq.
6-3-8: PENALTIES:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter, including any parent who
has failed to exercise proper parental responsibility as provided for herein,
shall pay the actual damages resulting therefrom, but not exceeding two
thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), the limit provided by 740 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 115/5, the parental responsibility law, and, in addition,
shall be fined as provided herein. (1977 Code § 8-6-16; amd. 2004 Code)
CHAPTER 4
FIREWORKS
SECTION:
6-4-1: Definitions
6-4-2: Pyrotechnic Displays
6-4-3: Application
6-4-4: Prohibition
6-4-5: Penalty
6-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
Terms used in this Chapter 4 are defined as follows:
ACT: The Pyrotechnic Distributor and Operator Licensing Act, 225 ILCS 227/1 et
seq.
BATFE: The federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms Enforcement.
CONSUMER FIREWORKS DISPLAY (OR CONSUMER DISPLAY): The detonation, ignition or
deflagration or consumer fireworks to produce a visual or audible effect.
CONSUMER FIREWORKS: Those fireworks that must comply with the construction,
chemical composition and labeling regulations of the U.S. Consumer Products
Safety Commission, as set forth in 16 C.F.R. Parts 1500 and 1507 and classified
as fireworks UN0336 or UN0337 by the U.S. Department of Transportation under 49
C.F.R. 172.101. Consumer fireworks do not include snake or glow work pellets;
smoke devices; trick noisemakers known as "party poppers," "booby traps,"
"snappers," "trick matches" and "cigarette loads;" auto burglar alarms;
sparklers; toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns or other devices in which paper or
plastic caps containing twenty-five hundredths grains or less of explosive
compound are used, provided they are so constructed that the hand cannot come
in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion; and toy pistol paper
or plastic caps that contain less than twenty hundredths grains of explosive
mixture; the same and use of which shall be permitted at all times.
LEAD PYROTECHNIC OPERATOR: The individual with overall responsibility for the
safety, setup, discharge and supervision of a pyrotechnic display.
PYROTECHNIC DISPLAY: The detonation, ignition or deflagration of display
fireworks or flame effects to produce the visual or audible effect of an
exhibitional nature before the public, invitees or licensees, regardless of
whether admission is charged. (Ord. 2020-21, 6-17-2020)
6-4-2: PYROTECHNIC DISPLAYS:
   A.   No pyrotechnic display shall be conducted in the Village without a
pyrotechnic display permit issued by the Board of Trustees. Such permit shall
not be issued to any person who is not licensed under the Act as a lead
pyrotechnic operator supervising the display. Such pyrotechnic display shall be
conducted in accordance with the Act and its administrative rules (41 Ill.
Admin Code 235).
   B.   All pyrotechnic displays permitted in the Village shall be performed in
compliance with the rules and regulations adopted by the Office of the State
Fire Marshall and in accordance with the Act and the Fireworks Use Act (425
ILCS 35/1 et seq.). (Ord. 2020-21, 6-17-2020)
6-4-3: APPLICATION:
   A.   At least twenty (20) business days prior to the pyrotechnic display
being conducted, the lead pyrotechnic operator shall apply for a permit from
the Village, which shall be in writing and signed by the applicant. The
application and the following documents shall be submitted to the Village for
approval by the Board of Trustees:
      1.   A current BATFE license for distribution of display fireworks;
      2.   Proof of a current United States Department of Transportation
(USDOT) Identification Number;
      3.   Proof of a current USDOT Hazardous Materials Registration Number;
and
      4.   Proof of insurance coverage for General Liability of one million
dollars ($1,000,000) per occurrence with a two million dollar ($2,000,000)
aggregate, an additional one million dollar ($1,000,000) excess umbrella
policy, Worker's Compensation with statutory levels and employer's liability of
five hundred thousand ($500,000) per occurrence. All Certificates of Insurance
must have the Village of North Barrington listed as an additional insured.
      5.   Application fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
   B.   The Board of Trustees may waive the permit fee for not-for-profit
entities.
   C.   Prior to the issuance of any permits, the full submittal package shall
be forwarded for review and approved by the Fire Commissioner and the fire
protection district that has jurisdiction where the display will be conducted.
(Ord. 2020-21, 6-17-2020)
6-4-4: PROHIBITION:
No person shall sell, offer for sale, possess, use or explode any illegal
fireworks as defined in the State Fire Marshal Code. In addition, consumer
displays are prohibited. (Ord. 2020-21, 6-17-2020)
6-4-5: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this Chapter
4 shall be subject to a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750) per violation plus court
costs. Each day that such violation exists shall constitute a separate and
distinct offense.
   B.   In addition to any other applicable penalty, any person, firm, co-
partnership or corporation who violates any pyrotechnic display permit shall
not be entitled to apply for a pyrotechnic display permit during the remainder
of the year in which the violation occurred and during the ensuing calendar
year. (Ord. 2020-21, 6-17-2020)
TITLE 7
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
CHAPTER 1
VEHICLE CODE

7-1-2: Amendments To Code

CHAPTER 3
GENERAL TRAFFIC REGULATIONS; DRIVING RULES
SECTION:
7-3-1: Application Of Provisions
7-3-2: Authority To Direct Traffic
7-3-3: Obedience To, Eluding Law Enforcement Officials
7-3-4: Fire Department Vehicles
7-3-5: Obstructing Traffic And Public Ways
7-3-6: Right Of Way
7-3-7: Speed Restrictions
7-3-8: Funeral And Other Processions
7-3-9: Clinging To Moving Vehicles
7-3-10: Transporting Alcoholic Liquor
7-3-11: Unlawful Use Of Or Damage To Highways
7-3-12: Display Of State Registration Plates
7-3-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this title applicable to the drivers of vehicles upon the
highways shall apply to the drivers of all vehicles owned or operated by the
United States, the state, the Village or any county, city, town, district or
any other political subdivision of the state, except as provided in this title
and subject to such specific exceptions as set forth in this title with
reference to authorized emergency vehicles. (1977 Code §
10-10-1)
7-3-2: AUTHORITY TO DIRECT TRAFFIC:
   A.   Law Enforcement Agency: Law enforcement officials, or such authorized
officers or crossing guards as are assigned or authorized by the law
enforcement agency, are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand,
or signal in conformance with traffic laws and regulations; provided, that in
the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard
pedestrians, law enforcement officials may direct traffic as conditions may
require, notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws and regulations.
   B.   Fire Department: Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of
a fire, may direct or assist the law enforcement officials in directing traffic
thereat or in the immediate vicinity.
   C.   Unauthorized Persons: It shall be unlawful for any person not
authorized by the law enforcement agency to direct or attempt to direct
traffic. (1977 Code § 10-8-7; amd. 2004 Code)
7-3-3: OBEDIENCE TO, ELUDING LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS:
   A.   Obedience To Law Enforcement Officials: No person shall wilfully fail
or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of any law enforcement
official invested by law with authority to direct, control or regulate traffic.
(1977 Code §
10-10-1; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Fleeing, Attempting To Elude Law Enforcement Officials:
      1.   Fleeing, Attempting To Elude Prohibited: Any driver or operator of a
motor vehicle who, having been given a visual or audible signal by a law
enforcement official directing such driver or operator to bring his vehicle to
a stop, wilfully fails or refuses to obey such direction, increases his speed,
extinguishes his lights, or otherwise flees or attempts to elude the official,
is guilty of a violation of this code. The signal given by the law enforcement
official may be by hand, voice, siren, or red or blue light; provided, the
official giving such signal shall be in police uniform, and, if driving a
vehicle, such vehicle shall be marked showing it to be an official vehicle of
the law enforcement agency. (1977 Code §
10-10-3; amd. 2004 Code)
      2.   Suspension Of Driver's License: Upon receiving notice of such
conviction, the secretary of state may forthwith suspend the driver's license
of the person so convicted for a period of not more than six (6) months. (1977
Code §
10-10-3)
7-3-4: FIRE DEPARTMENT VEHICLES:
   A.   Following Or Parking Near Fire Apparatus: The driver of any vehicle
other than one on official business shall not follow any fire apparatus
traveling in response to a fire alarm closer than five hundred feet (500') or
drive into or park such vehicle within the block where fire apparatus has
stopped in answer to a fire alarm. (1977 Code § 10-10-9)
   B.   Driving Over Fire Hose: No vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected
hose of a fire department when laid down on any street, private road or
driveway to be used at any fire or alarm of fire, without the consent of the
fire department official in command. (1977 Code § 10-10-10)
7-3-5: OBSTRUCTING TRAFFIC AND PUBLIC WAYS:
   A.   Village Jurisdiction: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or
corporation to cause, create or maintain any obstruction of any street or other
public way under the jurisdiction of the Village, except as may be specifically
authorized by ordinance or by the Superintendent of Roads.
   B.   State Jurisdiction: No obstruction or encroachment upon any street or
highway under the jurisdiction of the state shall be permitted except as
specifically authorized by the state and the Village Board of Trustees. The
Board of Trustees will cooperate in a reasonable manner with the state in
disposing of any existing encroachments within the Village. (1977 Code § 10-10-
12)
   C.   Violations: Any person who shall wilfully and unnecessarily hinder,
obstruct or delay, or who shall wilfully and unnecessarily attempt to delay,
hinder or obstruct any other person in lawfully driving or traveling along or
upon any street or who shall offer for barter or sale merchandise on said
street so as to interfere with the effective movement of traffic shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor. (1977 Code § 10-10-7)
7-3-6: RIGHT OF WAY:
   A.   Preferential Right Of Way: Preferential right of way at an intersection
may be indicated by stop or yield signs. (1977 Code § 10-3-9)
   B.   Stop Intersections: Except when directed to proceed by a law
enforcement officer or traffic control signal, every driver of a vehicle
approaching a stop intersection indicated by a stop sign shall stop at a
clearly marked stop line, but if none, before entering the crosswalk on the
near side of the intersection, or if none, then at the point nearest the
intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the
intersecting roadway before entering the intersection. After having stopped,
the driver shall yield the right of way to any vehicle which has entered the
intersection from another roadway or which is approaching so closely on the
roadway as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time when the driver is
moving across or within the intersection, but said driver having so yielded may
proceed at such time as a safe interval occurs. (1977 Code § 10-3-9; amd. 2004
Code)
   C.   Yield Right Of Way Intersections:
      1.   The driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign shall, in obedience
to such sign, slow to a speed reasonable for the existing conditions and, if
required for safety to stop, shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if
none, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or if
none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a
view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway. After slowing or
stopping, the driver shall yield the right of way to any vehicle in the
intersection or approaching on another roadway so closely as to constitute an
immediate hazard during the time such driver is moving across or within the
intersection. (1977 Code § 10-3-9)
      2.   If a driver is involved in a collision or interferes with the
movement of other vehicles at an intersection which is controlled by a yield
right of way sign, such collision or interference shall be deemed prima facie
evidence of the driver's failure to yield the right of way. (1977 Code § 10-3-
9; amd. 2004 Code)
7-3-7: SPEED RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Speed Limits Established:
      1.   Findings: The Village President and Board of Trustees have
determined that the basic statutory vehicular speed limits established by 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-601 are greater than that considered reasonable
and proper on all interior roads, streets and highways within the Village (with
the exception of Old Barrington Road and Timberlake Road) over which the
Village has maintenance responsibility and which are under the jurisdiction of
the Village and not under the jurisdiction of the Illinois department of
transportation or of Lake County.
      2.   Speed Limits Established:
         a.   Streets Generally: The Village President and Board of Trustees
have caused to be made an engineering and traffic investigation upon the
aforesaid roads, streets and highways, and by virtue of 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-604 and upon review of the supported data and findings of the
engineering and traffic investigation, has determined and hereby declares that
the reasonable, safe and proper absolute speed limit upon all interior roads,
streets, and highways within the Village (with the exception of Old Barrington
Road and Timberlake Road) over which the Village has maintenance and which are
under the jurisdiction of the Village and not under the jurisdiction of the
Illinois department of transportation or of Lake County shall be and is hereby
established at twenty five (25) miles per hour.
         b.   Timberlake Road: Pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-
604 and upon review of the supporting data and findings of the engineering and
traffic investigation, the maximum speed limits on those portions of Timberlake
Road lying within the Village limits over which the Village has maintenance and
which is under the jurisdiction of the Village and not under the jurisdiction
of the Illinois department of transportation or the Lake County department of
transportation shall be and hereby is established at thirty (30) miles per
hour.
         c.   Old Barrington Road: Pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-604 and upon review of the supporting data and findings of the engineering
and traffic investigation, the maximum speed limits on those portions of Old
Barrington Road lying within the Village limits over which the Village has
maintenance responsibility and which are under the jurisdiction of the Village
and not under the jurisdiction of the Illinois department of transportation or
of Lake County shall be thirty five (35) miles per hour. (1977 Code §
10-6-1; amd. 2004 Code)
         d.   School Zones: No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in
excess of twenty (20) miles per hour while passing a school zone or while
traveling upon any public thoroughfare on or across which children pass going
to and from school during school days when school children are present. School
zones shall be designated by resolution of the Village President and Board of
Trustees. (1977 Code §
10-6-2)
      3.   Signs Posted: The Superintendent of Roads shall cause signs to be
erected, giving notice of the aforesaid maximum speed limits, in conformance
with the standards and specifications contained in the Illinois manual of
uniform traffic control devices for streets and highways. (1977 Code §
10-6-1)
   B.   Minimum Speed:
      1.   No person shall drive a motor vehicle at such a slow speed as to
impede or block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic except when
reduced speed is necessary for safe operation of his vehicle or in compliance
with law.
      2.   Whenever the Village determines, upon the basis of an engineering
and traffic investigation concerning a highway or street under its
jurisdiction, that slow vehicle speeds along any part or zone of such highway
or street consistently impede the normal and reasonable movement of traffic,
the Village may determine and declare by proper regulation or ordinance a
minimum speed limit below which no person shall drive except when necessary for
safe operation of his vehicle or in compliance with the law. A limit so
determined and declared becomes effective when appropriate signs giving notice
of the limit are erected along such part or zone of the highway or street.
(1977 Code §
10-6-3)
7-3-8: FUNERAL AND OTHER PROCESSIONS:
   A.   Driving Through Processions: No operator of a vehicle shall drive
between the vehicles of persons comprising a funeral or other authorized
procession except when so directed by a police officer. This provision shall
not apply to "authorized emergency vehicles" as defined per section
7-1-1 of this title.
   B.   Funeral Processions:
      1.   Drivers In A Procession: Each driver in a funeral procession shall
drive as near to the right hand edge of the roadway as practicable and shall
follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practicable and safe.
      2.   Vehicles To Be Identified: All motor vehicles participating in a
funeral procession, when proceeding to any place of burial, shall display
illuminated headlamps thereon. (1977 Code § 10-10-8)
      3.   Right Of Way: All motor vehicles so designated shall have the right
of way over all other vehicles, except authorized emergency vehicles, at any
street or highway intersections within the Village and may proceed through stop
streets or signalized intersections with proper caution and safety. (1977 Code
§ 10-10-8; amd. 2004 Code)
7-3-9: CLINGING TO MOVING VEHICLES:
Any person riding upon any bicycle, motorcycle, motor driven cycle, coaster,
sled, roller skates, or any toy vehicle shall not attach the same or himself to
any moving vehicle upon any street or roadway. (1977 Code §
10-10-5)
7-3-10: TRANSPORTING ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR:
No person shall transport, carry, possess or have any alcoholic liquor in or
upon or about any motor vehicle except in the original package with the seal
unbroken. (1977 Code §
10-10-2)
7-3-11: UNLAWFUL USE OF OR DAMAGE TO HIGHWAYS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or damage any public highway or
street or any bridge, culvert, sign, signpost, or structure upon or used or
constructed in connection with any public highway or street for the protection
thereof or for protection or regulation of traffic thereon by any unusual,
improper or unreasonable use thereof, or by carelessly driving or using any
vehicle thereon, or by mutilating, defacing or destruction thereof. (1977 Code
§ 10-10-11; amd. 2004 Code)
7-3-12: DISPLAY OF STATE REGISTRATION PLATES:
State registration plates issued for a motor vehicle shall be attached thereto,
as provided by statute. Every such registration plate shall at all times be:
   A.   Securely fastened in a horizontal position to the vehicle for which it
is issued so as to prevent the plate from swinging.
   B.   Fastened in a place and position to be clearly visible.
   C.   Maintained free from foreign materials and in a condition to be clearly
legible. (1977 Code §
10-10-4)
CHAPTER 4
TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKINGS
SECTION:
7-4-1: Specifications For Traffic Control Devices; Official Devices
7-4-2: Installation And Maintenance Of Traffic Control Devices
7-4-3: Obedience To Traffic Control Devices
7-4-4: Marking And Use Of Traffic Lanes
7-4-5: Designation Of Crosswalks And Safety Zones
7-4-6: Unauthorized Signs, Signals, Markings And Advertisements
7-4-7: Damage To, Interference With Devices
7-4-8: Effect Of Traffic Control Devices On Enforcement
7-4-1: SPECIFICATIONS FOR TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES; OFFICIAL DEVICES:
   A.   State Specifications To Apply: All traffic control signs, signals and
devices shall conform to the "Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices and
Specifications" approved by the state department of transportation. (1977 Code
§
10-8-2; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Uniformity: All signs and signals required hereunder for a particular
purpose shall, so far as practicable, be uniform as to type and location
throughout the Village.
   C.   Official Traffic Control Devices: All traffic control devices so
erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this title
shall be official traffic control devices. (1977 Code §
10-8-2)
7-4-2: INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE OF TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
The Superintendent of Roads shall place and maintain traffic control signs,
signals, and devices when and as required under the traffic regulations of the
Village to make effective the provisions of said regulations and, with the
concurrence of the Village Board of Trustees, may place and maintain such
additional traffic control devices as he may deem necessary and as may be
authorized by the Village Board of Trustees to regulate traffic under the
traffic regulations of the Village, under state law, or to guide or warn
traffic. (1977 Code §
10-8-1)
7-4-3: OBEDIENCE TO TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES:
   A.   Obedience Required: Every person shall obey the instructions of any
official traffic control device thereto placed in accordance with this chapter,
unless otherwise directed by a law enforcement official, subject to the
exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle in this title.
(1977 Code §
10-8-3; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Avoiding Traffic Control Devices Prohibited: It is unlawful for any
person to leave the roadway and travel across private property to avoid an
official traffic control device. (1977 Code §
10-8-3)
7-4-4: MARKING AND USE OF TRAFFIC LANES:
The Superintendent of Roads is hereby authorized to mark traffic lanes upon the
roadway whenever, in his opinion, a regular alignment of traffic is necessary,
and said markings shall conform to the manual for uniform traffic control
devices. Whenever any roadway has been divided into two (2) or more clearly
marked lanes for traffic, the following rules, in addition to all others
consistent herewith, shall apply: (1977 Code § 10-8-8; amd. 2004 Code)
   A.   A vehicle shall be driven as nearly as practicable entirely within a
single lane and shall not be moved from such lane until the driver has first
ascertained that such movement can be made with safety.
   B.   Upon a roadway which is divided into three (3) lanes and provides for
two way movement of traffic, a vehicle shall not be driven in the center lane
except when overtaking and passing another vehicle traveling in the same
direction when such center lane is clear of traffic within a safe distance, or
in preparation for making a left turn or where such center lane is at the time
allocated exclusively to traffic moving in the same direction that the vehicle
is proceeding and such location is so designated by official traffic control
devices.
   C.   Official traffic control devices may be erected directing specific
traffic to use a designated lane or designating those lanes to be used by
traffic moving in a particular direction regardless of the center of the
roadway, and drivers of vehicles shall obey the directions of every such sign.
   D.   Official traffic control devices may be installed prohibiting the
changing of lanes on sections of roadways, and drivers of vehicles shall obey
the directions of every such device. (1977 Code § 10-8-8)
7-4-5: DESIGNATION OF CROSSWALKS AND SAFETY ZONES:
The Superintendent of Roads is hereby authorized, in conformance with the
manual for uniform traffic control devices: (1977 Code §
10-8-6; amd. 2004 Code)
   A.   Crosswalks: To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or
lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where, in
his opinion, there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway and
at such other places as he may deem necessary.
   B.   Safety Zones: To establish safety zones upon resolution of the Village
board of trustees of such kind and character and at such places as they may
deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. (1977 Code §
10-8-6)
7-4-6: UNAUTHORIZED SIGNS, SIGNALS, MARKINGS AND ADVERTISEMENTS:
   A.   Unauthorized Signs, Signals And Markings: No person shall place,
maintain or display upon or in view of any street any unauthorized sign,
signal, marking, or device which purports to be or is an imitation of or
resembles an official traffic control device or which attempts to direct the
movement of traffic, nor shall any person place, maintain, or display upon or
in view of any street any other sign which hides from view or interferes with
the movement of traffic or the effectiveness of any traffic control device.
   B.   Advertising On Traffic Signs Prohibited: No person may place or
maintain nor shall the Village permit upon any street any traffic sign or
signal bearing thereon any commercial advertising.
   C.   Nuisance Declared: Every such prohibited sign, signal or marking is a
public nuisance, and the Superintendent of Roads is empowered to remove the
same or cause it to be removed without notice. (1977 Code §
10-8-4)
7-4-7: DAMAGE TO, INTERFERENCE WITH DEVICES:
No person shall, without lawful authority, attempt to or in fact alter, injure,
knock down, or remove any official traffic control device. (1977 Code §
10-8-5)
7-4-8: EFFECT OF TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES ON ENFORCEMENT:
No provision of this chapter for which official traffic control devices are
required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if, at the time and
place of the alleged violation, an official device is not in proper position
and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever
a particular section does not state that official traffic control devices are
required, such section shall be effective even though no devices are erected or
in place. (1977 Code §
10-8-3)
CHAPTER 5
PARKING REGULATIONS 1
SECTION:
7-5-1: Application Of Provisions
7-5-2: Authority Of Superintendent Of Roads
7-5-3: Parking Prohibited In Certain Places
7-5-4: Overnight Parking Prohibited
7-5-5: Manner Of Parking
7-5-6: Duty Of Driver Upon Parking
7-5-7: Moving, Starting Parked Vehicle
7-5-8: Use Of Lights On Parked Vehicles
7-5-9: Obedience To Signs
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  1-4-4 of this code for citation provisions.
7-5-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of any regulation prohibiting the stopping, standing or parking
of vehicles shall apply at all times or at those times therein specified or as
indicated on official signs, except where it is necessary to stop a vehicle to
avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a law
enforcement officer or official traffic control device. (1977 Code §
10-7-1; amd. 2004 Code)
7-5-2: AUTHORITY OF SUPERINTENDENT OF ROADS:
   A.   The Superintendent of Roads is authorized, subject to the approval of
the board of trustees by resolution, to determine and designate those streets
or parts of streets upon which parking shall be prohibited or upon which
parking shall be prohibited on one side only, and he shall cause to be erected
appropriate signs giving notice thereof.
   B.   The Superintendent of Roads is hereby authorized, subject to the
approval of the board of trustees by resolution, to determine and designate
streets or parts of streets upon which stopping, standing or parking shall be
prohibited within certain hours or permitted for a limited time, and he shall
cause to be erected and maintained appropriate signs giving notice thereof.
(1977 Code § 10-7-6; amd. 2004 Code)
7-5-3: PARKING PROHIBITED IN CERTAIN PLACES:
No person shall park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with
other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a law enforcement officer
or traffic control device, in any of the following places: (1977 Code §
10-7-4; amd. 2004 Code)
   A.   In front of a public or private driveway.
   B.   Within an intersection.
   C.   Within twenty feet (20') of an intersection.
   D.   Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop
sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway.
   E.   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such
parking would obstruct traffic.
   F.   On the roadway side of any vehicle parked at the edge of a street 1 .
   G.   Upon any street within twenty feet (20') of any mailbox designed and
arranged to permit deposit of mail from vehicles.
   H.   At any place where official signs prohibit parking. (1977 Code §
10-7-4)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 7-5-5B2 of this chapter.
7-5-4: OVERNIGHT PARKING PROHIBITED:
In addition to any other restrictions now or hereafter imposed, it shall be
unlawful to park any vehicle on any street, alley or public right of way within
the Village between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00)
A.M., except upon approval of the Superintendent of Roads. Whenever any vehicle
shall have been parked in violation of this section, the person in whose name
such vehicle is registered shall be prima facie responsible for such violation
and subject to the penalty therefor; provided, however, no person who is the
lessor of a vehicle pursuant to a written lease agreement shall be liable for
the violation of any ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking involving
such vehicle during the period of the lease unless such lessor fails to provide
the name, address, and driver's license number of the lessee within forty five
(45) days of receipt by such lessor of a request by the Village for such
information made within ninety (90) days after the violation occurred. (1977
Code § 10-7-9; amd. 2004 Code)
7-5-5: MANNER OF PARKING:
   A.   Parallel And Angle Parking: No person shall stand or park a vehicle in
a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the
direction of lawful traffic movement and with the curbside wheels of the
vehicle within twelve inches (12") of the curb or edge of the roadway, except
as otherwise provided in this chapter; provided, that where a street has been
marked for angle parking by direction of the President and Board of Trustees,
cars shall be parked at the angle indicated by such marks and within the
boundaries designated by such marks.
   B.   Prohibitions:
      1.   No person shall park any vehicle on a street in such a manner or
under such conditions as to leave available less than fifteen feet (15') of the
width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic, except on a one
way street.
      2.   Double parking is prohibited 1 . (1977 Code §
10-7-2)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 7-5-3F of this chapter.
7-5-6: DUTY OF DRIVER UPON PARKING:
   A.   Leaving Vehicles Unattended, Procedures: No person driving or in charge
of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping
the engine and removing the ignition key and, when standing on any perceptible
grade, without effectively setting the brake and turning the front wheels away
from the curb when parking up grade and toward the curb when parking down
grade.
   B.   Opening Doors Into Traffic: No person shall open the door of a vehicle
on the side available to moving traffic unless and until it is reasonably safe
to do so, and can be done without interfering with the movement of other
traffic, nor shall any person leave a door open on the side of a vehicle
available to moving traffic for a period of time longer than necessary to load
or unload passengers. (1977 Code § 10-7-8)
7-5-7: MOVING, STARTING PARKED VEHICLE:
   A.   Safe Conditions Required: No person shall start to move a vehicle which
is stopped, standing, or parked unless and until such movement can be made with
reasonable safety. (1977 Code § 10-7-8)
   B.   Authority To Move And Start: No person other than a law enforcement
official, as provided in section
7-10A-1 of this title, shall move a vehicle into any prohibited area or away
from the road edge such distance as is unlawful, or start or cause to be
started the motor of any motor vehicle, or shift, change, or move the levers,
brake, starting device, gears, or other mechanism of a parked motor vehicle to
a position other than that in which it was left by the owner or driver thereof,
or attempt to do so. (1977 Code § 10-7-6; amd. 2004 Code)
7-5-8: USE OF LIGHTS ON PARKED VEHICLES:
   A.   Lighted Streets: Whenever a vehicle is lawfully parked at nighttime
upon any lighted street within a business or residence district, no lights need
to be displayed upon such parked vehicle.
   B.   Streets With No Lighting: During the period from sunset to sunrise,
every motorcycle or motor vehicle which is standing on any street, other than
as provided in subsection A of this section, shall display a parking light on
the front and at the rear of same.
   C.   Lights To Be Dimmed: Any lighted driving lamps upon a parked vehicle
shall be depressed or dimmed. (1977 Code §
10-7-3)
7-5-9: OBEDIENCE TO SIGNS:
Where signs have been erected upon any street as authorized herein indicating
that parking is prohibited during designated hours or prohibited for a longer
time than is designated, no person shall park any vehicle on said street in
violation of any such signs. (1977 Code § 10-7-7)
CHAPTER 6
TRAFFIC SCHEDULES 1
SECTION:
7-6-1: Authority To Regulate Traffic On Certain Streets
7-6-2: Through Streets
7-6-3: Signs Posted
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection 7-8-1B of this title for vehicle weight limits on certain
  streets.
7-6-1: AUTHORITY TO REGULATE TRAFFIC ON CERTAIN STREETS:
   A.   The Village Board of Trustees shall designate, by resolution or motion,
those streets or parts of streets insofar as they exist within the limits of
the Village which shall be through streets, one-way streets, or arterial
streets.
   B.   The Village Board of Trustees shall designate, by resolution or motion,
those locations and intersections which shall be stop locations, yield right of
way locations and any other designation that may be appropriate. (1977 Code §
10-3-1)
   C.   The Village Board of Trustees shall designate, by resolution or motion,
those locations at which parking shall be regulated.
   D.   The resolutions designating the various traffic schedules referenced in
this section are on file in the office of the Village Clerk for public use and
inspection. (2004 Code)
7-6-2: THROUGH STREETS:
The following described roads or streets are hereby designated through streets:
Miller Road
State Highway Route 22
State Highway Route 59 (1977 Code §
10-3-2)
7-6-3: SIGNS POSTED:
   A.   Through Streets: Whenever any street or road is designated a through
street, as herein provided, it shall be the duty of the superintendent of roads
to place and maintain a stop sign on each and every street intersecting such
through street or intersecting that part thereof described and designated as
such unless traffic at any such intersection is controlled by traffic control
signals; provided, however, that at the intersection of a through street and a
heavy traffic street not so designated, stop signs shall be erected at the
approaches of either or both of said streets as may be determined by the Board
of Trustees.
   B.   Stop Locations: Stop signs shall be erected at all locations designated
stop locations.
   C.   Yield Right Of Way Signs: Appropriate signs will be erected at all
yield right of way intersections. (1977 Code § 10-3-8)
   D.   One Way Streets: Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic
movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in the
opposite direction is prohibited. (1977 Code §
10-3-3)
CHAPTER 7
PEDESTRIANS
SECTION:
7-7-1: Applicability Of Traffic Regulations
7-7-2: Duty To Exercise Due Care
7-7-3: Right Of Way
7-7-4: Pedestrians Crossing Roadways
7-7-5: Pedestrians Walking On Roadways
7-7-6: Soliciting Rides Or Business
7-7-7: Persons With Disabilities
7-7-1: APPLICABILITY OF TRAFFIC REGULATIONS:
Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic control and pedestrian control signals
as heretofore declared in this title, but at all other places, pedestrians
shall be granted those rights and shall be subject to the restrictions stated
in this title. (1977 Code §
10-5-1)
7-7-2: DUTY TO EXERCISE DUE CARE:
   A.   Duty Of Driver: Notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter, every
driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any
pedestrian upon any roadway or any person operating a bicycle or other device
propelled by human power and shall give warning by sounding the horn when
necessary and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any
obviously confused or incapacitated or intoxicated person upon a roadway. (1977
Code §
10-5-2; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Duty Of Pedestrian: Nothing in this chapter shall relieve a pedestrian
from the duty of exercising due care. (1977 Code §
10-5-2)
7-7-3: RIGHT OF WAY:
   A.   Pedestrians' Right Of Way: When traffic control signals are not in
place or not in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right of
way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield to a pedestrian crossing
the roadway within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is upon the half of the
roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is
approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in
danger.
   B.   Vehicles Stopped At Crosswalks And Intersections: Whenever any vehicle
is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an
intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any
other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such
stopped vehicle. (1977 Code §
10-5-3)
   C.   Stop Signs; Flashing Red Signals: Whenever stop signs or flashing red
signals are in place at an intersection or at a plainly marked crosswalk
between intersections, pedestrians shall have the right of way over drivers of
vehicles. (1977 Code §
10-5-3; amd. 2004 Code)
7-7-4: PEDESTRIANS CROSSING ROADWAYS:
   A.   Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a
marked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right of way to all
vehicles upon the roadway.
   B.   No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and
walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible
for the driver to yield. (1977 Code §
10-5-2)
7-7-5: PEDESTRIANS WALKING ON ROADWAYS:
   A.   Where a sidewalk is provided and its use is practicable, it shall be
unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway.
   B.   Where a sidewalk is not available, any pedestrian walking along and
upon a roadway shall walk only on a shoulder, as far as practicable from the
edge of the roadway.
   C.   Where neither a sidewalk nor a shoulder is available, any pedestrian
walking along and upon a roadway shall walk as near as practicable to an
outside edge of a roadway and, if on a two way roadway, shall walk only on the
left side of the roadway.
   D.   Except as otherwise provided in this title, any pedestrian upon a
roadway shall yield the right of way to all vehicles upon the roadway. (2004
Code)
7-7-6: SOLICITING RIDES OR BUSINESS:
   A.   Soliciting Rides Prohibited: No person shall stand in a roadway for the
purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any vehicle.
   B.   Soliciting Business On A Roadway: No person shall stand on a roadway
for the purpose of soliciting employment or business from the occupant of any
vehicle.
   C.   Soliciting Contributions On A Roadway: No person shall stand on a
roadway for the purpose of soliciting contributions from the occupant of any
vehicle, except when expressly permitted by Village ordinance. Solicitations on
roadways within the Village shall be allowed only at intersections where all
traffic is required to come to a full stop. The soliciting entity shall:
      1.   Be registered with the attorney general as a charitable organization
as provided by "an act to regulate solicitation and collection of funds for
charitable purposes, providing for violations thereof, and making an
appropriation therefor", approved July 26, 1963, as amended 1 ;
      2.   Have complied with all applicable provisions of title 3, chapter 2
of this code relative to peddlers and solicitors;
      3.   Be engaged in a statewide fundraising activity;
      4.   Be liable for any injuries to any person or property during such
solicitation which is causally related to an act of ordinary negligence of the
agents or members of the soliciting entity and shall file with the Village a
public liability policy or certificate of insurance in the amount of one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) conditioned to indemnify the Village and hold
it harmless against any claim arising out of and resulting from such
solicitations; and
      5.   Any person engaged in the act of solicitation for a soliciting
entity under this section shall be sixteen (16) years of age or more and shall
be wearing a high visibility vest.
   D.   Soliciting To Hold Parking Space: No person shall stand on or in the
proximity of a roadway for the purpose of soliciting the watching or guarding
of any vehicle while parked or about to be parked on a street or roadway. (1977
Code §
10-5-4; amd. 2004 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 460/0.01 et seq.
7-7-7: PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES:
The driver of a vehicle shall yield the right of way to any pedestrian with
clearly visible disabilities. (2004 Code)
CHAPTER 8
VEHICLE WEIGHT LIMITS
SECTION:
7-8-1: Weight Limits Established
7-8-2: Enforcement
7-8-3: Violation
7-8-4: Penalties
7-8-1: WEIGHT LIMITS ESTABLISHED:
   A.   Limits Established: All vehicles operated on Village roads constructed
of bituminous pavement over a gravel base shall be limited to a maximum weight
of twelve thousand (12,000) pounds for any one axle; except, that such maximum
weight shall be reduced to eight thousand (8,000) pounds for any one axle upon
direction of the Village President, Superintendent of Roads, Deputy
Superintendent of Roads, or any law enforcement official, if any such official
finds that damage to the Village streets and roads will be probable from loads
in excess of eight thousand (8,000) pounds on any one axle, due to weather or
road conditions.
   B.   Exemptions From Provisions: The provisions of subsection A of this
section shall not be applicable to trucks specifically equipped with a self-
compactor, or an industrial roll off hoist and roll off container used
exclusively for garbage or refuse operations, or to fire apparatus, vehicles
used in snow and ice removal, or school buses.
   C.   Signs Posted: Regulatory signs providing notice of the weight
limitations in this section shall be posted at appropriate locations. (1977
Code §
10-9-1; amd. 2004 Code)
7-8-2: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Enforcement Officers: Any law enforcement official, the Building and
Zoning Officer, or the Superintendent of Roads, or their designated
representatives, having reason to believe that the weight of a vehicle and load
is unlawful, may require the driver of any vehicle other than a passenger
automobile to submit to having said vehicle weighed at the nearest public
scales or at any suitable portable or stationary scales, whether private or
public.
   B.   Removal Of Overweight Vehicles: Whenever a law enforcement officer, or
other official, upon weighing a vehicle and load as provided herein, determines
that the weight exceeds that permitted herein, the driver of such vehicle shall
remove said vehicle from all "roadways", which are defined as per section
7-1-1 of this title, by the shortest available route. (1977 Code §
10-9-3; amd. 2004 Code)
7-8-3: VIOLATION:
Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of this
chapter, or whenever any driver of a vehicle who fails or refuses to stop and
submit to a weighing, or fails or refuses when directed by an officer to comply
with the provisions of this chapter, the owner or driver of such vehicle, or
both such owner and driver, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (1977 Code
§
10-9-4)
7-8-4: PENALTIES:
   A.   Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of
section
7-8-1 of this title, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty
of such violation, and either the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be
prosecuted for such violation. Any person convicted of any violation of section
7-8-1 of this chapter, including, but not limited to, a maximum axle or gross
limit specified on a regulatory sign, shall be fined according to the following
schedule:
Overweight Pounds Fine
Overweight Pounds         Fine
Up to and including 2,000 $50.00 unless the overweight can be shifted or
                          removed to conform to all legal weights
2,001 through 2,500       $135.00
2,501 through 3,000       $165.00
3,001 through 3,500       $260.00
3,501 through 4,000       $350.00
4,001 through 4,500       $425.00
4,501 through 5,000       $475.00
                          The fine shall be computed at the rate of $75.00 for
5,001 or more             each increment of 500 pounds overweight or fraction
                          thereof
 
(1977 Code §
10-9-2; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   In addition, any person, firm or corporation convicted of four (4) or
more violations of section
7-8-1 of this chapter within any twelve (12) month period shall be fined an
additional amount of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for the
fourth and each subsequent conviction within a twelve (12) month period.
Provided, however, that with regard to a firm or corporation, a fourth or
subsequent conviction shall mean a fourth or subsequent conviction attributable
to any one employee driver. (1977 Code §
10-9-2)
CHAPTER 9
INOPERABLE VEHICLES
SECTION:
7-9-1: Definition
7-9-2: Nuisance Declared; Prohibitions; Exemptions
7-9-3: Abatement Procedures
7-9-4: Enforcement
7-9-5: Penalty
7-9-1: DEFINITION:
When used in this chapter, the term "inoperable motor vehicle" shall mean any
motor vehicle from which, for a period of at least ten (10) consecutive days,
the engine, any wheels or any tire is flat, or other parts have been removed,
or any wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated
that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor power.
"Inoperable motor vehicle" shall not include a motor vehicle which has been
rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor power in
order to perform ordinary service or repair operations. (Ord. 1306, 8-23-2017)
7-9-2: NUISANCE DECLARED; PROHIBITIONS; EXEMPTIONS:
The location or presence of any inoperable motor vehicle on any lot, tract,
parcel of land or portion thereof, occupied or unoccupied, improved or
unimproved, within the Village shall be deemed a public nuisance, and it shall
be unlawful for any person to cause or maintain such public nuisance by
wrecking, dismantling, rendering inoperable, abandoning or discarding his
vehicle on the property of another or public property or to suffer, permit or
allow the same to be placed, located, or maintained or to exist upon his own
real property or any premises leased or occupied by him; provided, that this
chapter shall not apply to: (1977 Code § 10-2-8; amd. 2004 Code)
   A.   A vehicle or part thereof which is completely enclosed within a
building in a lawful manner where it is not visible from the street or other
private or public property;
   B.   A vehicle or part thereof which is stored or parked in a lawful manner
on private property in connection with the business of a licensed vehicle
dealer or a vehicle on the premises of a licensed business engaged in wrecking
or junking of vehicles, if such businesses are otherwise permitted by the
ordinances of the Village; or
   C.   Historic vehicles over twenty five (25) years of age. (1977 Code § 10-
2-8)
7-9-3: ABATEMENT PROCEDURES:
   A.   Notice To Abate:
      1.   Private Property: Whenever such public nuisance exists in the
Village in violation hereof, the Village and/or its agents shall give not less
than seven (7) days' notice to the owner of the real property, the occupant or
lessee, if any, of the premises whereon such public nuisance exists to abate or
remove the same, stating the nature of the public nuisance on private property
and that it must be removed and abated within seven (7) days and further that a
request for a hearing must be made before expiration of said seven (7) day
period by the aggrieved person, such notice to be mailed, by certified or
registered mail and by regular mail, to the owner, the occupant or the lessee
of the private premises whereupon such public nuisance exists. If the notice is
returned undelivered by the United States Post Office, official action to abate
said nuisance shall be continued to a date not less than seven (7) days from
the date of such return.
      2.   Public Property: Whenever such public nuisance exists in the Village
in violation hereof, the Village and/or its agents shall give not less than
seven (7) days' notice, stating the nature of the public nuisance on the public
property or on a public right- of-way and that it must be removed and abated
within seven (7) days and further that a request for a hearing must be made
before expiration of said seven (7) day period, such notice to be mailed, by
certified or registered mail to the owner, the occupant or the lessee of the
public premises or to the owner, the occupant or the lessee of the premises
adjacent to the public right-of-way whereupon such public nuisance exists. If
the notice is returned undelivered by the United States Post Office, official
action to abate the nuisance shall be continued to a date not less than seven
(7) days from the date of said return.
   B.   Hearing: If a public hearing is requested within seven (7) days after
service of notice to abate the public nuisance to the owner, the occupant or
the lessee of the public or private premises upon which the inoperable vehicle
is located, said public hearing will be held before a person designated by the
Village Board of Trustees. Any resolution or order requiring the removal of a
vehicle or part thereof shall include a description of the vehicle, the correct
identification number and license number of the vehicle, if available.
   C.   Removal With Permission Of Owner Or Occupant: If, within seven (7) days
after receipt of notice from the Village and/or its agents to abate the
nuisance as herein provided, the owner, the occupant or lessee of the premises
shall give written permission to the Village for removal of the inoperable
motor vehicle from the premises, the removal shall be at the expense of said
owner. The giving of permission shall be considered compliance with the
provisions of this chapter. (1977 Code §
   D.   Failure To Abate; Disposal Of Vehicles: If the public nuisance is not
abated by the owner, occupant or lessee after notice is given in accordance
with this chapter, official action shall be taken by the Village to abate the
nuisance. Inoperable vehicles or parts thereof may be disposed of by removal to
a scrapyard or demolishers for processing as scrap or salvage.
   E.   Summary Abatement: Nothing in this chapter shall affect statutes or
