to this chapter shall be a lien upon the real property. The lien shall be
superior to all other liens and encumbrances except real estate taxes. The
Village Building and Zoning Officer shall file a notice of lien, within one (1)
year after such cost and expense is incurred, in the Office of the Lake County
Recorder. The lien may be enforced by proceeding to foreclose, as in case of
mortgages or mechanic's liens. (Ord. 1201, 3-23-2011)
8-6-10: REQUEST FOR WAIVER:
   A.   Any owner of a vacant residential property of one (1) to three (3)
units, who is a natural person with insufficient income or resources to fulfill
all of the obligations imposed herein, may petition the Village Building and
Zoning Officer for a waiver of the registration fee, a reduction of the minimum
amount of liability insurance, and/or a waiver of some or all of the property
rehabilitation requirements (hereinafter "financial requirements") under this
chapter for a period of time not to exceed twelve (12) months. Application for
a waiver of financial requirements shall be in writing on forms provided by the
Village. The decision of the Village Building and Zoning Officer, to be made
within fourteen (14) days after receiving the petition, shall be made in
writing and forthwith shall be mailed or delivered to the petitioner. An appeal
of the decision may be made to the Village President, in writing, within
fourteen (14) days of the mailing or delivery of the decision. Individuals who
are granted a twelve (12) month waiver under this section remain obligated to
keep the registered property secure and safe, and the exterior property areas
free from debris, with grass regularly mowed.
   B.   A request for a waiver from the other provisions of this chapter for
good cause as set forth in the waiver request, shall be made by the owner to
the President and Board of Trustees, in writing and submitted to the Village
Clerk. The waiver request shall be heard at a meeting of the corporate
authorities within thirty (30) days of receipt by the Village Clerk and the
decision of the Village Board shall be in writing and mailed or delivered to
the petitioner. (Ord. 1201, 3-23-2011)
TITLE 9
DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
9-1-1: Rules Of Word Construction; Definitions
9-1-2: Interpretation Of Provisions
9-1-3: Compliance With Comprehensive Plan
9-1-4: Plats Required; Prohibitions
9-1-5: Further Subdivision; Consideration If Part Of Larger Unit
9-1-6: Permit Requirements
9-1-7: Record Drawings
9-1-8: Costs And Expenses To Subdivider
9-1-9: Dedications Of Land
9-1-10: Erosion And Sedimentation Control
9-1-11: Variations
9-1-12: Culvert Materials
9-1-1: RULES OF WORD CONSTRUCTION; DEFINITIONS:
In the interpretation of this title, the definitions contained in this section
shall be observed and applied, except when the context clearly indicates
otherwise. Words used in the present tense shall include the future, and words
used in the singular number shall include the plural number, and the plural the
singular. The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary. The word "may"
is permissive. The word "lot" shall include the words "plot", "piece", and
"parcel". The phrase "used for" shall include the phrases "arranged for",
"designed for", "intended for", "maintained for" and "occupied for".
BASE FLOOD ELEVATION (BFE): The elevation delineating the level of flooding
resulting from the 100-year flood frequency elevation.
BLOCK: A tract of land bounded by streets, or by a combination of streets and
public parks, cemeteries, railroad rights of way, bulkhead lines or shorelines
of waterways, or corporate boundary lines of the Village.
BUILDING: Any structure designed, built, or intended for the shelter, enclosure
or protection of persons, animals, chattels or movable property of any kind.
BUILDING INTERIOR: Any portion of the interior of a principal building.
BUILDING SETBACK LINE: A line within a lot or other parcel of land, so
designated on the plats of the proposed subdivision, between which line and the
adjacent boundary of the street upon which the lot abuts the erection of a
building is prohibited.
CROSSWALK: A public right of way located across a block to provide pedestrian
access to adjacent streets or areas.
CUL-DE-SAC: A minor street having one open end and being permanently terminated
by a vehicle turnaround.
EASEMENT: A grant by a property owner for the use of a strip of land by the
general public, a corporation, or a certain person or persons for a specific
purpose or purposes.
FLOODPLAIN (REGULATORY): "Floodplains" may be either riverine or nonriverine
depressional areas. "Riverine floodplains" are those areas contiguous to a
lake, pond, or stream whose elevation is greater than the normal water pool
elevation but equal to or lower than the projected 100-year flood elevation.
"Nonriverine floodplains" are depressional storage areas not associated with a
stream system to which surrounding lands drain causing periodic inundation by
storm waters. In certain cases, the "floodplain" may also be known as the
special flood hazard area (SFHA). A "regulatory floodplain" exists along any
watercourse draining one hundred (100) acres or more, or any nonriverine areas
with a surface area greater than one-fourth (1/4) acre, for the 100-year event.
HEALTH OFFICER: The Health Officer as provided for in title 1, chapter 7,
article G of this code, the consulting engineer for health and sanitation
matters as appointed by the Village President and confirmed by the Board of
Trustees or any engineer or other person as directed by the Village President
or the Board of Trustees. Any appointee may be an individual, partnership,
corporation or other entity.
HIGHWAY: A right of way for vehicular traffic, which traverses a nonurban area,
usually a state numbered or federal numbered route.
IDOT: Illinois department of transportation.
LOT: A portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land intended for transfer
of ownership or for building development.
PARKWAY: A route intended to be used primarily by passenger vehicles and whose
right of way is or is intended to be developed in a park like character.
PERSON: Includes an individual, trustee, corporation, partnership or other
entity.
PLAN COMMISSION: Refers to the Plan Commission of the Village of North
Barrington, Illinois.
PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT (PUD): A tract of land or any single lot or
combination of lots which is developed as a unit under single ownership or
control, pursuant to the definitions and regulations of the Village zoning
ordinance, as adopted and amended.
PLAT: A plan, map, drawing, or chart on which the subdivider's plan for the
subdivision of land is presented and which he submits for approval and intends
to record in final form.
PLAT, FINAL: The drawings and documents presented for final approval and for
recording.
PLAT, PRELIMINARY: The drawings and documents presented for conditional
approval.
ROADWAY: The paved area within a street right of way intended for vehicular
traffic.
STREAM: Any continuously flowing natural watercourse.
STREET: An area, which primarily serves or is intended to serve as a vehicular
and pedestrian access to abutting lands or to other streets. The word "street"
refers to the entire right of way or easements, whether public or private, and
not merely to the roadway or paving or other improvement within the street
right of way.
STREET, APPROVED: Any street, whether public or private, meeting standards and
specifications of the Village of North Barrington.
STREET, ARTERIAL: A street for interurban continuity or regional importance
that provides reasonably continuous routes through this whole or major portion
of the Village.
STREET, COLLECTOR: A street, which conveys traffic from minor streets to state
or county highways or to other collector streets.
STREET, MINOR: A street intended primarily as access to abutting properties.
STREET, PRIMARY: Any primary or secondary thoroughfare or minor street, which
has been dedicated for public use by a recorded subdivision plat or other
document of dedication.
STREET, PRIVATE: Any street which is under the jurisdiction of a person or any
street which is privately owned or established.
SUBDIVIDER (DEVELOPER): Any individuals, firms, associations, syndicates,
corporations, copartnerships, trusts or other legal entities commencing
proceedings under this title to effect a subdivision of land.
SUBDIVISION: Includes resubdivision and where it is appropriate to the context,
relates to the process of subdividing or to the land subdivided. For the
purpose of these regulations, a subdivision of land is or includes:
A. The division of land into two (2) or more lots, sites, or parcels for the
purpose of transfer of ownership or building development; provided, however,
that a subdivision of land, in parcels of more than five (5) acres, not
involving any new street or easement of access, shall be exempted;
B. The establishment or dedication of a public or private road, expressway,
street, or alley through a tract of land;
C. The resubdivision of land heretofore divided or platted into lots, sites, or
parcels;
D. The design for any planned shopping or business center; or
E. The design for a planned development.
USGS: United States geological survey, department of the interior.
VILLAGE BOARD, BOARD OR BOARD OF TRUSTEES, OR CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: Refer
collectively to the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of North
Barrington, Illinois.
VILLAGE ENGINEER: The designated professional engineer licensed by the state of
Illinois.
WATER SUPPLY, PUBLIC: A water system consisting of wells, distribution pipes,
service lines, and other facilities (i.e., treatment plants, pump stations,
hydrants, etc.) which provides potable water and, in some cases, provides fire
protection to paying customers. Said system could be either publicly or
privately owned. (1977 Code §
11-2-1; amd. 2004 Code)
9-1-2: INTERPRETATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Minimum Requirements: In their interpretation and application, the
provisions of this title shall be held to be the minimum requirements.
   B.   Conflicting Provisions: Where the conditions imposed by any provisions
of this title upon the use of land are either more restrictive or less
restrictive than comparable conditions imposed by any other provision of this
title or of any other law, ordinance, resolution, rule, or regulation of any
kind, the regulations which are more restrictive or which impose higher
standards or requirements shall govern.
   C.   Abrogation And Greater Restrictions: This title is not intended to
abrogate any easement, covenant, or any other private agreement; provided, that
where the regulations of this title are more restrictive or impose higher
standards or requirements than such easements, covenants, or other private
agreements, the requirements of this title shall govern. (1977 Code § 11-1-8;
amd. 2004 Code)
   D.   Planned Unit Developments (PUD): In the case of any PUD, the Plan
Commission may recommend and the Village Board may by ordinance authorize
exceptions and variations of the applicable size of residential sites or lots
within the boundaries of a PUD as provided in the zoning ordinance of the
Village, as amended from time to time. (Ord. 1113, 4-25-2007)
   E.   Validity: If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or
portion of this title is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any
court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate,
distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the
validity of the remaining portions thereof. (1977 Code § 11-1-8; amd. 2004
Code)
9-1-3: COMPLIANCE WITH COMPREHENSIVE PLAN 1 :
No map or plat of any subdivision presented for record affecting lands within
the corporate limits or any contiguous territory outside of and distant not
more than one and one-half (11/2) miles from the corporate limits of the
Village shall be approved by the Village Board or be entitled to record or
shall be valid unless such subdivision substantially complies with the official
comprehensive plan and is approved by the Plan Commission and Village Board.
(Ord. 1185, 3-31-2010)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 9-4-1A of this title.
9-1-4: PLATS REQUIRED; PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   Plats Required: Wherever any subdivision of land shall hereafter be
laid out within the incorporated limits of the Village or within contiguous
territory not more than one and one- half (11/2) miles beyond the incorporated
boundary of the Village, the subdivider thereof or his agent shall submit both
a preliminary and a final subdivision plat, and all procedures relating thereto
shall, in all respects, be in full compliance with these regulations. (1977
Code §
11-1-1)
   B.   Prohibitions: Until plats and plans for the subdivision are approved:
      1.   No land shall be subdivided, nor any street laid out, nor any
improvements made to the natural land.
      2.   No lot, tract, or parcel of land within any subdivision shall be
offered for sale nor shall any sale, contract for sale or option be made or
given.
      3.   No improvements, such as sidewalks, water supply, stormwater
drainage, sanitary sewerage facilities, gas service, electric service,
lighting, grading, paving or surfacing of streets shall hereafter be made by
any owner or his agent, or by any public service corporation at the request of
such owner or his agent.
      4.   No trees shall be removed. (1977 Code § 11-1-7; amd. 2004 Code)
9-1-5: FURTHER SUBDIVISION; CONSIDERATION IF PART OF LARGER UNIT:
Where a tract of land proposed for subdivision is part of a larger, logical
subdivision unit in relation to the Village as a whole, the Plan Commission
may, before approval, cause to be prepared a plan for the entire area or
neighborhood, such plan to be used by the Plan Commission as an aid in judging
the proposed plat. The Village Engineer shall cooperate with the Plan
Commission in the preparation of this plan and shall furnish such surveys and
data as may be necessary. (1977 Code §
11-1-3)
9-1-6: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Building And Development Permits: No building permit providing for the
improvement of any lot in any subdivision shall be issued until there has been
filed with the Building and Zoning Officer a certified copy of the plat of
subdivision as recorded or registered in the office of the recorder of deeds or
registrar of titles, as the case may be. Nor shall a building permit be issued
for the improvement of any lot until the plans and specifications for the
public improvements have been approved by and filed with the President and
Board of Trustees and until cash or surety bond as provided by ordinance are
posted with the Village.
No building or development permit shall be issued for developments, buildings
(other than individual single-family homes) or subdivisions unless and until
evidence of liability insurance has been provided to the Village with limits of
liability in at least the following amounts:
      1.   General liability:
         a.   Each occurrence, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00); and
         b.   Personal injury, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00); and
         c.   General aggregate, two million dollars ($2,000,000.00); and
         d.   Products, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00).
      2.   Automobile liability:
         a.   Any vehicle including hired vehicles and nonowned vehicles, one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00).
      3.   Excess/umbrella liability on an occurrence basis:
         a.   Each occurrence, three million dollars ($3,000,000.00); and
         b.   Aggregate, three million dollars ($3,000,000.00).
      4.   Workers' compensation and employers' liability:
         a.   Each occurrence, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00); and
         b.   Policy maximum, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00); and
         c.   Occupational disease, five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00).
Said insurance shall insure the contractor, developer or entity primarily
responsible for the construction or project and shall name as additional
insureds:
      1.   The property owner; and
      2.   The Village of North Barrington and its officers, agents and
independent contractors having any responsibilities as to the work being
performed (including engineers, surveyors, building and enforcement officers
and attorneys). (Ord. 1086, 3-20-2006)
   B.   Occupancy Permits: No occupancy permit shall be granted by any
governing official for the use of any structure within any subdivision approved
for platting or replatting until required utility facilities have been
installed and made ready to service the property, and that roadways providing
access to the subject lot or lots have been constructed, or are in the course
of construction. (1977 Code § 11-1-5)
   C.   Temporary Occupancy Permits: At the discretion of the Building and
Zoning Officer, a temporary occupancy permit may be issued for a specific
period of time not to exceed six (6) months, and a bond, if appropriate,
required. (2004 Code)
9-1-7: RECORD DRAWINGS:
   A.   Reproducible record drawings signed and sealed by the design engineer
or other independent professional employed by the subdivider shall clearly show
any and all changes from the approved drawings. Record drawings shall be
submitted to the Village Engineer prior to the subdivider's or developer's
request for final inspection of the required improvements. The record drawings
shall be based on actual measurements of both horizontal and vertical
dimensions, made after the completion of the work. Record drawings shall
include, but are not limited to, the following information:
      1.   Location of streetlight poles and cable run to power source.
      2.   Location and elevation of structures (storm and sanitary sewer
system).
      3.   Depth and location of utility mains.
      4.   Drainage swale grades and capacity calculations.
      5.   Stormwater detention basin contours and volume calculations.
   B.   One mylar copy and three (3) blue line copies shall be submitted to
meet this requirement. A digital copy of the record drawing and the final plat
of subdivision as recorded (AutoCAD) shall also be submitted.
   C.   An electronic copy of the record drawing and the final plat of
subdivision as recorded shall be submitted in AutoCAD format, as approved by
the Village Engineer, and referenced to the Illinois state plane coordinate
system and NGVD88 datum. (Ord. 1200, 2-23-2011)
9-1-8: COSTS AND EXPENSES TO SUBDIVIDER:
   A.   Public Improvements: All public improvements proposed to be made under
the provisions of this title shall be inspected during the course of
construction by the Village Engineer or a duly designated deputy. All fees and
costs connected with such inspection and with reviewing the plans and
specifications for such improvements shall be paid by the subdivider.
   B.   Deposit For Expenses: Prior to the consideration of any subdivision
application by the corporate authorities or by any officer or employee of the
Village, the petitioner for such subdivision shall deposit with the Village in
a trust and agency account such sum as is reasonably required, in the opinion
of the Board of Trustees, to initially compensate the Village for the
engineering, planning and legal expenses expected to be incurred by the Village
in considering such subdivision application. The amount of such deposit may be
increased or decreased from time to time by the Board of Trustees as is
reasonably necessary to compensate the Village for such expenses and will be
referred as a "trust and agency account" as set forth in section
1-8-5 of this code. (1977 Code § 11-1-6; amd. 2004 Code)
9-1-9: DEDICATIONS OF LAND:
All offerings or dedications of land to the Village for use as streets,
highways, alleys, schools, parks, playgrounds or other public uses shall be
referred to the Plan Commission for review and recommendation before being
accepted by the Village Board or any other governing authority of the Village.
(1977 Code §
11-1-2)
9-1-10: EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL:
The provisions of title 5, chapter 1 of this code relative to erosion and
sedimentation control apply to all subdivisions (as well as to actions not
constituting subdivisions of property). (1977 Code § 11-1-11)
9-1-11: VARIATIONS:
The Village Board may waive or vary the strict requirements of any of the
provisions of this title, including the requirement of a plat of subdivision if
such waiver of plat requirement is consistent with state statutes, when the
Village Board finds that there are unusual or extraordinary conditions or
hardships relative to the property or that the enforcement of the regulations
in a specific case is not required in the public interest. In addition, where
the Plan Commission finds that extraordinary hardships may result from strict
application of the requirements of the regulations of this title to any
proposed plat of subdivision or otherwise finds that there are unusual
conditions or hardships relative to particular property and its development,
the Plan Commission may recommend to the Village Board that one or more
requirements of this title be waived as to said plat of subdivision. No
variation of this title shall be granted except by motion or resolution adopted
by the Village Board or by acceptance of such plat by the Village Board. (1977
Code § 11-1-9)
9-1-12: CULVERT MATERIALS:
Culverts located within the right of way of public streets, whether under
driveways or under the streets themselves, as well as culverts under driveways
located on private property, shall be constructed under the supervision of the
Village Engineer and shall be constructed of one of the following materials and
shall have the following specifications:
   A.   Reinforced concrete; or
   B.   Corrugated polyethylene with smooth interior; or
   C.   Polyvinyl chloride.
All flared end sections, fittings and specials shall match the pipe in all
respects. It is preferred that all portions of such pipe which are visible
after installation has been completed be a neutral color.
All pipe, except reinforced concrete, shall have at least twelve inches (12")
of cover from the top of the pipe to the bottom of the hard surface pavement,
except where lesser cover is authorized by the Village Engineer. (Ord. 1142, 4-
23-2008)
CHAPTER 2
SUBDIVISION PLATTING PROCEDURES
SECTION:
9-2-1: Preapplication Procedure
9-2-2: Preliminary Plat; Conditional Approval
9-2-3: Final Plat; Approval
9-2-1: PREAPPLICATION PROCEDURE:
   A.   Submission Of Plans And Data: Previous to the filing of an application
for conditional approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider may submit to
the Plan Commission plans and data as specified in chapter 5 of this title.
This item does not require formal application, fee, or filing of plat with the
Plan Commission.
   B.   Approval Or Denial Of Plans And Data: Within thirty (30) days the Plan
Commission shall inform the subdivider that the plans and data as submitted or
as modified do or do not meet the objectives of these regulations. When the
Plan Commission finds that the plans and data do not meet the objectives of
these regulations, it shall express its reasons therefor. (1977 Code § 11-3-1;
amd. 2004 Code)
9-2-2: PRELIMINARY PLAT; CONDITIONAL APPROVAL:
   A.   Preparation Of Preliminary Plat And Other Materials: On reaching
conclusions, informally, as recommended in section
9-2-1 of this chapter regarding his general program and objectives, the
subdivider shall cause to be prepared a preliminary plat, together with
improvement plans and other supplementary material as specified in chapter 5 of
this title.
   B.   Submission To Village: Twelve (12) copies of the preliminary plat and
supplementary material specified shall be submitted to the Village with written
application for conditional approval at least thirty (30) days prior to the
initial Plan Commission meeting at which it is to be considered.
   C.   Deposit Required: Along with the application for conditional approval
of the preliminary plat, the subdivider must deposit in the "trust and agency
(T&A) account" with the Village such amount as determined by the Village
President 1 . This account is to be used to provide reimbursement to the
Village for Village expenditures for all staff and outside consultants' time to
review and approve plans, specifications and other documents and for
construction supervision of the approved subdivision improvements. This account
must be maintained until subdivision improvements have been approved. Upon
approval of the improvements, any account funds not used will be returned to
the subdivider. (1977 Code § 11-3-2; amd. 2004 Code)
   D.   Approval Or Disapproval: Following review of the preliminary plat and
other data submitted in compliance with these regulations, and following
discussions with the subdivider on changes deemed advisable and the kind and
extent of improvements to be made by the subdivider, the Plan Commission shall,
within ninety (90) days from the date of the application or the filing by the
subdivider of the last item of required supporting data, act on the plat and
data as submitted or modified, and if approved, the Plan Commission shall
express its approval as "conditional approval" and state the conditions of such
approval, if any; if disapproved, the Plan Commission shall express its
disapproval in writing and its reasons therefor. The Plan Commission's action
shall be forwarded to the corporate authorities for final action.
   E.   Approval Required By Corporate Authorities; Notice: The corporate
authorities shall approve or disapprove the proposed preliminary plat within
sixty (60) days after the decision of the Plan Commission. By mutual agreement,
the subdivider and corporate authorities may agree to extend the sixty (60) day
period.
   F.   Distribution Of Copies: The actions of the Plan Commission and
corporate authorities shall be noted on three (3) copies of the preliminary
plat, referenced and attached to any conditions determined. One copy shall be
returned to the subdivider, one retained by the Plan Commission, and one
retained by the Village Clerk. (Ord. 1092, 6-28-2006)
   G.   Approval Of Preliminary Plat Not Approval Of Final Plat: Conditional
approval of a preliminary plat shall not constitute approval of the final plat.
Rather it shall be deemed an expression of approval to the layout submitted on
the preliminary plat as a guide to the preparation of the final plat which will
be submitted for approval by the Plan Commission not later than one year after
preliminary approval has been granted.
   H.   Areas Subjected To Flooding; Surface Water Drainage: No plat will be
approved for a subdivision which does not comply with the requirements of title
5, chapter 5 of this code. (1977 Code § 11-3-2; amd. 2004 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  1-8-5 of this code.
9-2-3: FINAL PLAT; APPROVAL:
   A.   Requests For Approval Of Final Plat: Requests for approval of the final
plat shall be submitted in writing to the Plan Commission at least forty five
(45) days prior to the meeting at which it is to be considered and shall be
submitted within six (6) months after approval of the preliminary plat unless
such time is extended by the corporate authorities. (Ord. 1092, 6-28-2006)
   B.   Conformance With Preliminary Plat: The final plat shall conform
substantially to the preliminary plat as approved, and if desired by the
subdivider, it may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary
plat which he proposes to record and develop at the time; provided, however,
that such portion conforms to all requirements of these regulations.
   C.   Distribution Of Copies; Time Limit: Four (4) copies of the final plat,
plans and other exhibits required for approval shall be prepared as specified
in chapter 5 of this title, and shall be submitted to the Plan Commission for
review by the Village Engineer within one year after approval of the
preliminary plat; otherwise, such approval shall become null and void unless
application for an extension of time is made to and granted by the Plan
Commission.
   D.   Approval Or Disapproval By Plan Commission: Within forty five (45) days
after application for approval, the Plan Commission shall approve or disapprove
the final plat; provided, that the subdivider has supplied all documents and
materials required by ordinance or law. If the Plan Commission approves, it
shall be certified by the signature of its chair. If the Plan Commission
disapproves, it shall set forth its reasons in its own records, and provide the
applicant and the corporate authorities with copies.
   E.   Approval Required By Corporate Authorities; Notice: The corporate
authorities shall approve or disapprove the proposed final plat within sixty
(60) days after the decision of the Plan Commission. By mutual agreement, the
subdivider and corporate authorities may agree to extend the sixty (60) day
period. (1977 Code § 11-3-3; amd. 2004 Code)
   F.   Recordation Of Plat: The subdivider shall post a performance guarantee
with the Village as set forth in section
9-3-2 of this title and the final plat shall be recorded in the office of the
Lake County Recorder by the Village or its designee within one year after the
date of its approval. The corporate authorities may extend such time for
posting the performance guarantee and of recording in its discretion upon
application. (Ord. 1092, 6-28-2006)
CHAPTER 3
REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS; PERFORMANCE, MAINTENANCE AND ACCEPTANCE
SECTION:
9-3-1: Subdivider's Responsibility
9-3-2: Performance Guarantee
9-3-3: Inspection Of Improvements
9-3-4: Default, Failure To Complete Improvements
9-3-5: Acceptance Procedure
9-3-6: Maintenance Guarantee
9-3-7: Repairs By Village
9-3-1: SUBDIVIDER'S RESPONSIBILITY:
All required improvements shall be made by the subdivider at the subdivider's
expense without reimbursement of any kind or nature by or from the Village.
Nothing shall be construed to require the subdivider to a file a performance
guarantee or deposit other security until the subdivider's final plat has been
approved by the corporate authorities in all other respects and the subdivider
has been notified of such approval; provided, however, such performance
guarantee shall be filed with the Village prior to execution of the plat by any
officials of the Village. (2004 Code)
9-3-2: PERFORMANCE GUARANTEE:
To assure the satisfactory installation and completion of all required
improvements, a performance guarantee acceptable to the Village shall be
provided. In conformance with state statutes, the performance guarantee shall
be either cash, cash escrow deposit, a letter of credit or surety bond. No
final plat shall be recorded until a performance guarantee meeting the
following requirements has been deposited with the Village:
   A.   Forms:
      1.   Cash: A cashier's check, certified check, bank draft, bank money
order or other instrument in a readily negotiable form acceptable to and
approved by the Village Treasurer and made payable to the Village, and in an
amount determined by the Village Engineer to be sufficient to pay for the cost
of construction of the improvement and all engineering costs, including the
engineering and inspection fees of the Village.
      2.   Cash Escrow Deposit:
         a.   A cash escrow account in the amount required shall be established
with a financial institution which meets the approval of the Board of Trustees.
The account shall be administered in accordance with the provisions of the
escrow agreement to be negotiated by the Board of Trustees and the owner,
developer and/or subdivider and approved by the Village Attorney. Such
agreement shall contain provisions for specific application of such funds,
partial contract layouts, contract retention percentages until completion, pro
rata reduction of deposit excess, final escrow settlement and other pertinent
administrative matters.
         b.   Such escrow agreement shall also provide that twenty five percent
(25%) of the escrow amount shall be retained until the Village Engineer has
approved the required improvements and all public improvements have been
accepted by the Village.
         c.   The financial institution shall disburse funds from time to time
for the purposes provided upon presentation of, and in accordance with, payout
orders issued by the owner's engineer and approved by the Village President.
Such disbursements shall not be subject to approval or disapproval by the owner
or financial institutions or their agents other than said owner's engineer;
however, for accounting purposes, the Village shall send to the owner a copy of
the approved engineer's estimate for payment at time of Village approval. Each
payout order shall be accompanied by all appropriate sworn statements,
affidavits and supporting waivers of lien in full compliance with the Illinois
mechanics lien law 1 .
         d.   If the Village President notifies the financial institution, in
writing, that the balance of funds undisbursed under the escrow account is more
than sufficient to cover the cost of construction, fees and maintenance, and if
the financial institution concurs, the financial institution shall pay to the
owner any excess of funds not disbursed under said escrow account. Any notice
written by the Village President shall specify the reduced balance deemed to be
necessary and sufficient so that the amount of excess funds can be calculated.
      3.   Letter Of Credit:
         a.   The subdivider or owner may file an irrevocable letter of credit
from any financial institution authorized by law to issue such a letter and
acceptable to the Village President and in form acceptable to the Village
Attorney.
         b.   Such letter of credit shall guarantee to the Village the
availability of the funds specified in the irrevocable letter of credit and
guarantee the availability of such funds specified from time to time and upon
the demand of the Village.
         c.   Such letter of credit shall be in an amount determined by the
Village Engineer to be sufficient to pay for the cost of construction of the
improvements and all engineering costs, including the engineering and
inspection fees of the Village.
         d.   Such letter of credit shall provide that the issuing financial
institution shall pay to the Village, or as the Village directs, such amounts
as may be required to complete the improvements according to the approved
specification.
         e.   Such letter of credit may provide that its amount will be reduced
from time to time as payments for improvements approved by the Village Engineer
are made.
         f.   Such letter of credit shall be irrevocable for at least twenty
four (24) months and shall provide that if any balance remains at the
expiration of any time limit placed on it, said balance shall be deposited with
the Village in a cash escrow or a new letter of credit in the amount of the
unpaid balance shall be issued or a surety bond shall be provided.
         g.   Such letter of credit shall also provide that twenty five percent
(25%) of the principal amount shall be retained until the Village Engineer has
approved the required improvements and all public improvements have been
accepted by the Village.
         h.   Such letter of credit shall provide that it shall remain in force
even though there have been amendments or modifications to the matter for which
it was issued.
         i.   Such letter of credit shall, by its terms, not expire until
thirty five (35) calendar days after written notice of expiration has been sent
by certified mail, return receipt requested, by the issuer to the Village.
         j.   Such letter of credit shall provide that in the event the issuer
fails to honor the Village's demand for payment under the terms of the letter
of credit, the issuer shall be responsible for the attorney fees and other
costs which may be incurred in enforcing collection.
      4.   Surety Bond:
         a.   The subdivider or owner may file a surety bond from an insurance
company or financial institution licensed to do business in the state of
Illinois, with A.M. Best rating of not less than A- and financial saving rating
of not less than VIII, in a form acceptable to the Village Attorney.
         b.   Such surety bond shall guarantee to the Village the availability
of the funds specified in the surety bond and guarantee the availability of
such funds specified from time to time and upon the demand of the Village.
         c.   Such surety bond shall be in an amount determined by the Village
Engineer to be sufficient to pay for the cost of construction of the
improvements and all engineering costs, including the engineering and
inspection fees of the Village.
         d.   Such surety bond shall provide that the issuing financial
institution shall pay to the Village, or as the Village directs, such amounts
as may be required to complete the improvements according to the approved
specification.
         e.   Such surety bond shall be irrevocable for at least twenty four
(24) months and shall provide that if any balance remains at the expiration of
any time limit placed on it, said balance shall be deposited with the Village
in a cash escrow or a new surety bond in the amount of the unpaid balance shall
be issued.
         f.   Such surety bond shall also provide that twenty five percent
(25%) of the principal amount shall be retained until the Village Engineer has
approved the required improvements and all public improvements have been
accepted by the Village; provided, however, the subdivider or owner may
substitute a maintenance surety bond.
         g.   Such surety bond shall provide that it shall remain in force even
though there have been amendments or modifications to the matter for which it
was issued.
         h.   Such surety bond shall, by its terms, not expire until thirty
five (35) calendar days after written notice of expiration has been sent by
certified mail, return receipt requested, by the issuer to the Village.
         i.   Such surety bond shall provide that in the event the issuer fails
to honor the Village's demand for payment under the terms of the surety bond,
the issuer shall be responsible for the attorney fees and other costs which may
be incurred in enforcing collection.
   B.   Term And Extension:
      1.   The initial term of any performance guarantee shall be determined by
the Board of Trustees and shall be specified by the Board of Trustees in the
resolution approving the final plat. However, in no event shall such initial
term exceed thirty (30) months from the date of approval by the Board of
Trustees of the final plat.
      2.   The Board of Trustees, for good cause, may extend the term of the
performance guarantee for such additional period or periods where they find it
reasonable and appropriate and in the best interests of the public health,
safety and welfare.
   C.   Amount: The amount of the performance guarantee shall cover all
construction costs, and the Village's engineering and inspection costs, and all
maintenance costs until acceptance by the Village. The guarantee shall be in
the following minimum amounts unless the owner can show that certain of the
costs have already been paid:
      1.   Construction Costs: Unless otherwise provided in an annexation
agreement, development agreement or other document, one hundred ten percent
(110%) of the estimated construction costs approved by the Village Engineer.
      2.   Village Engineering And Inspection Costs: Actual costs incurred.
   D.   Reductions: A performance guarantee may, in the sole discretion of the
Board of Trustees, be reduced by an amount equal to the improvements which have
been completed according to the plans, specifications and provisions; provided,
that the Village Engineer has certified, in writing, that such improvements
have been satisfactorily completed and a revised estimate of the cost of the
remainder of the improvements is included. In no event shall a performance
guarantee be reduced below twenty five percent (25%) of the original principal
amount. The balance of the performance guarantee shall not be released until
all required improvements have been satisfactorily completed and the
subdivider's engineer or surveyor has certified to the Village Engineer,
through submission of a detailed as built survey, plat of the subdivision,
indicating location, dimensions, materials and other information required in
these regulations or by the Village Engineer, that the layout of the line and
grade of all improvements is in accordance with the construction plans for the
subdivision and showing any other information required by the Village Engineer.
   E.   Insufficient Fund Balance: If, at any time before the construction of
all required improvements has been completed, the balance of funds remaining
undisbursed or unobligated under a performance guarantee is not sufficient, in
the sole judgment of the Village Engineer, to cover the cost including the
engineering and inspection fees of the Village, or if by reason of any claim of
lien or any order, decree or writ of any court, or for any other reason, the
said undisbursed balance of funds shall be withheld, diminished or otherwise
unavailable for the purposes provided herein, the owner, by acceptance of the
approval of owner's final plat, agrees to cause the balance to be increased to
such amount as shall be required by the Village for such purposes, or shall
provide such other performance guarantee as may be required by the Village.
   F.   Guarantee For Subdivisions Outside Village Limits: A performance
guarantee will not be required by the Village for a subdivision or that part of
a subdivision which is located outside of the corporate limits of the Village,
if a performance guarantee has been filed with the county in which said
subdivision is located.
   G.   Time Limit: All performance guarantees shall provide that if required
improvements are not installed within two (2) years of approval of the final
plat, the Village may deem the subdivider in default and proceed accordingly;
provided, however, such time period may be extended by the Board of Trustees
where they find it reasonable and appropriate and in the best interests of the
public health, safety and welfare. (2004 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 770 ILCS 60/0.01 et seq.
9-3-3: INSPECTION OF IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   Required: All required land improvements to be installed under the
provisions of this title shall be inspected at the subdivider's expense. The
subdivider's licensed engineer, as agent for the subdivider shall provide an
inspector on the job during the process of construction. When the work has been
completed, the subdivider's engineer shall certify that the improvements comply
in all respects with the approved plans and specifications and with the
requirements of this title. All work shall be, at all times, subject to
inspection by the Village code enforcement officer, the Village Engineer, other
Village officials and their representatives.
   B.   Notification: Before starting the construction of any improvements, the
subdivider shall ascertain from the Village Engineer what inspections are
required and the amount of notification desired in each case. In no event shall
notice to the Village Engineer be less than forty eight (48) hours prior to a
desired inspection.
   C.   Subdivider's Responsibility: Regardless of contracts, agreements or
inspections performed, the subdivider shall be solely responsible for the
installation of all improvements in accordance with the applicable standards.
   D.   Time Limit On Construction Of Public Improvements: All improvements
required under the provisions of this title shall be completed within two (2)
years of approval of a plat or the subdivider shall be considered in default.
(2004 Code)
9-3-4: DEFAULT, FAILURE TO COMPLETE IMPROVEMENTS:
If the subdivider fails to perform the work on the improvements with sufficient
workers and equipment or with sufficient materials to ensure the completing of
the work within the specified time or shall perform such work that is rejected
as defective and unsuitable or should discontinue the prosecution of the work
or for any other cause shall not carry on the work in an approved manner, the
Board of Trustees shall give notice to the subdivider and specify what is to be
corrected or repaired. If, in the sole discretion of the Board of Trustees, the
subdivider fails to undertake to correct or repair immediately that which is
set forth in said notice, the Board of Trustees may:
   A.   Advise the subdivider of failure, in writing, giving the subdivider
thirty (30) calendar days to cure such default. If the subdivider fails to cure
said default, the Village may, at its option, declare subdivider in default
and, upon written notification to the financial institution of such declaration
of default, all monies on deposit pursuant to the escrow agreement or available
pursuant to a letter of credit shall and may be disbursed by the financial
institution solely upon authorization of the Village President and Village
Treasurer; and/or
   B.   The Village Treasurer shall cash all financial institution funds and
deposit them in the appropriate Village account to complete the required
improvements. The Board of Trustees may then make such contract or contracts,
not exceeding in the aggregate the amount of performance guarantee, as
necessary and appropriate or use any other reasonable methods to provide for
the completion of the work in an acceptable manner. The Board of Trustees is
authorized to take whatever other actions, including, but not limited to, the
institution of litigation, as it deems necessary or appropriate in order to
complete the improvements; and/or
   C.   Require the subdivider to submit a new performance guarantee in an
amount sufficient to cover any increased cost of constructing the required
improvements. (2004 Code)
9-3-5: ACCEPTANCE PROCEDURE:
Upon completion of all required subdivision improvements, the developer's
engineer shall prepare a certified statement that the improvements comply with
the plans and specifications approved by the Village authorities and shall
forward same to the Village Clerk together with a request for approval of
improvements. The Village Engineer shall verify whether the improvements comply
with the approved plans and specifications and shall prepare a statement of
approval for the Village Board. Upon acceptance of that statement of approval,
and upon submittal of the maintenance guarantee required in this chapter, the
Village Board shall then direct the Village Clerk to direct the financial
institution or the financial institution issuing the letter of credit to pay
over to the owner, without further demand or notice, any balance of funds then
remaining undisbursed under said construction cost escrow agreement or letter
of credit. (2004 Code)
9-3-6: MAINTENANCE GUARANTEE:
   A.   Conditions Of Guarantee: The owner shall establish cash, a cash escrow
account or provide a letter of credit or surety bond in the amount of twenty
five percent (25%) of the final construction costs of the improvements to
guarantee cost of replacement of defective materials within the limits of the
improvements. Said maintenance guarantee shall remain in force for the two (2)
year maintenance period and shall be for use by the Village to effect such
repairs deemed necessary for public safety and which the owner has neglected to
repair for a forty eight (48) hour period after notification. Disbursements
from the cash escrow account or pursuant to the letter of credit shall be made
solely upon the direction of the Village and shall not be given subject to
approval or disapproval by the owner, financial institution or the financial
institution issuing the letter of credit or their agents.
   B.   Maintenance Of Improvements: The subdivider shall be required to
maintain all improvements in the subdivision until all maintenance guarantees
of the subdivider have been released and the subdivider has performed all
maintenance agreements with the Village. Maintenance by the subdivider shall
not include removal of snow on streets and other public ways, which the Village
shall undertake.
   C.   Termination Of Guarantee: At the termination of the time period
specified for the posting of any maintenance guarantee, the guarantee, or any
part remaining, shall be released to the subdivider.
   D.   Defects In Materials And Workmanship: The owner shall guarantee public
improvements against defects in materials and workmanship for a period of two
(2) years from the date of acceptance of public street improvements or approval
of private street improvements by the Village. The owner agrees to repair or
replace any of said public improvements which, during said two (2) year period
after acceptance, shall become damaged or deficient due to defective materials
or workmanship. (2004 Code)
9-3-7: REPAIRS BY VILLAGE:
Nothing herein contained shall prevent the Village authorities from curing,
repairing or correcting any defect or failure or from maintaining any
improvement and charging all costs to the subdivider or the subdivider's
performance or maintenance guarantee bond if the public health, safety and
welfare requires that immediate and/or emergency action be taken. If such
repairs, replacements or other work exceeds the subdivider's performance or
maintenance guarantee, the subdivider shall be liable for such excess and shall
immediately remit the same to the Village Treasurer. (2004 Code)
CHAPTER 4
DESIGN STANDARDS
SECTION:
9-4-1: Compliance With Regulations
9-4-2: Sanitary Sewage System
9-4-3: Water Supply
9-4-4: Stormwater Management
9-4-5: Streets
9-4-6: Alleys
9-4-7: Easements
9-4-8: Blocks
9-4-9: Lots
9-4-10: Building Setback Lines
9-4-11: Parks, Schools And Public Areas
9-4-12: Preservation And Restoration Of Natural Features
9-4-1: COMPLIANCE WITH REGULATIONS:
   A.   The subdivision of lands, including the arrangement, character, extent,
width, grade and location of all highways, streets, crosswalks, easements,
sites for parks, playgrounds and schools, or other land to be dedicated for
public use, shall substantially conform to the official comprehensive plan of
the Village and all maps which are a part thereof 1 . (Ord. 1185, 3-31-2010)
   B.   Before a subdivision shall be approved, the Village Engineer shall
certify that the improvements described in the subdivider's plan and
specifications, together with agreement, meet the minimum requirements of all
ordinances of the Village and this code and that they comply with the
regulations and standards as set forth in this chapter. (1977 Code § 11-4-1)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  9-1-3 of this title.
9-4-2: SANITARY SEWAGE SYSTEM:
Any individual sewage disposal system(s) (septic system) shall meet all the
requirements of and shall be approved by the Village and, if required by law,
the Lake County health department. Any sewerage system designated as public
shall meet the requirements of the Village in title 4 of this code and the
Illinois environmental protection agency. (1977 Code § 11-4-2; amd. 2004 Code)
9-4-3: WATER SUPPLY:
Any individual water supply shall meet all requirements of and shall be
approved by the Lake County health department. Any water supply designated as
public water supply shall meet the requirements of the Lake County health
department and the Illinois environmental protection agency. (1977 Code § 11-4-
3; amd. 2004 Code)
9-4-4: STORMWATER MANAGEMENT:
A properly designed stormwater management system is required for all
developments in compliance with the requirements set forth in title 5, chapter
5 of this code and shall conform to the Lake County "comprehensive stormwater
management plan" and the requirements set forth below:
   A.   General Requirements:
      1.   All developments, whether public or private, shall include
provisions for the construction of a stormwater runoff conveyance system,
swales, drainage ditches, culvert pipes, storm sewers, detention and retention
basins, individually or in combination, shall constitute the stormwater runoff
conveyance system.
      2.   All streams, channels, or storm sewers shall be designed to
accommodate stormwater runoff from all areas, which naturally flow from the
area of development.
   B.   Design:
      1.   Design Runoff Rates: Minor drainage systems (storm sewers, swales
and ditches), as defined by title 5, chapter 5 of this code, conveyance of flow
from tributary areas of less than one hundred (100) acres may be based on
calculations using the rational method using the formula Q = c x i x A, where:
Q = runoff flow in cubic feet per second
c = runoff coefficient, characteristic of the tributary area in dimensionless
units
i = average rainfall intensity in inches per hour
A = tributary drainage area in acres
      2.   Rainfall Intensity:
         a.   The average rainfall intensity used for design shall be selected
from rainfall intensity curves based on Illinois state water survey bulletin
70.
         b.   The rainfall intensity for design of storm sewers or minor swales
and ditches shall be based on a rainstorm with a 10-year reoccurrence interval.
         c.   The rainfall intensity for design of major storm sewers in
combination with streams and channels shall be based on a rain storm with a
100-year recurrence interval.
      3.   Runoff Coefficients:
         a.   The runoff coefficient is the ratio of runoff to rainfall and
shall assume saturated conditions.
         b.   Runoff coefficient, "c", shall be a minimum of:
Impervious areas = 0.95
Pervious areas = 0.30
         c.   Runoff coefficients for undeveloped areas outside of the limits
of the proposed development shall be a minimum c = 0.50.
      4.   Stream, Channel And Storm Sewer Hydraulics:
         a.   Streams and channels shall be designed to provide design flow
capacity based on Manning's formula:
A2/3 x 1.486 x (r1/2) x (S)
n
Where:
Q = Quantity of flow in cubic feet per second
A = Area of the conduit in square feet
n = Roughness coefficient of the conduit (dimensionless)
r = Hydraulic radius = area of the conduit divided by wetted perimeter
S = Slope in feet per foot
         b.   Roughness Coefficients:
            (1)   Concrete pipe: n = 0.013
            (2)   Channel, sodded: n = 0.020
            (3)   Streams, clean: n = 0.030
            (4)   Stream, obstructed: n = 0.150
         c.   Velocities: Design velocities shall be:
            (1)   Storm sewers: minimum two feet per second (2 fps), maximum
ten feet per second (10 fps);
            (2)   Channels and streams:
   (A) Lined: minimum two feet per second (2 fps); maximum ten feet per second
(10 fps).
   (B) Unlined: minimum two feet per second (2 fps); maximum five feet per
second (5 fps).
      5.   Storm Sewers:
         a.   Storm sewers, when allowed, shall be designed such that the
hydraulic gradient shall be at an elevation no greater than six inches (6")
below the west structure frame.
         b.   Minimum storm sewer size shall be ten inches (10").
         c.   Storm sewers shall be laid straight in both horizontal and
vertical planes between structures unless otherwise approved in writing by the
Village Engineer.
         d.   Storm sewers of differing diameters shall join at structures
only. The invert elevations shall be adjusted to maintain a uniform energy
gradient by matching the 0.8 depth points of the differing diameters.
         e.   Inlets shall be provided so that surface water is not carried
across or around street intersections. Inlets shall be spaced such that
overland flow shall not build up a flow exceeding one cubic foot per second (1
cfps); except, that curb inlets shall be located such that not more than three
hundred feet (300') of gutter is tributary to an inlet or as otherwise approved
by the Village Engineer. Inlets shall be provided at all low points.
         f.   Manholes shall be provided at:
            (1)   Changes in direction, horizontal or vertical.
            (2)   Changes in shape or size of pipe.
            (3)   Junction of pipes.
            (4)   Maximum spacing four hundred feet (400') for sewers forty two
inches (42") in diameter and smaller; five hundred feet (500') for sewers forty
eight inches (48") in diameter and larger.
      6.   Drainageways:
         a.   Existing streams and channels may be maintained, stabilized,
realigned or channelized subject to requirements of the Illinois department of
natural resources, office of water resources, the U.S. army corps of engineers,
the federal emergency management agency, and title 5, chapter 5 of this code.
         b.   Where streams and channels are allowed to be realigned or
channelized, the bottom shall be stabilized and the banks shall be protected
from erosion by methods approved by the Village Engineer and in compliance with
title 5, chapter 1 of this code.
      7.   Floodplains: All construction in floodplains shall conform to title
5, chapter 5 of this code.
   C.   Material And Construction Requirements: All material specifications and
construction methods shall be determined by the Village Engineer and shall be
in accordance with the latest edition of the Illinois department of
transportation's "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction".
(1977 Code § 11-4-4; amd. 2004 Code)
9-4-5: STREETS:
   A.   Scope: All streets shall be considered in their relation to existing
and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public convenience and
safety, and in their relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by
such streets.
   B.   Arrangement Of Streets: Where such is not shown in the maps, which are
a part of the official comprehensive plan, the arrangement of streets in a
subdivision shall either:
      1.   Provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing
principal streets in surrounding areas; or
      2.   Conform to a plan for the area or neighborhood approved or adopted
by the Plan Commission to meet a particular situation where topographical or
other conditions make continuance or conformance to existing streets
impracticable.
   C.   Minor Streets: Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by
through traffic will be discouraged.
   D.   Cul-De-Sacs: The maximum length of a cul-de-sac shall be eight hundred
feet (800') measured along the centerline from the intersection at origin
through center of circle to end of right of way.
   E.   Reserve Strips: Reserve strips controlling access to streets shall be
prohibited.
   F.   Intersections And Street Jogs:
      1.   All street intersections and confluences should encourage safe
traffic flow.
      2.   Street jogs at intersections with centerline offsets of less than
one hundred twenty five feet (125') shall be avoided.
      3.   Streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible
at right angles, and no street shall intersect any other street at less than
sixty degrees (60°).
      4.   No more than two (2) streets shall intersect at any one point.
   G.   Half Streets: Half streets shall be prohibited. (1977 Code § 11-4-5;
amd. 2004 Code)
   H.   Street Names: No street names shall be used which will duplicate or be
confused with the names of existing streets. Existing street names shall be
used wherever possible. Street names shall be submitted by the subdivider in
advance to the appropriate local U.S. postal service office for approval and
shall be subject to approval by the Plan Commission. (Ord. 1175, 11-18-2009)
   I.   Grades Of Streets: Roadway grades shall provide proper relation between
the roadway and the first floor elevation of the houses or buildings and permit
convenient and economical access to the drainage of the lots. (1977 Code § 11-
4-5; amd. 2004 Code)
   J.   Visibility: Stopping sight distance, measured along the centerline of
the roadway, shall be provided for at least three hundred feet (300') on all
collector streets and two hundred feet (200') on minor streets.
   K.   Curves:
      1.   Where there is a deflection in the street alignment in excess of one
degree (1°), a curve shall be inserted with a radius of not less than the
following:
 
Collector street 300 feet
Minor street     150 feet
 
      2.   All vertical grade changes in the roadway centerline of more than
one percent (1%) shall require a vertical curve of two hundred feet (200')
minimum length.
   L.   Design And Construction Requirements:
      1.   Table Of Minimum Standards For Street And Roadway Design:
SCHEDULE OF MINIMUM DESIGN REQUIREMENTS FOR
SUBDIVISION ROADS IN THE VILLAGE OF NORTH BARRINGTON

                      Marginal Access-Minor        Collector
