   General Notes:
(i)   Return radii at all intersections shall be a minimum of 50 feet. Corner
lots shall have lot line corner radii such that the distance from the edge of
the pavement to the right of way line is approximately 20 feet.
   (ii)   Design requirements for private streets shall be the same as public
streets or as determined by the Village Engineer, and approved by the Board of
Trustees.
   Note 1:   Wider right of way may be required if deemed necessary by the Plan
Commission.
   Note 2:   Maximum length vertical curves consistent with good engineering
practice and compatible with the terrain shall be used between changes in
grade.
   Note 3:   Earth slopes shall be as flat as possible and shall in all cases
be carried to the property line. Construction easements shall be indicated on
the plat at locations where additional width is required to meet slope
requirements.
Additional geometrics, including stopping sight distance, should be in
accordance with IDOT design manual (latest edition) requirements, or in such
cases that may be deemed advisable for proper development, minimum standards as
determined by the Plan Commission or Village Engineer.
      2.   Roadway Construction Specifications:
         a.   Design Methods: Roadway pavements shall be designed in accordance
with structural design methods described in the IDOT design manual (latest
edition). The minimum allowable structural design numbers (Dt) by street
classification shall be as follows:
 
Collector Min D t 3.15
Minor     Min Dt 2.95
 
         b.   Base Course:
            (1)   The minimum width of base course by street classification
shall be as follows:
 
Collector                32 feet
Minor and cul-de-sac leg 30 feet
Cul-de-sac circle        92 foot diameter
 
            (2)   Allowable base course materials shall include aggregate base
course, type B (crushed stone or crushed gravel), or bituminous base course all
as specified in the IDOT "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge
Construction" (latest edition). The bearing capacity shall be determined by
"proof rolling" with a twenty five thousand (25,000) pound rubber tired vehicle
load provided by the contractor.
         c.   Primer: Prior to placing the bituminous binder and bituminous
surface course, the approved base course shall be primed in accordance with the
IDOT "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" (latest
edition).
         d.   Bituminous Binder And Surface Courses:
            (1)   Thickness:
 
        Minor And Cul-De-Sac   Collector
Binder  1 1/2" hot mix asphalt 21/2" hot mix asphalt
Surface 11/2" hot mix asphalt  11/2" hot mix asphalt
 
            (2)   Allowable surface course materials shall include hot mix
asphalt binder and surface course as specified in the IDOT "Standard
Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" (latest edition); except, that
the final lift of bituminous surface shall not be placed until at least seventy
five percent (75%) of the subdivision lots are occupied by a building for which
an occupancy permit has been issued.
         e.   Shoulders: Shoulders shall be not less than four feet (4') in
width and shall consist of not less than nineteen inches (19") of PCC adjacent
to the surface course, and not less than twenty nine inches (29") of compacted
turf shoulder adjacent to the concrete shoulder material. (See typical roadway
section at the end of this chapter.)
All materials shall be in accordance with IDOT "Standard Specifications For
Road And Bridge Construction", latest edition.
         f.   Ditches: Ditches of adequate capacity shall be provided on both
sides of the roadway. The slope from the shoulder line to the ditch and the
back slope to the existing grade shall not be greater than three to one (3:1).
The ditch flow line shall be not less than eighteen inches (18") below the
shoulder grade. (See typical roadway section at the end of this chapter.)
         g.   Bike Paths: Whenever constructed within the Village, bike paths
shall conform to the following standards:
            (1)   Bike paths shall be a minimum ten feet (10') in width to
provide for two-way traffic.
            (2)   The minimum construction of any bike path shall consist of a
six inch (6") type B aggregate base course with a two inch (2") bituminous
surface course.
            (3)   Bike paths shall have removable posts placed at all locations
necessary to prevent vehicular traffic from entering the paths.
            (4)   Construction of any bike path shall conform to the IDOT
"Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", latest edition,
except as provided herein, and the development standards.
            (5)   Bicycle lanes shall be appropriately signed and striped in
accordance with the "Illinois Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices".
         h.   Improvements; Public And Private: All construction on private
property in a subdivision or development shall conform to the requirements
stated herein. No private improvements may be considered for future acceptance
by the Village unless constructed in accordance with this chapter. Public
rights of way shall be governed by the following:
            (1)   Parking Lots:
   (A) All parking lots shall be designed in conformance with:
(i) "Transportation And Traffic Engineering Handbook" - Institute of
Transportation Engineers, latest edition.
(ii) These development standards.
   (B) Parking areas shall be designed and constructed in accordance with this
chapter of these development standards set forth below:
Minimum structural number shall be 2.0 for parking stall areas and a minimum
structural number of 2.5 for aisles and fire lanes, but in no case less than
the minimum thickness as provided in this chapter.
   (C) Combination concrete curb and gutter type B 6:12 or concrete barrier
curb type B shall be constructed around the perimeter of all parking lots and
around all islands within parking lots.
   (D) Striping of the pavement surface to define each parking stall is
required except for single-family dwellings, and such striping shall be a
minimum of four inches (4") wide for the length of the stall. All areas
designed as fire lanes and/or "No Parking" shall be painted with yellow
stripes.
   (E) Any location within parking lots intended for storage of trash
containers exceeding 2.0 cubic yards' capacity shall be constructed of concrete
rather than bituminous surface as provided in this chapter and shall be
enclosed with an approved screen or enclosure.
            (2)   Driveways:
   (A) Design: All driveway designs shall be consistent with the projected
traffic volume, type of traffic, and type of roadway, and shall be subject to
the review and approval of the Village Engineer. All driveways shall meet the
minimum standards as shown in detail and the development standards. Driveway
design shall be based upon a maximum of twelve feet (12') per lane. Any
driveway designed for three (3) or more lanes shall be striped or divided as
approved by the Building and Zoning Officer or Village Engineer.
   (B) Distance And Number: Driveway access to arterials shall be kept to a
minimum. Whenever possible, adjacent uses shall share common driveway access to
arterials. The minimum distance between driveways on arterials and SRA shall be
three hundred feet (300'), unless otherwise permitted upon review by the
Village Engineer and other units of government when applicable.
   (C) Construction: Driveways within a site shall be constructed to the
minimum specifications as required in this chapter. Driveways with high volumes
of truck traffic or other heavy loads shall be constructed to collector road
standards.
            (3)   Private Streets: All streets which serve as access or
frontage to subdivided lots shall be dedicated to the public unless specific
approval is granted by the Village Board. When any private streets are approved
by the Village Board in accordance with the requirements of this title and are
constructed, the following construction specifications shall apply:
   (A) Design: Private streets shall conform to the requirements for public
streets as stated in this chapter regarding general layout, design,
intersections and offsets.
   (B) Construction: Private streets shall conform to the requirements for
public streets as provided in this chapter regarding pavement design and
specifications.
            (4)   Sidewalks: Sidewalks shall be constructed where pedestrian
and vehicular traffic may conflict on private streets and where necessary to
provide access from parking areas to buildings. Sidewalks shall have a minimum
clear width of five feet (5') and shall conform to the requirements for public
sidewalks as provided in this chapter.
            (5)   Bike Paths: Whenever constructed, bike paths shall comply
with the requirements for bike paths in public rights of way.
            (6)   Easements: Easements shall be required for any development in
order to provide for placement of public utilities, protection of residential
uses, continuity of waterways, flow and storage of stormwater runoff, and
pedestrian access. Easements shall be located whenever necessary to ensure
these objectives and shall be subject to use, design, and location conditions
stated in section
9-4-7 of this chapter.
            (7)   Sight Triangle: No improvements shall be placed, nor plant
materials allowed to grow within the sight triangle so as to obstruct or limit
the sight distance of motorists. Such a triangle shall have legs of twenty five
feet (25') along the rights of way lines when two (2) streets intersect and ten
feet (10') along the right of way line and the driveway edge when a street and
a driveway intersect. The maximum height of any obstruction shall be eighteen
inches (18") within the sight triangle, unless otherwise permitted by the
zoning ordinance.
      3.   Procedure For Construction:
         a.   Licensed Engineer: The subdivider shall employ a licensed
professional engineer who shall be responsible for establishing proper lines
and grades for construction of all required improvements.
         b.   Inspections Prior To Construction: Prior to the start of roadway
construction, the subdivider shall consult with the Village Engineer for the
purpose of reviewing plans for drainage facilities, grading, alignment and any
such other plans involving road construction. No less than five (5) days' prior
notice of such consultation shall be given by the subdivider to the Village
Engineer.
         c.   Unsuitable Materials: Where the Village Engineer finds that
unsuitable subgrade material is present, that material shall be removed and
replaced with granular materials deemed acceptable by the Village Engineer.
         d.   Placement Of Surfaces:
            (1)   Placement of the first lift of bituminous binder course shall
not be done until the base course installation has been approved and has been
in place over at least one winter season.
            (2)   Placement of the final lift of bituminous surface course
shall be done only when one of the following criteria is satisfied:
   (A) Seventy five percent (75%) or more of all lots are occupied with a
permanent residence; or
   (B) The approved base course has been in place for more than five (5) years.
(Ord. 1175, 11-18-2009)
9-4-6: ALLEYS:
Alleys in residential areas shall not be permitted. (1977 Code § 11-4-11)
9-4-7: EASEMENTS:
   A.   Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lot lines shall be
provided for utilities and where necessary for drainage and shall be at least
ten feet (10') wide.
   B.   Easements shall be designed to provide continuity from block to block.
   C.   Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway,
channel, or stream, it shall be provided a storm water easement or drainage
right of way conforming substantially with the line of such watercourse and
shall include such further width or construction, or both, as will be adequate
for the purpose and as determined by the Plan Commission. Parallel streets or
parkways may be required in connection therewith. (1977 Code § 11-4-6; amd.
2004 Code)
9-4-8: BLOCKS:
   A.   Determination Of Block Design: The lengths, widths, and shapes of
blocks shall be determined with due regard to:
      1.   Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs
of the type of use contemplated.
      2.   Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions within the
corporate limits of the Village.
      3.   Needs for convenient access, circulation, control, and safety of
street traffic.
      4.   Limitations and opportunities of topography.
   B.   Length Of Blocks: Block lengths shall not exceed one thousand eight
hundred feet (1,800') nor be less than six hundred feet (600').
   C.   Crosswalks: Pedestrian crosswalks not less than ten feet (10') wide
shall be required where deemed necessary by the Plan Commission to provide for
pedestrian circulation or access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers,
transportation and other community facilities. (1977 Code § 11-4-7)
9-4-9: LOTS:
   A.   Lot Size And Design:
      1.   Lot dimensions and areas shall conform to the requirements of the
Village zoning ordinance within the Village limits or the comprehensive plan as
to unincorporated territory. However:
         a.   Where unusual soil conditions or other physical factors exist
which may impair the health and safety of the residents of the neighborhood in
which a subdivision may be located, upon recommendation of the state department
of public health, the Plan Commission may increase lot area requirements as may
be necessary.
         b.   Lots abutting a watercourse, drainageway, channel, or stream
shall have a minimum width or depth as required to provide an adequate building
site and to afford the minimum usable area required in this title or the
Village zoning ordinance for front, rear, and side yards.
      2.   Corner lots for residential use shall have extra width to permit
appropriate building setback from and orientation to both streets on which they
abut.
      3.   Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to
street lines.
   B.   Abutment On Public Street: All lots shall abut on a publicly dedicated
street unless otherwise approved by the Village Board.
   C.   Double And Reverse Frontage Lots: Double frontage and reverse frontage
lots should be avoided except where essential to provide separation of
residential development from highways or primary thoroughfares or to overcome
specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. A planting screen
easement of at least ten feet (10'), and across which there shall be no right
of access, shall be provided along the lines of lots abutting such highways and
primary thoroughfares or other disadvantageous use. (1977 Code § 11-4-8; amd.
2004 Code)
9-4-10: BUILDING SETBACK LINES:
Building setback lines of new subdivisions shall conform to the provisions of
the Village zoning ordinance. (1977 Code § 11-4-9)
9-4-11: PARKS, SCHOOLS AND PUBLIC AREAS:
The Plan Commission shall recommend to the Village Board such subdivider
donations as shall be equitable, taking into consideration the size and impact
of the development on public bodies, topography, wetlands, wooded areas and
other features of the property. (1977 Code § 11-4-10)
9-4-12: PRESERVATION AND RESTORATION OF NATURAL FEATURES:
   A.   Purpose And Scope:
      1.   The purpose of this section is to provide a procedure by which new
developments can preserve the natural country atmosphere, which is prevalent
throughout the Village.
      2.   Requirements set forth herein are minimal in scope and are not to be
assumed as a restriction on landscaping efforts. Innovative ideas to naturalize
disturbed landscapes are encouraged as long as they meet the overall objective
of this section and the approval of the Plan Commission and the Village Board.
      3.   Restorative and landscaping measures set forth herein are intended
to cover only those areas of the subdivision disturbed in the course of making
the improvements required by this section. The subdivider is encouraged to
provide additional landscaping throughout the subdivision that will compliment
the existing features and the developed site. Of particular importance is the
matter of noise abatement along high noise generators such as regional and area
highways and collector streets where site grading and landscaping can do much
to preserve the natural quietness of a residential neighborhood.
   B.   Natural Features And Tree Inventories Submitted; Determinations: The
Plan Commission may require that the subdivider submit a natural features
inventory and a tree survey which inventories all trees on the property and
shows their location. Based thereon, the Plan Commission may designate what
existing features which would add value to residential development or to the
Village as a whole, such as trees, as herein defined, watercourses, historic
spots and similar irreplaceable assets, and which of them shall be preserved in
the design of the subdivision. No trees shall be removed from any subdivision
nor any change of grade of the land effected until approval of the preliminary
plat has been granted. All trees on the plat required to be retained shall be
guarded and preserved, and all trees, where required, shall be welled and
protected against change of grade.
   C.   Ground Cover: The Plan Commission may require that all disturbed areas
within the subdivision, including unimproved areas within the dedicated right
of way of streets and other public use areas, shall be restored by placing a
minimum of three inches (3") of topsoil, graded and seeded or sodded, in a
manner approved by the Village Engineer. Consideration shall also be given to
restoring select areas with natural growths of wildflowers, ground cover or
similar material.
   D.   Replacement Trees: Trees required to be replaced must be replaced with
the species listed herein. If nine (9) or fewer trees are being replaced, equal
numbers of at least three (3) of the listed species must be used. If ten (10)
or more trees are being replaced, equal numbers of at least eight (8) of the
varieties listed must be used. Replacement trees must be limited to the
following varieties:
Northern red oak (Quercus Borealis maxima)
Bur oak (Quercus macrocarpa)
Green ash (Fraxinus pennsylvanica)
White ash (Fraxinus americana)
Norway maple (Acer platanoides)
Red maple (Acer rubrum)
Sugar maple (Acer saccharum)
Chestnuts (Aesculus baumanni, Aesculus glabra, Aesculus hippocastanum, Aesculus
octandra, Aesculus brioti)
Euchlora linden (Tilia euchlora)
Hackberry (Celtis occidentalis)
European black elder (Ainus glutinosa) - wet situation
   E.   Steep Slopes: All slopes greater than three to one (3:1) shall be
restored by means of sod or suitable ground cover.
   F.   Landscape Plan:
      1.   The Plan Commission may require that landscape plans and
specifications be furnished as part of the overall development plan submittal.
The plans shall be prepared by a practicing landscape architect and contain the
following information:
         a.   Plant name, both Latin and English.
         b.   Planting location.
         c.   Number of plants in any one location.
         d.   Total number of plants to be provided.
      2.   Bushes and trees utilized in the plan shall be selected from the
Village approved listing of landscape materials on file with the Village
Engineer. Not less than three (3) species of bushes and three (3) species of
trees will be utilized in developing a plan for a proposed subdivision. (1977
Code § 11-4-12)
CHAPTER 5
PLATS AND DATA
SECTION:
9-5-1: Preapplication Plans And Data
9-5-2: Plats And Data For Preliminary Approval
9-5-3: Plats And Data For Final Approval
9-5-1: PREAPPLICATION PLANS AND DATA:
   A.   General subdivision data shall describe or outline the existing
conditions of the site and the proposed development as necessary to supplement
the drawings required below. This may include information on existing
covenants, land characteristics, and available community facilities and
utilities and information describing the subdivision proposal, such as number
of residential lots; typical lot width and depth; price range; business areas;
school, playground, and park areas; other public areas, proposed protective
covenants; and proposed utilities and street improvements.
   B.   Sketch plan on topographic survey shall show in simple sketch form the
proposed layout of streets, lots, and other features in relation to existing
conditions. The sketch plan may be a free-hand pencil sketch made directly on a
print of the topographic survey. The sketch plan shall include the existing
topographic data listed in section
9-5-2 of this chapter. (1977 Code § 11-5-1)
9-5-2: PLATS AND DATA FOR PRELIMINARY APPROVAL:
   A.   Preliminary plat shall be at a scale of one hundred feet to one inch
(1" = 100') or, if the area of the subdivision is more than two hundred (200)
acres, two hundred feet to one inch (1" = 200'). It shall show all existing
conditions, topographic data, and proposed improvements including the
following:
      1.   Boundary lines: bearings and distances.
      2.   Easements: location, width and description.
      3.   Existing and proposed streets on and adjacent to the tract; name and
width of right of way and pavement; approximate grades and gradients; angles,
radii, arcs and central angles of curves; walks, curbs, gutters, culverts, etc.
      4.   Proposed lot lines, lot dimensions, building setback lines, lot
number, block numbers and lot area.
      5.   Sites, if any, to be reserved or dedicated for schools, parks,
playgrounds or other public uses.
      6.   Sites, if any, for multi-family dwellings, shopping centers,
churches, industry or other nonpublic uses exclusive of single-family
dwellings.
      7.   Site data table, including total tract acreage, number of
residential lots, average area of lots, acreage of streets and acreage of
public land to be dedicated other than streets.
      8.   Proposed name of the subdivision.
      9.   Location by section, township and range.
      10.   Name and address of the owner, developer, subdivider and engineer
or surveyor preparing the plat.
      11.   Title, graphical scale, northpoint and date.
      12.   Key plan showing location of the tract, lakes, streams, schools and
parks.
      13.   Identification and description of existing and proposed sewers,
water mains, fire hydrants, wells, culverts, septic systems (including minimum
seepage field area) or other underground facilities within the tract or
adjacent to the tract, indicating pipe sizes, grades, manholes and locations
and storm and sanitary sewer outfalls; location of existing gas lines, electric
and telephone lines. If water mains are not on or adjacent to the tract,
indicate the direction and distance to, and the sizes of, the nearest one.
      14.   Ground elevations on the tract based on the USGS datum plane.
Contour line shall be shown at one foot (1') intervals.
      15.   A natural resources inventory report by the Lake County soil and
water conservation district, plus additional subsurface conditions on the
tract, if required by the Plan Commission; location and results of tests made
to ascertain subsurface soil, rock, and groundwater conditions; depth
groundwater soils test pits are dry, at a depth of five feet (5'); location and
results of soil percolation tests if individual sewage disposal systems are
proposed. A soils survey map, prepared by a certified soils scientist, which
shows the soil conditions on the property based on examination of soils test
cores taken in intervals of not less than two hundred feet (200') each, but
with a minimum of two (2) per acre.
      16.   Other conditions on the tract: watercourses, marshes, rock outcrop,
wooded areas, isolated preservable trees one foot (1') or more in diameter,
houses, barns, shacks, and other significant features.
      17.   Other conditions within three hundred feet (300') of the tract:
approximate direction and gradient of ground slope, including any embankments
or retaining walls; character and location of buildings, railroads, power
lines, towers and other nearby nonresidential land uses or adverse influences;
and owners of adjacent unplatted land (for adjacent platted land, refer to
subdivision plat by name, recording data, and number, and show approximate
percent built up, typical lot size, and dwelling type).
      18.   The flow lines and shorelines of streams and channels; and the
normal water elevation and shorelines of lakes, ponds, swamps and other
detention basins.
      19.   The delineation of all floodplains and wetlands including base
flood elevations.
      20.   Location of existing field drainage tiles, inlets and outfalls, if
any.
      21.   Comprehensive drainage system plan (first in preliminary form),
designed to convey the stormwater runoff following the 100-year storm event in
accordance with title 5, chapter 5 of this code.
      22.   Other preliminary plans. When required by the Plan Commission, the
preliminary plat shall be accompanied by profiles showing existing ground
surface and proposed street grades, including extension for a reasonable
distance beyond the limits of the proposed subdivision; typical cross sections
of the proposed grading, roadway, and sidewalks; and preliminary plan of
proposed sanitary and stormwater sewers with grades and sizes indicated. All
elevations shall be based on the USGS datum plane.
      23.   Draft of proposed covenants whereby the subdivider proposes to
regulate land use in the subdivision and otherwise protect the proposed
development.
   B.   A letter or statement from the Illinois department of natural resources
that the consultation process mandated by state law for possible endangered
species has been undertaken, with the results thereof, or evidence that the
consultation process has been undertaken. (1977 Code § 11-5-2)
9-5-3: PLATS AND DATA FOR FINAL APPROVAL:
The following are required for final plat approval:
   A.   The final plat shall be drawn on tracing cloth or mylar measuring not
less than eight and one-half inches by fourteen inches (81/2" x 14") nor more
than thirty inches by thirty six inches (30" x 36") with a scale of one inch
equals one hundred feet (1" = 100') and shall show the following:
      1.   Monuments, primary control points, or descriptions and "ties" to
such control points, to which all dimensions, angles, bearings and similar data
on the plat shall be referred. A minimum of two (2) monuments shall be
referenced to the Illinois state plane coordinate system on the plat.
      2.   Tract boundary lines, right of way lines of streets, easements and
other rights of way, and property lines of residential lots and other sites,
with accurate dimensions, bearings or deflection angles, and radii, arcs and
central angles of all curves.
      3.   Name and right of way width of each street or other right of way.
      4.   Location, dimensions and purpose of any easement.
      5.   Number to identify each lot or site and block.
      6.   Purpose for which sites, other than residential lots, are dedicated
or reserved.
      7.   Building setback lines on all lots and other sites.
      8.   Location and description of monuments.
      9.   Statement by owner dedicating streets, rights of way and any sites
for public use.
      10.   Name of subdivision.
      11.   Complete metes and bounds legal description of the parcel to be
subdivided.
      12.   Location by section, township and range.
      13.   Title, scale, north arrow and date.
      14.   The following statement regarding septic systems: "In approving
this plat of subdivision, the municipality has not undertaken or reviewed any
tests or data relative to the suitability of individual lots for septic
systems. Prior to the issuance of a building permit, the municipality will
require evidence that soil conditions for the lots in question permit the use
of septic systems".
      15.   Certificates and other such affidavits, endorsements or dedications
as may be required in the enforcement of these regulations. Certificates
include, but are not limited to: County Clerk certificate, municipal
certificate, owner's certificate, surveyor's certificate, drainage certificate,
school district certificate, highway department certificate, Lake County health
department certificate, Village Health Officer certificate, and Village
Engineer certificate.
   B.   Plans, profiles, and cross sections of streets showing grades, approved
by the Village Engineer. The profiles shall be drawn to Village standard scales
and elevations and shall be based on the NAVD88 datum plane.
C. Engineering plans and details of required public improvements including, but
not limited to, sanitary and storm sewer facilities approved by the Village
Engineer and Village Health Officer. The topography data on the engineering
plans shall include the surface water drainage certification as required by the
plat act of the Illinois Compiled Statutes 1 .
   D.   Covenants, conditions and restrictions or other forms of protective
covenants in form for recording, if applicable.
   E.   Letter to the Lake County Recorder from the surveyor who prepared the
final plat designating the Village Clerk or the Village Attorney as the person
authorized to record the plat.
   F.   Soil borings and percolation tests for each proposed lot determined by
the Village Health Officer to be satisfactory pursuant to requirements of this
code. The tentative location on the lot of the septic field and any building
may be subject to change; provided, that soil borings and percolation test
results are determined by the Health Officer to be satisfactory at the
alternative location on the lot.
   G.   Provisions to implement ordinances of any fire protection district, if
applicable.
   H.   An electronic copy of the final approved subdivision plat shall be
submitted in AutoCAD format as approved by Village Engineer and referenced to
the Illinois state plane coordinate system and NGVD88 datum. (Ord. 1200, 2-23-
2011)

1 1. 765 ILCS 205/0.01 et seq.
CHAPTER 6
DEDICATION OF LANDS FOR PUBLIC USE AND/OR CASH CONTRIBUTIONS

9-6-1: LEGISLATIVE INTENT:
As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision or of a final plat of
a planned development, each subdivider or developer shall be required to
dedicate land for library, Village park, recreational, fire/rescue and school
purposes to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the
development, or shall be required to make a cash contribution in lieu of actual
land dedication, or a combination of both, at the option of the Village with
the concurrence of the affected district or districts, which concurrence shall
be obtained in writing. However, the Village shall have the final decision
making power in this regard. Land dedication sites may be made to the Village
or to the applicable district at the discretion of the Village Board. The
dedications and cash contributions required hereunder shall be made in
accordance with the criteria and formulas of this chapter. (Ord. 915, 2-13-
2003)
9-6-2: CRITERIA FOR REQUIRING SCHOOL SITE DEDICATIONS:
   A.   Requirement And Population Ratio: The ultimate number of students to be
generated by a subdivision or planned development shall bear directly on the
amount of land required to be dedicated for school sites. The land dedication
requirement shall be determined by obtaining the ratio of: 1) estimated
children to be served in each such school classification over the 2) maximum
recommended number of students to be served in each such school classification
as stated herein, and then applying such ratio to 3) the appropriate number of
acres for a school site of each such school classification as stated herein.
The product thereof shall be the acres of land deemed needed to have sufficient
land for school sites to serve the estimated increase in number of students for
each such school classification.
However, if in the written opinion of the Village Administrator, the density
formula is not appropriately applied because the new development will be an age
restricted community or extended care facility that is not expected to have any
significant impact on school enrollment, the Village Administrator may
recommend to the Village Board that the educational facilities impact fee
requirements be waived or modified for the specific development without the
necessity of an objection procedure pursuant to section
9-6-17 of this chapter. The Village Board either may accept the recommendation
by a majority vote of the Board members, or failing that, may refer the matter
to the Plan Commission for consideration pursuant to the terms of section
9-6-17 of this chapter. (Ord. 1150, 11-19-2008)
   B.   School Classifications And Size Of School Site:
      1.   These requirements for acreage are based upon a review of available
data studies and literature on the subject, including, but not limited to,
information provided by the state superintendent of education and the unique
characteristics of the Village, including its general rural character and open
spaces, and the desire of the residents to maintain this character and open
space in future school sites. These requirements for acreage shall be presumed
as the appropriate acreage requirements and shall be used in calculating any
cash in lieu of land dedication herein, unless timely objected to as provided
herein. Objections to these acreage requirements for any particular development
shall be made in accordance with section
9-6-17 of this chapter to the Plan Commission. Failure to timely object to
these acreage requirements in accordance with said section
9-6-17 shall thereafter waive any right to raise an objection at a later time.
      2.   School classifications and size of school sites within the Village
shall be determined in accordance with the following criteria:
